(d)  Mutual aid agreements. The coordinator of ESDA may negotiate mutual aid agreements with other cities or political subdivisions of the state, but no such agreement shall be effective until it has been approved by the village president and by the state director of ESDA. 
Sec. 8-20. - Members. 
(a)  Oath. Every person appointed to serve in any capacity in the village ESDA organization shall, before entering upon his duties, subscribe to the following oath, which shall be filed with the coordinator: 
"I, ____________ do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support and defend and bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of Illinois, and the territory, institutions and facilities thereof, both public and private, against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully swear (or affirm) that I do not advocate, nor am I nor have I been a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this state by force or violence; and that during such time as I am affiliated with the Village of Bourbonnais ESDA organization, I will not advocate nor become a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this state by force or violence." 
(b)  Compensation. Members of the ESDA who are paid employees or officers of the village, if called for training by the state director of ESDA, shall receive for the time spent in such training the same rate of pay as is attached to the position held. Members who are not such village employees or officers shall receive for such training time such compensation as may be established by the village president. 
Sec. 8-21. - Financial provisions. 
(a)  State reimbursement for expenses. The village treasurer may receive and allocate to the appropriate fund, any reimbursement by the state to the village for expenses incident to training members of the ESDA as prescribed by the state director of ESDA, compensation for services and expenses of members of a mobile support team while serving outside the village in response to a call by the governor or state director of ESDA, as provided by law, and any other reimbursement made by the state incident to ESDA activities as provided by law. 
(b)  Purchase and expenditure authority. The village president may, on recommendation of the village coordinator of ESDA, authorize any purchase of contracts necessary to place the village in a position to combat effectively any disaster resulting from the explosion of any nuclear or other bomb or missile, and to protect the public health and safety, protect property, and provide emergency assistance to victims in the case of such disaster, or from manmade or natural disaster. 
In the event of enemy-caused or other disaster, the village coordinator of ESDA is authorized, on behalf of the village, to procure such services, supplies, equipment or material as may be necessary for such purposes, in view of the exigency without regard to the statutory procedures or formalities normally prescribed by law pertaining to village contracts or obligations, as authorized by "The State ESDA Act of 1975." If the village board meets at such time he shall act subject to the directions and restrictions imposed by that body. 
(c)  Tax levy, appropriation. The board of trustees may make an appropriation for ESDA purposes in the manner provided by law, and may levy in addition for ESDA purposes only, a tax not to exceed $0.05 per $100.00 of the assessed value of all taxable property in addition to all other taxes, as provided by the "State ESDA Act of 1975"; however, that amount collectable under such levy shall in no event exceed $0.25 per capita. 
(Ord. No. 77-309, 6-6-77) 
Chapter 9 - ELECTRICITY[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 91-808, pt. 1, adopted March 4, 1991, amended former Ch. 9, §§ 9-1-9-4, relative to electricity, to read as herein set out. The provisions of former Ch. 9 derived from original codification and Code 1973, §§ 9-3-9-6 and Ord. No. 80-449, adopted Oct. 27, 1980. 
Cross reference- Building regulations generally, Ch. 7; fire prevention, Ch. 11; trimming near wires, § 33-20. 
State Law reference- Registration of electrical contractors, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 11-33-1; inspection of electrical equipment, Ch. 24, § 11-27-1 et seq. 

Sec. 9-1. - Electrical code adopted. 
    The National Electrical Code, 1990 Edition, as published by the National Fire Protection Association, be and is hereby adopted as the electrical code of the Village of Bourbonnais and is hereby amended, explained and supplemented as hereinafter set forth, for the control and safeguarding of persons and property from hazards arising from the use of electricity; and each and all of the regulations of the National Electrical Code, 1990 Edition, are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part of this section, as if fully set out in this section. When any provisions of the National Electrical Code, 1990 Edition, conflict with the provisions of this chapter, the provisions of this chapter shall control. Furthermore, this chapter provides for penalties and enforcement provisions which shall apply to any violations or requirements of the National Electrical Code, 1990 Edition, in general. 
(Ord. No. 91-808, Pt. 1, 3-4-91) 
Sec. 9-2. - Permits. 
(a)  Permits issued by the building department shall be required of all persons performing or contracting to have done any electrical work within the confines of this village. Such work shall include wiring of single-family residential, multifamily, commercial and industrial buildings, garages and storage sheds or work shops. Permits shall be required for the installation of TV cable, exterior lighting, telephone, sign, warning, alarm and security systems and shall be in the possession of such persons before any work is begun. Violators of this stipulation shall be subject to citation and penalties as outlined in section 9-4 of this chapter. 
(b)  Permits shall be issued to qualified homeowners who intend to perform their own electrical work. Such homeowners shall indicate their intention and so state on the permit form provided. The permit shall be issued to allow them to do electrical work on their own property (excluding multifamily units) and they shall follow all provisions of the electrical code. Such work shall be subject to the inspection and approval of the electrical inspector. When the work is to be done by the owner, the permit shall so state and shall bear the signature of said owner. 
(c)  A qualified homeowner shall be one who can, by his performance, demonstrate his ability to properly perform such work to the reasonable satisfaction of the electrical inspector. Failure to do so shall culminate in the denial of that privilege and he shall be required to employ a qualified tradesman or contractor to complete the job. 
(d)  Permits shall be issued to those persons qualified, registered and insured as electrical contractors who may be under contract to perform a given work and the permit shall be issued by the electrical inspector or his designated assistant and shall bear the signature of the person or persons responsible for its completion. 
(Ord. No. 91-808, Pt. 1, 3-4-91) 
Sec. 9-3. - Registration of contractors. 
(a)  It shall be required of every electrical contractor working within the Village of Bourbonnais to be registered with the village building department. 
(b)  All persons and/or agents of that person who are not electrical contractors and wish to do electrical work in this jurisdiction shall be registered with the building department before their work begins. They shall be required to show proof of their qualification to perform in that capacity to the reasonable satisfaction of the electrical inspector and their signature shall appear on the electrical permit. 
(Ord. No. 91-808, Pt. 1, 3-4-91) 
Sec. 9-4. - Penalties. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be subject to a fine of $50.00 for the first day of offense and $100.00 for each subsequent day of offense thereafter. Each day that such violation continues unassuaged shall be deemed a separate offense and shall be charged cumulatively. 
(Ord. No. 91-808, Pt. 1, 3-4-91) 
Sec. 9-5. - Electrical inspection department. 
(a)  Creation, composition. There is hereby created the department of electrical inspection, the duties of said department to be performed by the member or members thereof, composed of a chief electrical inspector and any number of assistant electrical inspectors who shall be appointed by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(b)  Powers and duties. It shall be the duty of the chief electrical inspector and the assistant electrical inspectors to enforce all of the regulations outlined in this chapter and in the current National Electrical Code (hereinafter referred to as the NEC). The electrical inspectors shall have full authority to modify or waive said regulations by giving special permission in particular cases where such action shall be advisable, prudent, or in the best interests of the village. Such "special" permission shall be made in a charge order form signed by both parties prior to the commencement of the work and a copy kept on file in the building department. 
(c)  Compensation, supervision of personnel. The compensation of the chief electrical inspector and such assistant electrical inspectors as from time to time may be appointed shall be fixed by resolution of the president and the board of trustees. The assistant electrical inspectors shall be under the supervision of the chief electrical inspector. 
(Ord. No. 91-808, Pt. 1, 3-4-91) 
Sec. 9-6. - Electrical commission. 
    There shall be an electrical commission, consisting of six members as follows: The chief electrical inspector shall be a member and ex officio chairman of the commission; of the other five members, one shall be a registered professional engineer, one an electrical contractor, one a journeyman electrician, one a representative of an inspection bureau maintained by the fire underwriters, if such a representative resides in the municipality, and if no such representative resides in the municipality, then the chief of the fire department, and one representative of an electricity supply company. If there is no person residing in the municipality who is qualified under any one of these descriptions, the president may appoint some other person to fill that position. All members of the electrical commission shall be appointed by the president with the advice and consent of the corporate authorities. 
(Ord. No. 91-808, Pt. 1, 3-4-91) 
Sec. 9-7. - Administration. 
(a)  Responsibility and liability. The electrical regulations of this code shall not be construed to relieve from or lessen the responsibility of any person owning, operating, selling, offering for sale, or installing any electrical wires, apparatus, appliance or equipment, for damages to anyone injured by any defect therein by reason of the inspection authorized herein or the certificate of inspection issued by the building department or the electrical inspectors, nor shall the Village of Bourbonnais be held liable for any damages resulting from the enforcement of the regulations of this code. The electrical inspectors shall not be liable for any problems arising out of any electrical installation which he may have inspected. Upon the completion of any project which he has approved, the contractor or electrical practitioner responsible for such work shall sign a certificate of completion and shall be held responsible for any ensuing disaster which might occur. 
(b)  Notification of progress for inspection. It shall be incumbent upon the permit holder, that person to whom the permit is issued or the registered contractor and/or agent performing the work to inform the building department that a job has progressed to a point requiring inspection. Points of inspection are: 
(i)  Upon the completion of the installation of a service entrance on a building or structure; 
(ii)  Upon the completion of that stage of development known as the "rough in"; and 
(iii)  Upon the completion of the entire electrical installation and prior to assuming occupancy or utilization of the premises. 
(c)  Authority to enter buildings. The electrical inspectors are hereby authorized to enter any building or premises, occupied or vacant, at any reasonable hour in the discharge of his duties. It shall be competent for them, when deemed to be necessary, to remove or cause to be removed any existing obstruction such as laths, plaster board, wall board, partitions or siding which may prevent a completion inspection of the electrical equipment in question. They shall be authorized to enter any building used in whole or in part for the purpose of public assemblage at any time, when occupied by the public, in order to examine electrical equipment in such building. It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with an inspector in the performance of his duties. 
(d)  Right of entry. (PM 104.4 of BOCA code, 1990). If any owner, occupant or other person in charge of a structure subject to the provisions of this code refuses, impedes, inhibits, interferes with, restricts or obstructs entry and free access to any part of the structure or premises where inspection authorized by this code is sought, the administrative authority shall be permitted to seek, in a court of competent jurisdiction, an order that such owner, occupant or other person in charge cease and desist with such interference. 
(e)  Authority to stop work. No electrical conduit, wires, equipment or apparatus shall be installed in any building or structure for which a permit is required until such permit shall have been secured. Any such installations made prior to having procured a proper permit for same shall be a violation of the electrical regulations of this code and of this village and the electrical inspectors shall have the power to stop all such work at once and to order any and all persons engaged therein to stop and desist therefrom until proper permit has been secured. 
    Failure to comply with such order of an electrical inspector shall be a violation of the code and shall merit a citation for noncompliance with these regulations. Violation shall be subject to penalties as outlined in section 9-4 of this chapter. 
    A "stop work order" shall also be enforceable by application to the circuit court for an order of injunction. 
(f)  Notices and seals. The electrical inspectors are hereby empowered to attach to cabinets, equipment or structures, any official notice or seal to prevent the use of electricity or premises. It shall be unlawful for any other person to put or attach such seal or to break, change, destroy, tear, mutilate, cover or otherwise deface or injure any such official notice or seal posted by an electrical inspector. Penalties for such violation shall be as outlined in section 9-4 of this chapter. 
(g)  Certificate of occupancy. 
(1)  A certificate of occupancy shall be required before any owner, agent, proprietor, landlord or tenant shall be allowed to inhabit or utilize any structure or premises while it remains under the consideration and scrutiny of the building department. Premises under construction shall be deemed construction sites under the law and shall be subject to applicable regulations. Said sites shall remain "construction sites" until certified by the building department, having been finally inspected and approved, to be ready for occupancy and/or utilization. 
(2)  No premises, residential or commercial, shall be occupied until a certificate of occupancy has been issued by the building department signifying the legal, safe and satisfactory completion of the work undertaken to assure the health and welfare of any and all occupants thereof. 
(Ord. No. 91-808, Pt. 1, 3-4-91) 
Sec. 9-8. - Approved equipment and installation methods. 
(a)  Only those electrical equipments, appliances and devices which are listed and approved for use by Underwriters Laboratories, Canadian Standards Association (C. S. A.) or other NEC-approved testing agency shall be installed in the Village of Bourbonnais. 
(b)  Article B-310-2b of the NEC shall be amended to include the following exception: Aluminum or copper-clad aluminum wire shall not be used for any wiring in the Village of Bourbonnais. 
    The conditions set forth in this chapter shall apply from the point where the source of public power is connected to the service entrance conductors and throughout the entire succeeding structure or structures. 
(c)  Where rework or rewiring of any building or structure of 50 percent or more, then all wiring shall be made code complaint. 
(d)  All service entrance systems installed in this jurisdiction shall be installed by electrical contractors registered with the building department. Violators of this section shall be subject to a fine as outlined in section 9-4 of this chapter. 
(e)  All service entrances shall be made in accordance with the specifications as outlined in the current NEC article 230. Article 230-43 with the exception of Item 5: SE or USE cable-: 11: MC cable-: 12: Mineral-insulated or metal-sheathed cable shall not be used as a service entrance. 
(f)  All overhead-type service entrance installations shall use rigid or intermediate metal conduit (IMC) or rigid aluminum conduit as the riser from the meter socket to the weather head. Service entrance installation shall be made in a workmanlike manner and firmly attached to the building or structure it is designed to serve. 
(g)  No service entrance shall be installed on any buildings within the village limits which is smaller than 100-amp capacity without the specific approval and permission of the electrical inspectors. Such approval shall be governed by the amperage requirements of that particular application. 
    A 100-amp service entrance conduit shall be a minimum of one and one-fourth inch diameter rigid pipe. The service conductors shall be three #3 copper THHN conductors. A 200-amp service entrance conduit shall be not less than one and one-half inch diameter rigid pipe and shall have three #3/0 copper THHN conductors. 
(1)  In cases where the service riser is intended to serve as the sole support of the service drop, it shall be per the Commonwealth Edison requirements for the supply of electrical service, page 84, i.e. "Rigid steel conduit two and one-half inch for 100-Amp or smaller or three inch for larger service entrance-". 
(2)  All electrical distribution panels shall be fed in conduit from the metering source. 
(3)  No distribution panel shall be installed in any closet where working space is limited or where combustible materials are stored in hazardous proximity. Article 100-16. 
(4)  Electrical distribution panels using plug fuses for circuit interrupters shall not be approved for use in this village to protect more than two circuits. This is not intended to prevent the use of fused disconnects as a disconnect means for specific appliances. 
(h)  Grounding and bonding . 
(1)  All parts of the service entrance system, raceways (pipe at both ends) and enclosures shall be effectively bonded to the grounding electrode. See articles 230-63 and 250-B through J. The grounding conductor shall be firmly landed in each enclosure. Concentric or eccentric knockouts shall not be considered to be adequate to affect acceptable bonding unless the maximum knockout is being used for the raceway fitting in which case a solid locknut will be used both inside and outside of the enclosure to assure bonding. See article 250-72, c, d and e. Where a lessor [lesser] knockout is used, a lock nut shall be used on the outside of the enclosure and a bonding bushing will be required on the inside with a jumper to the enclosure to affect continuity to ground. All fittings are to be made up wrench tight. 
(2)  In residential wiring, a grounding electrode (ground rod) shall be installed and the grounding electrode conductor from the meter socket to the grounding electrode shall be firmly attached to the building or structure it is designed to serve. For 100-amp service, no grounding conductor smaller than No. 6 AWG shall be used for this application and it is required that it be sheathed for protection as described in paragraph (3) below. For 200-amp service, no grounding conductor smaller than No. 4 AWG shall be used. It shall not be required to sheath a #4 conductor but it shall be firmly attached to the building for protection against possible injury or damage. The current NEC shall determine the conductor size in all cases. 
(3)  If it is elected that the ground electrode conductor be protected by electrical metallic tubing (EMT), it shall be firmly attached to the meter socket and to the building or structure to guard against accidental damage. Both ends of this EMT shall be bonded to the grounding conductor by NEC approved methods. Exception: A straight length of nonmetallic tubing (PVC) which may or may not be attached to the meter socket is acceptable for this purpose but it too will be required to be firmly mounted to the building or structure it is intended to serve. 
(4)  All grounding conductors and the grounding electrode conductor shall be effectively connected to the metal cold water piping system to the extent that such piping exists. 
(5)  Approved grounding clamps shall be used to install a bonding jumper of not smaller than No. 6 copper around the water meter. It shall be of sufficient length to allow the removal of said meter without disconnecting the jumper. 
(6)  All equipment grounding conductors shall be copper. 
(7)  Article 250-83, c,1 shall be amended for the purposes of this chapter and galvanized rod or pipe shall not be used for grounding electrodes. 
(i)  Reserved . 
(j)  Wiring and wiring systems . 
(1)  Wire used for 120V wiring in the Village of Bourbonnais shall be #12 AWG or heavier including switch legs. 
(2)  NM wire (Romex) used in any building or structure where it is approved shall be installed using the methods set forth in article 336-1 through 27 (Exception: (1) article 336-4 as amended by these ordinances. (2) article 336-12 deleted. (3) article 336-16 deleted.) of the current NEC and shall have the grounding conductor carried within the sheath with the circuit conductors. 
(3)  NM (Romex) wire shall be approved for the purpose of wiring single-family residences of elevations not to exceed three stories. A tri-level being considered to be a three-story house for the purposes of this application, the first floor being 50 percent above grade at a point six feet away from the foundation wall. 
(4)  NM wire shall be acceptable for wiring in multifamily attached structures when all units are one story elevations on basements or crawl spaces and are separated by appropriate fire rated party walls. 
(5)  NM wire shall not be permitted to be used as exposed work except as provided for in this chapter. 
(6)  NM wire shall not be used in the construction of single family dwellings which are "stacked"; where one dwelling is above another; or attached to similar dwelling structures separated by properly fire rated party walls. Multi-family buildings, condominium or apartment styles shall be wired in conduit; electrical metallic tubing. 
(7)  In any case where the wiring from one apartment or dwelling must penetrate the party wall of another, that point of penetration shall be firmly caulked to seal against the passage of gases, vapors or fire. 
(8)  All junction boxes intended to accommodate more than two pairs of conductors and one or more devices shall be the four inch box (4×4×11/2-Cap. 9 #12 conductors) designed to be 10 capped with a plaster ring. "Gem" Boxes (3×2×2-Cap. 4 #12 conductors) may be "ganged" to accommodate multiple controlling devices. 
(9)  All buildings or parts of buildings which serve a commercial or industrial enterprise shall be required to be wired in conduit. All residences located in buildings being used for commercial or industrial purposes shall also be wired in conduit. 
(10)  Flat conductor cable (FCC) shall not be used in any construction without the written permission of the electrical inspector. 
(11)  Armored cable (BX) shall not be used in any construction. Article 333 of the NEC is eliminated for purposes of this section. 
(12)  Flexible metal tubing (FMT) may be used in concealed work in dry locations where it is fished in existing walls or in partitions where it is not possible to install conduit, EMT or other approved raceway. FMT larger than one and one-fourth inches in diameter or exceeding six feet in length shall be required to carry a ground wire. 
(13)  FMT shall not be allowed in new partitions or existing partitions where the exterior finish of the wall or partitions has been removed for remodeling. It shall not be approved for use in new construction or exposed work. 
(14)  EMT shall not be used underground, outside exposed to the weather, on outside walls, on roofs, exposed to permanent moisture, in concrete slabs or in contact with earth or fill where, during installation or afterward, it will be subject to mechanical injury. The use of plastic or visqueen or similar materials placed under or over the tubing shall be considered the same as earth or fill. 
(15)  Article 300-4 shall be amended to include the following: Holes bored through floor and ceiling joints for the purpose of creating a wire way for NM wire shall be so located that the openings are not less than two inches above the lowest edge of said joist. 
(16)  Wire(s) installed so as to run on the longitudinal axis of the wide side of any stud shall be stapled as nearly as possible to the centerline of the stud. Staples sufficient in number shall be driven to a depth sufficient to affect control of the wire and to prevent any damage to the conductors throughout the length of its installation. 
(17)  Wires necessarily run through attic areas shall be so located as to leave an open area in the most physically accessible part of the attic which shall be not less than eight feet (generally four feet on either side of a line) under and parallel to the roof ridge member. The purpose for this rule is to protect such wiring from possible damage by the occupant who may choose to put down flooring or to otherwise utilize that area for storage. 
(18)  When wiring with NM (Romex) the use of the crawl space area as a wire chase or wireway shall be avoided. The load side wiring or "home run" shall not be installed in the crawl space without a special variance from the inspector in the jurisdiction before it is installed. All wire runs shall be made along lateral and longitudinal axis of the building or structure. Wiring run on diagonal orientations will be rejected. It shall be allowed to run NM in a crawl space to subtend some otherwise impossible structural corner treatment. 
(19)  An exception to the above article shall be that SE wire may be used and run in a crawl space to add an electric dryer or air conditioner to an existing residence. It shall be run in a protected and controlled manner and run in a parallel and/or perpendicular orientation to existing structural members. 
(20)  All low-voltage wiring, sound or telephone, indicator feeds or computer or cash register, bell or warning wiring or cable TV antenna wiring shall not be run in such a way as to be supported by any suspended ceiling. It shall follow the same axes of the building or structure as other wiring in the system and be supported and controlled by sufficient means; insulated staples or other fasteners designed for such purposes. 
(21)  In a commercial application, wiring described in [subsection] (17) above shall be run in EMT when run in vertical walls. 
(22)  In residential application, TV coaxial cable shall not be run on the surface of the ground but shall be buried in the earth at a depth of not less than six inches. 
(23)  In all commercial construction, places where public assembly is encouraged or is a condition of operation, it shall be required in (but not limited to) hotels, motels, lounges, taverns, offices, waiting rooms or any areas of similar treatment, wiring of fire alarms, smoke detectors and emergency lighting shall be run entirely in conduit. Splices and terminations shall be made in listed enclosures using appropriate listed fittings. Flexible conduit (Greenfield) used in this application shall not be longer than two feet. 
(24)  All accessible low-voltage systems such as warning systems, nurses call stations, bell and buzzer systems, may be installed in a workmanlike manner using plenum-rated cable sized per the manufacturer's recommendations. In "new work" such wiring run in vertical walls shall be in conduit. 
(25)  NM electrical wiring shall not pass within six feet of any attic or storage access portal unless adequately protected from accidental damage per article 333-12a and article 336-13 of the NEC. In no case is wire to be run in the area that passes over the top of joints which may serve as support for future storage or flooring and thereby be exposed to possible accidental damage. 
(26)  In single-family or multifamily residences, a duplex wall receptacle shall be installed in an entry, passage area or hallway. A hallway ten feet in length shall be provided with at least one receptacle. 
(27)  A duplex receptacle shall be installed within 18 inches of each end of a "picture window" opening wider than five feet. 
(28)  In multifamily buildings where a balcony is a feature, one weatherproof GFCI outlet shall be provided on each balcony. 
(29)  The location of light fixtures in closets shall be in accordance with the NEC article 410-8 and shall have enclosed light bulbs when required per that article. 
(30)  All light fixtures shall have at least one bulb in working condition for final inspection. 
(31)  The roughed-in boxes for smoke detectors shall be prominently identified for the benefit of the electrical inspector. One smoke detector shall be located on the ceiling outside of the bedrooms but in the sleeping area. If there is more than one sleeping area, the other(s) shall be similarly protected. A detector shall be located on the ceiling at the top of each stairwell. One detector shall be located in the basement or utility room furnace area on the ceiling. All detectors in a dwelling shall be on a single circuit and shall be so interlocked that any one alarm will actuate them all and all shall be of battery back-up design. 
(32)  One or more porcelain pull chain lighting fixtures shall be provided in crawl spaces. It shall not be necessary to provide protective covering for exposed light bulbs in this application. 
(33)  Unfinished basement areas shall be wired in thinwall conduit (EMT) under the specification of the current NEC and any feeds entering the living quarters above shall be allowed to be fed by NM wire with not more than 18 inches exposed before entry through the floor above, into a wall or sill. 
(34)  Structures, buildings, basements or garages which are remodeled or revised to serve any commercial purposes shall be required to obtain proper permits for said adaptation and shall be subject to all ordinances and licensing appurtenant to their particular intended enterprise and shall be evaluated by applicable standards. 
(35)  Any enterprise which tends to create conditions comparable to those described in the NEC as being class 1 or 2 and division 1 or 2 shall not be allowed. Example: Sanding and/or spray painting of vehicles, cars or equipment; power sanding, buffing and blasting (sand or cob) type operations, but not limited to these listed (See article 500-4). Violators shall be prosecuted as creating a noxious, hostile and/or explosive environment. Proper wiring for such enterprise shall be in conformity with the terms outlined in articles 500, 501, 502, 503, 504, 511 and 516. Penalties for such infractions shall be imposed in accordance with those found in section 9-4 of this chapter. 
(36)  Any business which utilizes a pit type of operation in order to conduct the particulars of its enterprise shall be considered to be utilizing an area where vapors, gases and fumes may accumulate to form a hazardous condition and that pit area shall be wired in accordance with the methods outlined to cover class 1, division 1 or class 1, division 2 conditions in article 504 of the NEC. Or as an alternative method, ventilation of such pit areas shall be such that a volume of air equivalent to six times that of the pit volume shall be circulated out of the pit every hour per article 511-3 of the NEC and the NFiPC National Code, latest edition, for regulation and ventilation of air. 
(37)  Any business which requires storage of flammable liquids or gases shall be required to make special provision for the ventilation of that area and for the drawing off of any accumulated vapors to the outside of the structure. Such system should be designed for the purpose and continuous so that there can be no buildup of combustible vapor to create an explosive or otherwise hazardous condition. Such areas shall be required to install and maintain an approved grounding system to protect against any accumulation of static charge resulting from that storage operation. Vessels used in the transfer of liquids from one to another shall be effectively bonded together during the act of transferring of liquid. Reference BOCA and NFPA. 
(38)  Any electrical receptacles located within six feet of a sink or comparable source of water tap (kitchens, bathrooms, the wet bar in a family room or den and laundry room area) shall be protected by a ground fault circuit interrupter (GFCI) receptacle or breaker. 
(39)  Electrical receptacles in restaurants or bars that are within six feet of any sink or water source or any conductor such as metal tables or decorative metallic trim which may be in continuity with such a water source shall be ground fault protected receptacles. 
(40)  A ground fault receptacle in a residential kitchen may only protect those receptacles in that kitchen. One such receptacle may control as many as four other appliance receptacles (other than a refrigerator or freezer outlet) in that wall but may not protect such receptacles in any other rooms adjacent to the kitchen. Soffitt or ceiling lights or exhaust fans shall not be fed from kitchen appliance circuits. 
(41)  A ground fault receptacle in a bathroom may be allowed to protect another receptacle in a separate bath. 
(42)  A ground fault receptacle in a garage wall can protect as many as five other receptacles within the garage and may include one outdoor weatherproof receptacle located on a common wall. One receptacle in the garage which is meant to serve a refrigerator or freezer should not be ground faulted. 
(43)  It shall not be necessary to ground fault the receptacle for a garage door opener, a sump pump, ejector pump, refrigerator, freezer or a vacuum system located in a crawl space or unfinished basement. It shall be necessary to ground fault all other receptacles located in an unfinished basement or crawl space. 
(44)  The sump pump receptacle shall be a single outlet rather than a duplex per article 210-8a-4, exc. 3. 
(45)  A sump pump, ejector pump, furnace or heating system and laundry receptacle shall each be on an individual branch circuit of its own. 
(46)  The receptacle in a utility room dedicated to serve the washer need not be ground faulted (GFCI) if it is located less than 32 inches from the floor so as to be inaccessible to other uses. Such a receptacle located in an unfinished basement or so as to be readily accessible shall be ground faulted. 
(47)  Outdoor weatherproof receptacles shall be ground faulted individually. When located on the outside of the wall of an attached garage, it shall be permissible to protect it from the garage interior ground fault device. 
(48)  All exterior lighting fixtures shall be mounted on appropriate enclosures, octagon, "gem," or round boxes, and shall be grounded. Any exposed boxes shall be of the weatherproof type. 
(49)  The location of any hot tub, sauna, or swimming facility shall be judged giving consideration to the proximity of existing electrical installations and the particulars outlined in the NEC for such installations shall be enforced. 
(50)  Any light fixture designed to be used as a "lay in" in a suspended ceiling shall not depend upon the grid system of the suspended ceiling to be its sole support but it shall be independently supported by not less than two No. 10 AWG wires from structural members above. 
(51)  Rigid nonmetallic conduit (PVC) wiring systems, raceways, boxes, flexible tubing, extensions and enclosures may be incorporated in any construction installations. Approved rigid nonmetallic conduit may be permitted for underground branch circuits outside or under buildings or in concrete slab work. Underground raceways shall not be less than 18 inches below grade except in areas where they shall be covered by nonporous material such as concrete or black top. Rigid nonmetallic conduit shall have a ground wire run with the enclosed conductors to assure proper grounding continuity. Particular attention is to be given to the grounding of all devices used in such an application to assure absolute grounding continuity. 
(Ord. No. 91-808, Pt. 1, 3-4-91; Ord. No. 18-2096 , § 2, 6-18-18) 
Sec. 9-9. - Emergency lighting. 
(a)  Adequate emergency lighting of exit ways shall be installed and maintained in buildings of all types of occupancy except one- and two-family dwellings. Such lighting shall be of a battery backed up design that will actuate in the event of any power failure. Adequate lighting shall be defined as that amount of light sufficient for occupants to safely find their way to existing exits. 
(Ord. No. 91-808, Pt. 1, 3-4-91) 
Sec. 9-10. - Residential garages, storage units and similar buildings. 
(a)  Where more than one building or other structure is on the same property and under single electrical management, each building or other structure served shall be provided with a means for disconnecting all ungrounded conductors. This disconnecting switch shall be a fused enclosure if it is meant to control more than one circuit. Where more than one circuit is to be controlled, the fused disconnect will be treated as another service panel and will require a separate ground rod and grounding conductor per article 250-24. 
(b)  The feeders for any additional structures, as described in Section 35 above, may be run underground or overhead. Underground feeders shall be copper of sufficient amperage to serve the anticipated demand load and shall be installed in accordance with NEC (Article 300-5) and local ordinances. See subsection 9-8(b) V-B [Village of Bourbonnais] of this chapter. 
(c)  Overhead feeders to such structures shall be copper of sufficient amperage to serve the anticipated demand load (ref. NEC, article 220) and shall be supported per NEC requirements (ref. NEC, articles 225 and 230). In no case will overhead feeders be supported by nor by being passed through any tree or live vegetation. 
(d)  Underground feeders to such structures shall be installed in accordance with the NEC. Direct burial cable is acceptable but shall not be covered until the inspectors have approved the installation. 
(e)  Unfinished garages or other structures shall be wired with EMT. 
(f)  Private or residential garages shall have not less than one ceiling light, one switch and one receptacle. The garage or building shall be on a separate circuit of its own. 
(Ord. No. 91-808, Pt. 1, 3-4-91) 
Sec. 9-11. - Swimming pools. 
    Permits for the installation of swimming pools will not be issued until the proposed site has been affirmed by Commonwealth Edison Company after consideration of their facilities in the immediate area and been approved for installation by the authority in the jurisdiction. The service for all accessories shall conform to NEC requirements. 
(Ord. No. 91-808, Pt. 1, 3-4-91) 
Sec. 9-12. - Temporary services. 
    Any service installed to serve temporarily shall provide ground fault protection for all branch circuits. It shall be classified a temporary service for the duration of the construction period or until adequate permanent electrical service can be provided to the site. In no case shall a temporary service be maintained for a period of time longer than six calendar months without the approval of the electrical inspector. Violators shall be subject to penalties as outlined in section 9-4 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 91-808, Pt. 1, 3-4-91) 
Chapter 10 - ENTERPRISE ZONES[1]

Sec. 10-1. - Definitions. 
    [As used in sections 10-2 through 10-9, the following words and terms shall have the meaning ascribed thereto:] 
    Department. The Department of Commerce and Community Affairs of the State of Illinois. 
    Designated zone organization. The organization or organizations recommended by the administrative entity as authorized by the Enterprise Zone Act. 
    Enterprise zone. The Kankakee River Valley Enterprise Zone. 
    Industrial property. Any real estate used primarily in manufacturing or in the extraction or processing of raw materials unserviceable in their natural state to create new physical products or materials, or in the transportation or storage of raw materials or finished or partially finished physical goods in the wholesale distribution of such materials or goods. 
    Manufacturing property. Any real estate used primarily in the material staging and production of goods used in procedures commonly regarded as manufacturing, processing, fabrication, or assembling which changes existing material into new shapes, new qualities, or new combinations. 
    Parties. The parties to the agreement: Kankakee, Bourbonnais, Bradley, Aroma Park and Kankakee County. 
(Ord. No. 89-740, § 1, 11-20-89; Ord. No. 90-786, § 1, 9-4-90; Ord. No. 92-933, § 1, 2-1-93; Ord. No. 94-993, § 1, 4-4-94; Ord. No. 95-1063, § 1, 8-21-95) 
Sec. 10-2. - Description of enterprise zone. 
    The enterprise zone, which is the subject matter of this agreement, shall be known as the Kankakee River Valley Enterprise Zone. The enterprise zone is comprised of those areas of Kankakee, Bourbonnais, Bradley, Aroma Park and Kankakee County designated by the respective ordinances of the municipalities and county. The enterprise zone is legally described in exhibit A and schematically depicted in exhibit B, both of which are attached to this agreement [Ordinance No. 95-1063] and are hereby incorporated by reference. 
(Ord. No. 89-740, § 2, 11-20-89; Ord. No. 90-786, § 2, 9-4-90; Ord. No. 92-933, § 2, 2-1-93; Ord. No. 94-993, § 2, 4-4-94; Ord. No. 95-1063, § 2, 8-21-95) 
Sec. 10-3. - Administrative entity. 
(a)  Duties. A management organization to be known as the administrative entity will act as a steering committee to the zone administrator. Advice rendered will be determined by a majority vote. 
(b)  Composition. The administrative entity shall be composed of ten members; to include the chief elected officials of the City of Kankakee, the Village of Bourbonnais, the Village of Bradley, the Village of Aroma Park and the chairman of the Kankakee County Board. Each chief elected official will appoint one representative to serve on the board. The zone administrator will not be appointed as a member. 
(c)  Term of office. The term of office of the members of the administrative entity shall expire simultaneously with the expiration of the term of office of the appointing mayor, village president or board chairman. 
(Ord. No. 89-740, § 3, 11-20-89; Ord. No. 90-786, § 3, 9-4-90; Ord. No. 92-933, § 3, 2-1-93; Ord. No. 94-993, § 3, 4-4-94; Ord. No. 95-1063, § 3, 8-21-95) 
Sec. 10-4. - Zone administrator. 
(a)  Selection; removal. The zone administrator shall be appointed by the three-fourths vote of the parties and shall be an employee of one of the parties. The zone administrator shall be removed from office by a majority vote of the parties. 
(b)  Duties. The zone administrator shall: 
(1)  Be the chief executive officer of the enterprise zone; 
(2)  Be authorized to hire and fire personnel for those staff positions established by the board of directors; 
(3)  Develop and recommend a comprehensive planning program for the enterprise zone; 
(4)  Examine and recommend local incentives, benefits and programs to accomplish stated objectives, to stimulate economic activity in the enterprise zone and to address impediments to capital investment; 
(5)  Recommend necessary legislative and administrative controls for guiding enterprise zone development, including planned capital improvements; 
(6)  Coordinate planning activities and program implementation with other city departments and department programs; 
(7)  Act as liaison between the municipalities, county, and any designated zone organization, any federal agency and any local planning groups in support of the enterprise zone program and plan; 
(8)  Act as liaison between the EZ units of government and the department of commerce and community affairs; and 
(9)  Act as program manager responsible for the enterprise zone's day-to-day operations. 
(Ord. No. 89-740, § 4, 11-20-89; Ord. No. 90-786, § 4, 9-4-90; Ord. No. 92-933, § 4, 2-1-93; Ord. No. 94-993, § 4, 4-4-94; Ord. No. 95-1063, § 4, 8-21-95) 
Sec. 10-5. - Designated zone organization. 
    The administrative entity will select one or more designated zone organizations. Each unit of government must pass an ordinance or resolution designating the zone organization. 
(a)  Standards of designated zone organizations. 
(1)  The members of a designated zone organization shall consist substantially of residents of the enterprise zone. 
(2)  The board of directors of a designated zone organization shall be elected by the membership of the organization. 
(3)  A designated zone organization shall meet the requirements of section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code. 
(4)  A designated zone organization shall have as its primary purpose the performance within the enterprise zone of services for the benefit of the residents and businesses of any of the functions set forth in section 8 of the Illinois Enterprise Zone Act. 
(b)  Functions of designated zone organizations. 
(1)  Establishment of crime watch patrols within zone neighborhoods; 
(2)  Establishment of volunteer day care centers; 
(3)  Organization of recreational activities for zone area youth; 
(4)  Energy conservation programs; 
(5)  Drug abuse programs; 
(6)  Senior citizen assistance programs; 
(7)  Rehabilitation, renovation, operation and maintenance of low and moderate income housing; 
(8)  Other types of public services as provided by law or regulations; and 
(9)  Provide a forum for business, labor and government action on the innovations. 
(Ord. No. 89-740, § 5, 11-20-89; Ord. No. 90-786, § 5, 9-4-90; Ord. No. 92-933, § 5, 2-1-93; Ord. No. 94-993, § 5, 4-4-94) 
Note- See the editor's footnote at the beginning of this chapter. 
Sec. 10-6. - Requirements of Act. 
    This area meets the requirements of and is intended to implement the advantages of the Illinois Enterprise Zone Act. 
(Ord. No. 89-740, § 6, 11-20-89; Ord. No. 90-786, § 6, 9-4-90; Ord. No. 92-933, § 6, 2-1-93; Ord. No. 94-993, § 6, 4-4-94; Ord. No. 95-1063, § 5, 8-21-95) 
Sec. 10-7. - Programs established. 
    The following programs are established and authorized within the zone in accordance with the Enterprise Zone Act: 
(a)  Property tax abatement: The Village of Bourbonnais authorizes and directs the county clerk to abate ad valorem taxes imposed upon real property located within the enterprise zone, upon which new improvements have been constructed or upon which existing improvements have been renovated or rehabilitated, subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  Such abatement shall be for a period of five years following the issuance of an occupancy permit and shall be for a percentage of the total value of such improvements as follows: 
Year 1\100% 
Year 2\80% 
Year 3\60% 
Year 4\40% 
Year 5\20% 
(2)  Such abatement shall be allowed only for industrial or manufacturing property in the enterprise zone in general and provided that such remodeling, rehabilitation or new construction is of such a nature and scope for which a building permit is required and has been obtained; and 
(3)  The improvements are to be commenced after the certification of the enterprise zone by the department of commerce and community affairs and an occupancy permit for such improvements, renovation or rehabilitation must be issued prior to June 1, 1999; 
(4)  No property within a redevelopment area created pursuant to the Tax Increment Allocation Redevelopment Act (65 ILCS 5/11-74.4-1 et seq.) shall qualify for a tax abatement under this chapter; 
(5)  In addition to those tax abatements granted generally in the enterprise zone, that portion of the enterprise zone within the Village of Aroma Park shall be allowed an abatement pursuant to the provisions hereof for apartment or residential buildings containing 12 or more units. 
(6)  As a condition of allowance of a property tax abatement under this section, the property owner shall make all good faith efforts to use local contractors and local labor to the greatest extent reasonably possible and to purchase as much of the building supplies and materials within the enterprise zone as reasonably possible. 
(b)  Sales tax credit. Each retailer whose place of business is within the Village of Bourbonnais and who makes a sale of building materials to be incorporated into industrial, commercial or residential real estate located in the enterprise zone by remodeling, rehabilitation or new construction, may file for credit or refund to recover the amount of tax paid under the "Municipal Retailers' Occupation Tax Act" (or the "County Retailers' Occupational Tax Act"); provided, however, that such remodeling, rehabilitation or new construction is of the nature and scope for which a building permit is required and has been obtained. 
(c)  Permit and fee waivers. There will be no charge for building permit fees, inspection fees or zoning application fees for commercial and industrial property. All permits and inspections will otherwise continue to follow existing laws. 
(d)  Industrial revenue bond fee reduction. There will be no municipality or county issuer fee charged. 
(e)  Urban shopsteading. The parties to the enterprise zone agree to establish an urban shopsteading program pursuant to the provisions of the Illinois Enterprise Zone Act. 
(f)  Urban homesteading. The parties to the enterprise zone agree to establish an urban homesteading program pursuant to the provisions of the Illinois Enterprise Zone Act. 
(g)  Program targeting. The parties agree to use their eligibility and resources to make available urban development action grants, Economic Development Administration programs, Small Business Administration programs, Job Training Partnership Act assistance and such other federal and/or state programs as may be eligible and dollars recaptured within the county will be targeted for the enterprise zone. 
(h)  Development streamlining. Each party shall name an individual to be an advocate for all commercial and/or industrial development projects of $200,000.00 and more. This advocate will provide answers to the developers' questions regarding municipal rules, regulations, costs, time lines, processes, etc. 
(i)  Utility tax relief. There will be no increase in any municipality and county utility tax for any new zone business after one year for the following five years it will remain the same. 
(j)  [Other methods of cooperation.] The parties will consider other methods of cooperation with firms as the enterprise zone regulations are finalized. 
(k)  [Cooperation with designated zone organization.] The parties will cooperate with the designated zone organization to assist it in its operation. 
(l)  [Other programs.] In addition to the above-recited programs, all programs available by state statute to an enterprise zone as now existing or hereinafter enacted shall be available within the enterprise zone. 
(Ord. No. 89-740, § 7, 11-20-89; Ord. No. 90-786, § 7, 9-4-90; Ord. No. 92-933, § 7, 2-1-93; Ord. No. 94-993, § 7, 4-4-94; Ord. No. 95-1063, § 6, 8-21-95) 
Sec. 10-8. - Additional tax incentives. 
    This agreement in no way limits the ability of any of the parties to extend additional tax incentives or reimbursement to businesses within the enterprise zone or throughout their jurisdiction by separate ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 89-740, § 8, 11-20-89; Ord. No. 90-786, § 7, 9-4-90; Ord. No. 92-933, § 7, 2-1-93; Ord. No. 94-993, § 7, 4-4-94; Ord. No. 95-1063, § 6, 8-21-95) 
Sec. 10-9. - Approval of designated area. 
    The enterprise zone, as designated herein, requires approval of the Illinois Department of Commerce and Community Affairs and is established pending such approval. The program established herein shall be in effect for 20 calendar years from the original date upon which the enterprise zone was first adopted and certified by the Department of Commerce and Community Affairs. 
(Ord. No. 89-740, § 9, 11-20-89; Ord. No. 90-786, § 8, 9-4-90; Ord. No. 92-933, § 8, 2-1-93; Ord. No. 94-993, § 8, 4-4-94; Ord. No. 95-1063, § 7, 8-21-95) 
Chapter 11 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Board of fire and police commissioners, 2-201 et seq.; false fire alarms, § 3-1; fire zone, § 7-86 et seq.; foreign fire insurance companies, § 18-41 et seq.; traffic restrictions concerning fire apparatus, § 19-56; open burning, § 22-1; notification of hazardous materials incidents, § 22-36 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 11-1. - Department created; membership; appointments. 
    There is hereby created a fire department, an executive department of the village. The fire department shall consist of the fire chief and such other members as may be provided for from time to time by the board of trustees. The fire chief shall be appointed by the president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(Code 1973, § 10-1) 
Sec. 11-2. - Rules governing department. 
    The fire chief may make or prescribe such rules and regulations for the guidance of the members of the department as he shall see fit. Such rules when approved by the board of trustees shall be binding on such members. 
(Code 1973, § 10-2) 
Sec. 11-3. - Duties of chief. 
    The fire chief shall keep such records and make such reports concerning activities of his department as may be required by statute or ordinance. The chief shall be responsible for the performance by the fire department of all its functions, and all persons who are members of the department shall serve subject to the orders of the fire chief. 
(Code 1973, § 10-3) 
Cross reference- Quarterly inspections of nursing and care homes by fire chief, § 21-4. 
Sec. 11-4. - Duty to attend fires, obey chief. 
    It shall be the duty of the members of the fire department to attend all fire calls and other emergency calls that it is reasonably possible for them to attend and in so doing to obey the commands of the fire chief. 
(Code 1973, § 10-4) 
Secs. 11-5-11-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE PREVENTION 

Sec. 11-16. - Adoption of codes. 
    There is hereby adopted by the village, for the purposes of prescribing regulations governing conditions hazardous to life and property from fire or explosion, certain codes known as the National Fire Code (current edition), the BOCA Basic National Fire Prevention Code (current edition), and the Life Safety Code (current edition), and the whole thereof, of which codes not less than three copies of each have been and are now filed in the office of the village clerk of the Village of Bourbonnais, and the same are hereby incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein, and from the date on which this article shall take effect, the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the limits of the Village of Bourbonnais, Illinois. 
Sec. 11-17. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of the code hereby adopted or fail to comply therewith, or who shall violate or fail to comply with any order made thereunder, or who shall build in violation of any detailed statement of specifications or plans submitted and approved thereunder, or any certificate or permit issued thereunder, and from which no appeal has been taken, or who shall fail to comply with such an order as affirmed or modified by the director of the fire prevention bureau, the village board of trustees or by a court of competent jurisdiction, within the time fixed herein, shall severally for each and every such violation and noncompliance respectively, be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not more than $500.00. The imposition of one penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to continue; and all such persons shall be required to correct or remedy such violations or defects within a reasonable time. 
(b)  The application of the above penalty shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions. 
(c)  Each day that a violation shall be allowed to continue shall constitute a separate violation and shall be punishable as such. 
(Code 1973, § 10-26) 
Sec. 11-18. - Validity; conflicting provisions. 
(a)  Should any section or provision of this fire prevention code and this article be declared by a court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid, such decision shall not affect the validity of the article as a whole or any part thereof other than the part so declared to be invalid. 
(b)  If any other ordinance or part of ordinances or codes are in conflict or are inconsistent with the provisions of this article or the fire prevention code hereby adopted, the most stringent code shall prevail. 
(c)  This article shall take effect and be in full force after the date of its passage, approval and publication as provided by law. 
(Code 1973, § 10-27) 
Secs. 11-19-11-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SMOKE DETECTORS 

Sec. 11-31. - Smoke detectors required. 
(a)  Every builder of each new dwelling unit is hereby required to install approved smoke detector or detectors in each dwelling unit as hereinafter provided. 
(b)  Every owner of each existing dwelling unit is hereby required to install approved smoke detector or detectors in each dwelling unit as hereinafter provided. 
(c)  A dwelling unit is defined as a single-family residence, apartment, efficiency apartment and home trailer. 
(d)  Approved smoke detectors shall be capable of sensing visible or invisible particles of combustion and shall provide an alarm signaling device which, when activated, shall be clearly audible in all sleeping rooms when all intervening doors are closed. 
(e)  In the event the property owner wishes to purchase a smoke detector as part of the inspection process, the cost of the detector shall be $10.00 in addition to the $25.00 inspection fee. 
(Ord. No. 77-321, § 1, 11-21-77; Ord. No. 03-1362, § 1, 5-19-03) 
Sec. 11-32. - Violations; penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be subject to a fine of not less than $25.00 nor more than $500.00 for each offense, and each and every day such violation continues, it shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 77-321, § 1, 11-21-77) 
Sec. 11-33. - Location of smoke detectors. 
(a)  At least one approved smoke detector shall be installed near each sleeping area to protect each sleeping area. A sleeping area is defined as an area or areas in which sleeping rooms are located. Where sleeping rooms are separated by other use areas, excluding bathrooms and closets, they shall be considered as separate areas; each requiring an approved smoke detector. 
(b)  At least one approved smoke detector shall be installed at the top of each stairway leading to an occupied area, including the top of a stairway from a basement. An occupied area includes, but is not limited to, a sleeping area. 
An approved smoke detector shall be installed at a location at the top of each stairway in such a manner as to assure that rising visible or invisible particles of combustion are not obstructed in reaching the detector and that the detector intercepts rising visible or invisible particles of combustion before such particles of combustion reach an occupied sleeping area. 
(Ord. No. 77-321, § 1, 11-21-77) 
Sec. 11-34. - Equipment. 
    All devices, combinations of devices, and equipment required herein shall be installed in conformance with the building code and this article, and shall be approved by the fire safety inspector. 
    Approved smoke detectors, as required by this article, shall be those listed by Underwriters Laboratories Inc. and Factory Mutual. 
    Approved smoke detectors listed by Underwriters Laboratories Inc. and Factory Mutual shall be used unless the fire safety inspector subsequently finds that the equipment is hazardous or unreliable, in which case the fire safety inspector may suspend or revoke an approved smoke detector. 
    The fire safety inspector may in any such case determine whether replacement of existing installation shall be required. 
(Ord. No. 77-321, § 1, 11-21-77) 
Cross reference- Building codes adopted, § 7-46. 
Sec. 11-35. - Installation. 
    In new residential occupancies, smoke detectors shall be connected to the building's electrical circuit without a disconnect wall switch and be permanently mounted to a standard electrical outlet or junction box on the ceiling. 
    In existing dwellings, it is preferred that smoke detectors be wired directly to the electrical power supply; however, said detectors may be powered by self-monitored battery or operated in a plug-in outlet which is fitted with a plug restrainer device, provided the outlet is not controlled by any wall switch. 
(Ord. No. 77-321, § 1, 11-21-77) 
Sec. 11-36. - Duty of builder, etc., to comply with this article. 
    Effective upon passage and publication of Ordinance No. 77-321, as amended, it shall be the duty of every builder of each new dwelling unit to install and have in good working condition all approved smoke detectors required by the article. 
    Effective upon passage and publication of Ordinance No. 77-321, as amended, at every change of ownership of a single-family residence, apartment, efficiency apartment, and home trailer and/or mobile home, it shall be the duty of the grantor (seller) thereof to provide the grantee (purchaser) a certificate of compliance issued by the Bourbonnais Fire Department, before change of ownership, stating that all smoke detectors as required by this article are installed and in proper working condition. 
    When an approved smoke detector is installed, the Bourbonnais Building Department shall be notified by the builder or owner of the dwelling unit within five days of installation. 
    When there is a proposed change of ownership of a single-family residence, apartment, efficiency apartment, and home trailer and/or mobile home, the owner (seller) of the single-family residence, apartment, efficiency apartment, or home trailer and/or mobile home shall request a smoke detector inspection from the Bourbonnais Building Department at least five days prior to the closing on the property. 
    Upon receiving a request, the Bourbonnais Building Department shall notify the Bourbonnais Sewer Department of the request for the property proposed to be sold. The sewer department shall then determine whether there are any unpaid sewer bills for sewer service provided by the village to the property proposed to be sold. The sewer department shall notify the building department whether there are any unpaid sewer bills for sewer service provided by the Village to the property proposed to be sold. If there are unpaid sewer bills for sewer service provided by the village to the property proposed to be sold, the village shall not conduct the necessary smoke detector inspection until it receives payment in full for the unpaid sewer bills. The village may demand payment in cash or via certified funds. If there are no unpaid sewer bills for sewer service provided by the village to the property proposed to be sold or once the unpaid bills are paid in full, the building department shall contact the Bourbonnais Fire Department and direct the fire department to inspect said smoke detectors in the property proposed to be sold to ensure compliance with this article. The cost of this inspection shall be $25.00 and shall be paid to the fire department before a certificate of compliance may be issued. Following inspection, the fire department shall issue a certificate of compliance or a certificate of noncompliance to the builder and/or owner of the property and the building department. 
    No single-family residence, apartment, efficiency apartment, and home trailer and/or mobile home shall be conveyed unless the owner (seller) obtained a certificate of compliance from the fire department. 
    Failure to comply with this section shall be punishable as set forth in section 11-32 herein; provided, however, that this section shall not be construed to vitiate or render void any contract or sale agreement. 
    Should any provision or [sub]section of this section be declared invalid by any court of competent jurisdiction, such declaration shall not affect the validity of this section as a whole or any part hereof other than the part so declared to be invalid. 
(Ord. No. 77-321, § 1, 11-21-77; Ord. No. 02-1335, §§ 1, 2, 11-4-02; Ord. No. 02-1348, §§ 1, 2, 12-16-02) 
Sec. 11-37. - Notification of installation; certification of compliance. 
    When an approved smoke detector is installed, the Bourbonnais Fire Department shall be notified by the builder or owner of the dwelling unit within five days of installation. Upon notification, the Bourbonnais Fire Department shall inspect said detectors to ensure compliance with this article. Following inspection, the fire department shall issue a certificate of compliance or a certificate of noncompliance to the builder or owner of the dwelling unit. 
(Ord. No. 77-321, § 1, 11-21-77) 
Sec. 11-38. - Permits and fees. 
    No smoke detector shall be directly connected (permanently wired) to the electrical system of the structure unless an electrical permit shall have first been obtained from the electrical inspector or code enforcement officer. No fee shall be charged for said permit. 
(Ord. No. 77-321, § 1, 11-21-77) 
Chapter 12 - FLOOD DAMAGE PREVENTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) ---

No. 12-1899, § 2, adopted April 16, 2012, amended Ch. 12 by replacing Article II with Articles II through Article IX and renumbering the former Article III to Article X to read in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Article II, §§ 12-16-12-34, pertained to stormwater management, and derived from Ord. No. 79-382, adopted August 6, 1979; Ord. No. 89-739, adopted Nov. 20, 1989; Ord. No. 95-1044, adopted March 6, 1995; Ord. No. 99-1196, § 1, 8-2-99; and Ord. No. 00-1219, adopted July 17, 2000. 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 29; trees, shrubs and weeds, Ch. 33; water and sewers, Ch. 35. 

ARTICLE I. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 12-1. - Introduction. 
    These Regulations provide for the regulation of matters relative to the management of stormwater within the jurisdiction and its extraterritorial jurisdiction to provide no adverse impact on neighboring property owners. Its provisions include, but are not limited to, regulating drainage installations and improvements, requiring the preservation and enhancement of certain natural environmental features, requiring the installation of drainage improvements in developments, regulating uses, maintenance, and activities in floodplains and flood hazard areas, requiring permits, payment of fees and assurances of completion, and providing for inspections and control of work. The requirements, standards and specifications herein provided are in addition to any other applicable legal requirements. 
(Ord. No. 12-1899, § 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 12-2. - Authority. 
(a)  This article shall be known, and may be cited, as the Village of Bourbonnais Stormwater Management Ordinance. 
(b)  The Village of Bourbonnais adopts this article pursuant to its authority to regulate stormwater management and govern the location, width, course, and release of all stormwater runoff channels, streams, and basins in the village. The statutory authority for this article is contained in 55 ILCS 5/5-1041, 5-1042, 5-1043, 5-1049, 5-1062.2, 5-1063, 5-1104, 5-12003, 5-15001 et seq. , 415 ILCS 5/43, the Federal Water Pollution Control Act including Sec. 402(p) (commonly known as the Clean Water Act), the Federal Register, and other applicable authority, all as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 12-1899, § 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 12-3. - Purposes. 
(a)  To maintain and improve the quality of water impacted by the storm drainage system within the Village of Bourbonnais. 
(b)  To promote and protect the public health, safety and general welfare of the citizens from the hazards of flooding. 
(c)  To create a set of fair and consistent standards that will facilitate desirable and sustainable development. 
(d)  To protect and conserve the natural resources. 
(e)  To preserve property values by protecting new and existing buildings and improvements to buildings from damage due to stormwater flow. 
(f)  To assure that new developments and redevelopments do not increase flood or drainage hazards to others, or create unstable conditions susceptible to erosion. 
(g)  To preserve the natural characteristics of stream corridors in order to moderate flood and stormwater impacts and to protect water quality. 
(h)  To prevent the discharge of contaminated stormwater runoff and illicit discharges from industrial, commercial, residential, and construction sites into the storm drainage system. 
(i)  To promote public awareness of the hazards involved in the improper discharge of trash, yard waste, lawn chemicals, pet waste, wastewater, oil, petroleum products, cleaning products, paint products, hazardous waste, sediment and other pollutants into the natural and man-made storm drainage system. 
(j)  To encourage recycling of used motor oil and safe disposal of other hazardous consumer products. 
(k)  To facilitate compliance with state and federal standards and permits by owners of construction sites within the jurisdiction. 
(l)  To enable the jurisdiction to comply with all current federal and state laws and regulations applicable to the National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permitting requirements for stormwater discharges and prepare for future requirements. 
(m)  To prevent additional disruption of the economy and governmental services due to stormwater and flood drainage. 
(n)  To protect the public from the degradation of water quality on a watershed basis and enhance the quantity and quality of potable groundwater and surface water supplies. 
(o)  To protect the quantity and quality of wetlands. 
(p)  To require the design and evaluation of each site stormwater management plan to be consistent with watershed capacities. 
(q)  To require regular, planned maintenance of stormwater management facilities. 
(r)  To encourage cooperation and consistency in stormwater management activities between units of government having floodplain and stormwater jurisdiction. 
(s)  To lessen the taxpayer's burden for flood related disasters, repairs to flood damaged public facilities and utilities, and flood rescue and relief operations. 
(t)  To restrict development and building to facilities that will not adversely affect the potential for flood damage. 
(u)  To require appropriate and adequate provision for site runoff control, especially when the land is developed with a large amount of impervious surface. 
(Ord. No. 12-1899, § 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 12-4. - Abbreviations. 
    The following abbreviations when used in this article shall have the designated meanings: 
BMP - Best Management Practices BFE - Base Flood Elevation CFR - Code of Federal Regulations CWA - Clean Water Act FEMA - Federal Emergency Management Agency FIRM - Flood Insurance Rate Map HHW - Household Hazardous Waste IDNR - Illinois Department of Natural Resources IDPH - Illinois Department of Public Health EPA - U.S. Environmental Protection Agency IEPA - Illinois Environmental Protection Agency MS4 - Municipal Separate Storm Sewer System NPDES - National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System NRCS - Natural Resources Conservation Service (formerly SCS) SCS - Soil Conservation Service (now NRCS) SWCD - Soil and Water Conservation District SWP3 - Stormwater Pollution Prevention Plan USACE - US Army Corps of Engineers USDA - U.S. Department of Agriculture USEPA - U.S. Environmental Protection Agency  
(Ord. No. 12-1899, § 2, 4-16-12) 
Sec. 12-5. - Definitions. 
    Unless a provision explicitly states otherwise, the following terms and phrases, as used in this article, shall have the meanings hereinafter designated. 
    Adverse impacts. Any negative impact on plant, soil, air or water resources affecting quality and quantity and their beneficial uses including recreation, aesthetics and aquatic habitat. 
    Agricultural practices. Normal farming, silviculture and ranching activities, such as gardening, plowing, seeding, cultivating and harvesting, for the production of food, fiber, forest products, nursery stock and livestock. Maintenance of agricultural drain tiles, irrigation and drainage ditches, farm roads and other access areas for farm vehicles and equipment use are also included. These practices shall not include grading, filling or draining flood prone areas with greater than 100 acres of tributary area or a regulatory wetland. 
    Applicant. Any person, firm, or governmental agency who executes the necessary forms to procure official approval of a development or permit to carry out construction of a new development, additions or reconstruction of structures, or re-development from the jurisdiction. 
    Appropriate official. The Village of Bourbonnais village administrator or his/her designee. 
    Base flood elevation (BFE). The elevation shown on the Flood Insurance Rate Map for Zone AE, AH, A1-A30, AR, AR/A, AR/AE, AR/A1-A30, AR/AH, AR/AO, that indicates the water surface elevation resulting from a flood that has a one percent chance of equaling or exceeding that level in any given year. 
    Best management practices (BMPs). Refers to management practices and methods to control pollutants in stormwater. BMPs are of two types: "source controls" (nonstructural) and "treatment controls" (structural). Source controls are practices that prevent pollution by reducing potential pollutants at their source before they come into contact with stormwater. Treatment controls partially remove pollutants from stormwater. The selection, application and maintenance of BMPs must be sufficient to prevent or reduce the likelihood of pollutants entering the storm drainage system. 
    Buffer. An area of predominately vegetated land to be left open adjacent to channels, wetlands, lakes, ponds, or other surface waters for the purpose of eliminating or minimizing adverse effects to such areas, stabilizing banks, reducing contaminants, including sediments, in stormwater that flows to such areas. 
    Building official. The officer or other designated authority charged with the administration and enforcement of the building codes and regulations. 
    Building permit. A permit issued by the jurisdiction for the construction, erection or alteration of a structure or building and the related ground and surface preparation prior to and after completion of construction, erection or alteration of a structure or building. 
    Certify or certification. Formally attesting that the specific inspections and tests were performed, and that such inspections and tests comply with the applicable requirements of this article. 
    Channel. Any defined river, stream, creek, brook, natural or artificial depression, ponded area, on-stream lake or impoundment, abandoned mine, flowage, slough, ditch, conduit, culvert, gully, ravine, wash, or natural or manmade drainageway, that has a definite bed and bank or shoreline, in or into which surface or groundwater flows, either perennially or intermittently. 
    Channel modification. The alteration of a channel by changing the physical dimensions or materials of its bed or banks. Channel modification includes damming, rip-rapping (or other armoring), filling, widening, deepening, straightening, relocating, lining, and significant removal of bottom or woody rooted vegetation. 
    Clearing. Any activity that removes the natural vegetative ground cover. 
    Commercial. Pertaining to any business, trade, industry, or other activity engaged in for profit. 
    Compensatory storage. The NFIP floodway standard in 44 CFR 60.3 (d) restricts new development from obstructing the flow of water and increasing flood heights. However, this provision does not address the need to maintain flood storage. Especially in flat areas, the floodplain provides a valuable function by storing floodwaters. When fill or buildings are placed in the flood fringe, the flood storage areas are lost and flood heights will go up because there is less room for the floodwaters. This is particularly important in smaller watersheds which respond sooner to changes in the topography. One approach that may be used to address this issue is to require compensatory storage to offset any loss of flood storage capacity. Some communities adopt more restrictive standards that regulate the amount of fill or buildings that can displace floodwater in the flood fringe. Community rating system credits are available for communities that adopt compensatory storage requirements. 
    Conduit. Any channel, pipe, sewer or culvert used for the conveyance or movement of water, whether open or closed. 
    Construction site. Any location where clearing, grading, excavation, filling, or other construction activity occurs. 
    Contaminated. Containing harmful quantities of pollutants. 
    Contractor. Any person or firm performing or managing construction work at a construction site, including any construction manager, general contractor or subcontractor. Also includes, but is not limited to, earthwork, paving, building, plumbing, mechanical, electrical or landscaping contractors, and material suppliers delivering materials to the site. 
    Control structure. A structure designed to control the rate of flow that passes through the structure, given a specific upstream and downstream water surface elevation. 
    Dam. Defined by the IDNR.
