    The degree of protection required by this division is considered reasonable for regulatory purposes and is based on available information derived from engineering and scientific methods of study. Larger floods may occur or flood heights may be increased by manmade or natural causes. This division does not imply that development either inside or outside of the floodplain will be free from flooding or damage. This division does not create liability on the part of the village or any officer or employee thereof for any flood damage that results from proper reliance on this ordinance or any administrative decision made lawfully there under. 
(Ord. No. 10-1836, § 2, 1-4-10) 
Sec. 12-203. - Penalty. 
    Failure to obtain a permit for development in the floodplain or failure to comply with the conditions of a permit or a variance shall be deemed to be a violation of this division. Upon due investigation, the building commissioner/floodplain manager may determine that a violation of the minimum standards of this division exists. The building commissioner/floodplain manager shall notify the owner in writing of such violation. 
(1)  If such owner fails after ten days' notice to correct the violation: 
a.  The village shall make application to the circuit court for an injunction requiring conformance with this ordinance or make such other order as the court deems necessary to secure compliance with the division; 
b.  Any person who violates this division shall upon conviction thereof be fined not less than $50.00 or more than $750.00 for each offense; 
c.  A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues; and 
d.  The village shall record a notice of violation on the title of the property. 
(2)  The building commissioner/floodplain manager shall inform the owner that any such violation is considered a willful act to increase flood damages and therefore may cause coverage by a standard flood insurance policy to be suspended. 
The building commissioner/floodplain manager is authorized to issue an order requiring the suspension of the subject development. The stop work order shall be in writing, indicate the reason for the issuance, and shall order the action, if necessary, to resolve the circumstances requiring the stop work order. The stop work order constitutes a suspension of the permit. 
No site development permit shall be permanently suspended or revoked until a hearing is held by the president and village board of trustees. Written notice of such hearing shall be served on the permittee and shall state: 
a.  The grounds for the complaint, reasons for suspension or revocation, and 
b.  the time and place of the hearing. 
At such hearing the permittee shall be given an opportunity to present evidence on their behalf. At the conclusion of the hearing, the president and village board of trustees shall determine whether the permit shall be suspended or revoked. 
(3)  Nothing herein shall prevent the Village of Bourbonnais from taking such other lawful action to prevent or remedy any violations. All costs connected therewith shall accrue to the person or persons responsible. 
(Ord. No. 10-1836, § 2, 1-4-10) 
Sec. 12-204. - Abrogation and greater restrictions. 
    This division repeals and replaces other ordinances adopted by the Village of Bourbonnais to fulfill the requirements of the National Flood Insurance Program including: Ordinance 95-1044 dated March 6, 1995. However, this division does not repeal the original resolution or ordinance adopted to achieve eligibility in the program. Nor does this division repeal, abrogate, or impair any existing easements, covenants, or deed restrictions. Where this division and other ordinance easements, covenants or deed restrictions conflict or overlap, whichever imposes the more stringent restrictions shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 10-1836, § 2, 1-4-10) 
Chapter 13 - FOOD AND FOOD HANDLERS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Alcoholic liquors, Ch. 4; fire prevention, Ch. 11; garbage and trash, Ch. 14; health and sanitation, Ch. 15. 
State Law reference- Municipal regulations as to food, water, disease, etc., Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 11-20-1 et seq.; municipal authority to license, tax and regulate eating places, Ch. 24, § 11-42-5; sanitary requirements for food handling establishments, Ch. 561/2, § 67 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 13-1. - "Food" includes beverages. 
    The term "food" as used in this chapter shall be construed to include beverages. 
(Code 1973, § 11-1) 
Sec. 13-2. - Unwholesome food. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale or keep for the purpose of selling or offering for sale, any food of any kind intended for human consumption which is spoiled or tainted or is unwholesome or unfit for human consumption for any reason. 
    All tainted or unwholesome food intended for human consumption may be condemned by the health officer and shall thereupon be seized and destroyed by the health officer or any policeman. 
(Code 1973, § 11-2; Ord. No. 80-445, 10-27-80) 
Sec. 13-3. - Adulterated food. 
    It shall be unlawful to sell, offer for sale, or keep for such purpose, any food or drink intended for human consumption which has been adulterated by any material harmful in any way, or which does not comply with the statutes governing the same. 
(Code 1973, § 11-3) 
Sec. 13-4. - Cleanliness of premises. 
    Premises used for the sale or storage of food intended for human consumption must be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. It shall be unlawful to permit any accumulation of refuse or waste of any kind to remain thereon for more than 24 hours, and it shall be unlawful to permit any decaying animal or plant material to remain on such premises. 
(Code 1973, § 11-4) 
Sec. 13-5. - Cleanliness, health of employees. 
    All persons engaged in handling or coming in contact with food intended for sale for human consumption shall keep themselves clean, both as to person and clothing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person who is afflicted with, or a carrier of, any infectious or contagious disease to handle or be engaged in the care or preparation of any such food; and it shall be unlawful to permit any such person to be employed in or about any premises where food is stored, prepared or sold, or to deliver any such food. 
(Code 1973, § 11-5) 
Sec. 13-6. - Serving utensils. 
    Utensils for personal use in all places serving food or drink to the public shall be thoroughly cleaned and sterilized after each such usage. 
(Code 1973, § 11-7) 
Sec. 13-7. - Flies and vermin. 
    Premises used for the storage, preparation or sale of food intended for human consumption shall be kept free from flies and vermin and rodents. 
(Code 1973, § 11-8) 
Sec. 13-8. - Penalty for violations. 
    Whenever in this chapter any act is prohibited or made or declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor, or whenever in such chapter the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision of this chapter shall be punished by fine of not more than $500.00. Each day any violation of any provision of this chapter shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 80-445, 10-27-80) 
Secs. 13-9-13-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FOOD DEALERS 

Sec. 13-21. - Defined. 
    The term "food dealer" as used in this article shall be construed to mean and include every person engaged in conducting or operating any business for the storage, handling, preparation or sale of food or drink intended for human consumption. 
(Code 1973, § 11-19) 
Sec. 13-22. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any food dealer to engage in or do business in the village without having first secured a license therefor. 
(Code 1973, § 11-20; Ord. No. 80-445, 10-27-80) 
Cross reference- Licenses generally, Ch. 18. 
Sec. 13-23. - License application required. 
    Applications for licenses required by this article shall be made in accordance with the general provisions of this Code relating thereto and shall state the kind of food intended to be sold or handled. 
(Code 1973, § 11-21) 
Sec. 13-24. - Referral of application; inspection, report. 
    Each application for a license to conduct a business connected with the storage, handling, sale or preparation of food or drink intended for human consumption shall be referred to the health officer, who shall make or cause to be made an investigation of the premises to be used, and report his finding thereon, recommending or advising against the issuance of the license. 
(Code 1973, § 11-22) 
Sec. 13-25. - Revocation of license. 
    Any food dealer's license may be revoked by the president for repeated violation of the provisions of this chapter, or for any violation of any other ordinance provision relating to the conduct of the business, the condition of the premises, the article sold, or to the license required. 
(Code 1973, § 11-23) 
Cross reference- Penalty for violations, § 13-8. 
Chapter 14 - GARBAGE AND TRASH[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Building regulations, Ch. 7; fire prevention, Ch. 11; food and food handlers, Ch. 13; health and sanitation, Ch. 15; nuisances, Ch. 20; open burning, § 22-1; littering in Kankakee River, § 22-27; notification of hazardous materials incidents, § 22-41 et seq.; sewer use, § 35-16 et seq. 
State Law reference- Power of village with reference to garbage, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 11-19-1 et seq.; Environmental Protection Act, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 1111/2, § 1001 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, certain words and terms shall be defined as follows: 
    Approved scavenger. A scavenger duly licensed by the Village of Bourbonnais in accordance with the provisions of chapter 14 article II of the Code of Ordinances of the Village of Bourbonnais, Illinois. 
    Garbage. Wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of foods; wastes from the handling, storage and sale of product. 
    Refuse. Combustible trash, including but not limited to, paper; cartons; boxes; barrels; wood; excelsior; tree branches; yard trimmings; wood furniture; bedding; noncombustible trash, including but not limited to metals, tin cans, metal furniture, dirt, small quantities of rock and pieces of concrete, glass, crockery, and other mineral wastes; street rubbish, including but not limited to, street sweepings, dirt, leaves, catch-basin dirt, and contents of litter receptacles; but refuse does not mean earth and wastes from building operations, nor shall it include solid wastes resulting from industrial processes and manufacturing operations such as food processing wastes, boiler-house cinders, lumber, scraps and shavings. 
(Ord. No. 83-515, 10-3-83) 
Sec. 14-2. - Container required. 
(a)  Multifamily buildings. The owner or duly authorized agent of any multifamily building within the Village of Bourbonnais shall be required to provide a container such as a dumpster, "toter" or other leakproof approved containers provided with close fitting covers of sufficient size to completely contain all garbage and refuse generated by the building's residents between normal collection. 
(b)  Commercial establishments. The owner or operator of all commercial establishments within the village shall provide a container or containers such as a dumpster, "toter" or other leakproof approved container provided with closed, close-fitting covers of sufficient size to completely contain all garbage and refuse generated by the operations of such establishment between normal collections. 
(Ord. No. 83-515, §§ 3, 5, 10-3-83) 
Sec. 14-3. - Collection service contract required. 
(a)  Single-family dwellings. The owner or lessee of each single-family dwelling unit within the Village of Bourbonnais shall keep in full force and effect a contract to pick up garbage and refuse no less than once each week with the franchise scavenger approved by the Village of Bourbonnais, Illinois. 
(b)  Multifamily dwellings. The owner or duly authorized agent of any multifamily dwelling within the village shall be required to execute a contract with an approved garbage collection service for the collection and disposal of garbage and refuse at least once each week. However, nothing in this subsection shall be construed to require the owner of a multi-family dwelling or his duly authorized agent to contract with the scavenger franchised by the Village of Bourbonnais for single-family residential trash and refuse removal. 
(c)  Commercial establishments. The owner or operator of all commercial establishments within the Village of Bourbonnais, Illinois, shall be required to execute a contract with an approved garbage collection service for the collection and disposal of garbage and refuse. However, nothing in this section shall be construed so as to require the owner or operator of a commercial establishment to contract with the scavenger franchised by the Village of Bourbonnais for single-family residential garbage and refuse removal. 
(Ord. No. 83-515, §§ 2, 4, 6, 10-3-83) 
Sec. 14-4. - Penalty. 
    Whenever in this chapter any act is prohibited or made or declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor, or whenever in such chapter the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision of this chapter shall be punished by fine of not more than $500.00. Each day any violation of any provision of this chapter shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 80-444, 10-27-80) 
Sec. 14-5. - Deposit of refuse-Generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit anywhere in the village any uncovered piles of refuse, garbage, offal or carcasses of dead animals. Such refuse must be buried at least two feet below the surface of the ground or burned in properly constructed incinerators or placed in a covered receptacle for the deposit of garbage adequate to make the contents inaccessible to dogs and other animals and to prevent the breeding of flies. Any uncovered pile of refuse is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(Code 1973, § 12-2; Ord. No. 80-444, § 2, 10-27-80) 
Sec. 14-6. - Same-In streets. 
    No garbage or any refuse of any kind shall be deposited in any street, alley or public way, except for purposes of removal by a disposal company or scavenger. 
(Code 1973, § 12-3) 
Cross reference- Deposits on streets, § 29-12; deposits on sidewalks, § 29-13. 
Sec. 14-7. - Pick-up of recyclables by unauthorized persons. 
(a)  No persons or entities other than Allied Waste of Momence, and its agents and employees, successors and assigns shall be authorized to pickup the recyclable materials set out by village residents in the designated recycling bags with the village logo imprinted on each. 
(b)  Any unauthorized person or entity found to be collecting a recycling trash bag containing recyclable materials shall be in violation of this section. Each recycling bag collected by an unauthorized person or entity shall be considered as a separate violation of this section. 
(c)  The recycling bags shall be used only by village residents and only for collection of the recyclable materials listed above. Any use of the recycling bags other than by village residents solely for collection of recycling materials shall be a violation of this section. 
(d)  A person or entity having been found in violation of this section shall be subject to fine by the village of no less than $50.00 nor more than $100.00 for each violation thereof. 
(Ord. No. 94-1001, §§ 1-4, 4-4-94; Ord. No. 10-1846, 3-23-10) 
Sec. 14-8. - Additional garbage fees; payment. 
(a)  Additional charges for garbage and refuse collection imposed upon the village by reason of a party's leaving out for collection garbage and refuse which exceed the weekly per-resident maximum allowable amount shall be paid by the party leaving out for collection such additional garbage and refuse. 
(b)  The owner of the real property on which the additional garbage and refuse which exceeds the weekly per-resident maximum amount is left shall be equally responsible for the payment of such additional charges as are billed to the village. 
(c)  In the event that the owner of the real property or party leaving the additional garbage and refuse for collection fails to pay such additional charges then the village, after giving 30 days' notice to such owner and party, may proceed to enforce the collection of such additional charges through every available legal means and recover, in addition to such unpaid bill, its costs and expenses incurred in such recovery actions, including reasonable attorney's fees. 
(Ord. No. 96-1080, §§ 1-3, 4-1-96) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 96-1080, §§ 1-3, adopted April 1, 1996, which pertained to payment of additional garbage fees, did not specify manner of codification; hence, designation as § 14-8 has been at the editor's discretion. 
Secs. 14-9-14-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SCAVENGERS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses generally, Ch. 18. 

Sec. 14-16. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of scavenger, or the collection or disposal of refuse or garbage, including animal, human or vegetable refuse, or offal, other than collecting such from commercial establishments only, without first having secured a license therefor. 
(Code 1973, § 12-14) 
Sec. 14-17. - Application for license. 
    Application for a scavenger's license shall be made to the clerk, and shall be referred by him to the board of trustees. 
(Code 1973, § 12-15) 
Sec. 14-18. - Bond required; conditions. 
(a)  No scavenger's license shall be issued unless the applicant therefor shall first file a performance bond with sureties to be approved by the board of trustees, in the sum of $5,000.00, with the village as beneficiary, conditioned upon the licensee continuing to properly operate the business of scavenger for the period covered by the license on the following terms: 
(1)  That the licensee will have at least one vehicle in operation in collecting garbage. 
(2)  That the licensee will collect garbage or refuse from each and every resident of the village requesting such service, provided that such resident or residents pay the established fee within 30 days from the date of billing for service rendered, except that the licensee shall not be required to collect garbage recently burned if such burning is indicated or evidenced by live embers, coals, or smoke, or similar indications or evidence. 
(3)  That collection will be made of all garbage and refuse properly placed in suitable containers of 30 gallons or less capacity, which container or containers must be placed by such resident in the alley, but if there is no alley abutting the property of such resident, then at the curb or curbline of such property, provided that such resident shall not be delinquent in payment as hereinbefore provided. 
(4)  That collection of such garbage or refuse shall be made between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. of the day or days of the week selected by such licensee, provided that once such day or days of the week is or are selected, the licensee shall regularly make his collection on such day or days, and in the event such days selected fall on a legal holiday, then such collection shall be made on the day following such holiday. 
(5)  That the term garbage or refuse does not include such materials as concrete, trees, brush, bricks, sand, dirt, building materials, lumber or similar materials. 
(6)  The licensee shall comply with all ordinance provisions relating to the business, and will properly dispose of all garbage and refuse collected. 
(b)  A failure to comply with the provisions hereof because of conditions, acts or occurrences beyond the control of the licensee, or mechanical failure of equipment repaired or replaced promptly or possible, shall not be considered a breach of these conditions. 
(c)  Provided that in lieu of such bond, the licensee may deposit cash or direct general obligations of the federal, state or village government, in the sum of $1,000.00 with the village treasurer, such deposits to be returned upon compliance with the foregoing conditions. 
(Code 1973, § 12-16; Ord. No. 80-444, 10-27-80) 
Cross reference- Requirements for surety bonds generally, § 1-13. 
Sec. 14-19. - Insurance required. 
    No license shall be issued under the provisions of this article unless the applicant for such license has first submitted a certificate by an insurer duly authorized to issue liability policies in the State of Illinois. Such certificate shall show that the applicant for a license has public liability insurance coverage covering his operation within the village and that the same shall not be canceled without at least ten days' notice to the village clerk. Upon the cancellation or expiration without the renewal of such insurance, the license or permit issued hereunder to the insured shall be void. Such insurance shall be in the amount of not less than $500,000.00 per person injured, not less than $1,000,000.00 for all personal injuries in any one accident, and not less than $250,000.00 for property damage in any one accident. 
(Code 1973, § 12-17; Ord. No. 87-634, 9-8-87) 
Sec. 14-20. - License fee. 
    The fee for a scavenger's license shall be $50.00 per year per truck. 
(Code 1973, § 12-18) 
Sec. 14-21. - Issuance of license. 
    No scavenger's license shall be issued except on order of the board of trustees. 
(Code 1973, § 12-19) 
Sec. 14-22. - Number of licenses. 
    No more than one scavenger's license shall be in force at any time in the village. 
(Code 1973, § 12-20) 
Sec. 14-23. - Term of license. 
    Each license granted hereunder shall be for the term of from May 1 until the following April 30. Any applicant for a license must pay the annual fee regardless of the time when the license is issued, and no refunds will be made and no fees will be prorated. 
(Code 1973, § 12-21) 
Sec. 14-24. - Increases in charges. 
    The charges established at the start of the license year for garbage and refuse collection shall not be increased during the license year without the consent of the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1973, § 12-22) 
Sec. 14-25. - Vehicle requirements; Sunday operation prohibited. 
    Any vehicle used by a scavenger in his business shall be watertight and equipped with covers for such portions as are used for the transportation of refuse. It shall be unlawful for any such vehicle to be driven on or through any street in the village during a Sunday. 
(Code 1973, § 12-23) 
Sec. 14-26. - Place of disposal. 
    It shall be unlawful for any scavenger to dispose of or store any refuse in any place within the village limits, or within one and one-half miles thereof, except with the permission of the board of trustees. 
(Code 1973, § 12-24) 
Chapter 15 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Food and food handlers, Ch. 13; garbage and trash, Ch. 14; nuisances, Ch. 20; notification of hazardous materials incidents, § 22-36 et seq. 
State Law reference- General health power of municipality, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 11-20-5; public health and safety, Ch. 1111/2. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 15-1. - Office of health officer created; appointment. 
    There is hereby created the office of health officer, an executive office of the village. He shall be appointed by the president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(Code 1973, § 13-1) 
Sec. 15-2. - Duties of health officer. 
    The health officer shall enforce all ordinances containing provisions for the protection of the public health; he shall make inspection of foodstuffs and of the premises used for storing or selling of provisions as may be provided by ordinance; and he shall perform such other duties and functions as may be required by statute or ordinance. 
(Code 1973, § 13-2; Ord. No. 80-436, 10-27-80) 
Cross reference- Investigation of certain license applications by health officer, § 18-4; authority to abate nuisances, § 20-1; inspection of nursing and care homes, § 21-18. 
Sec. 15-3. - Reports by health officer; recommendations. 
    The health officer shall make such reports to the board of trustees as may be required. He shall also make recommendations for rulings, orders or ordinances respecting the public health whenever he is requested to do so, or whenever he deems it advisable or necessary. 
(Code 1973, § 13-3) 
Sec. 15-4. - Cemeteries; burials. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to bury any person within the village limits or within three-quarters of a mile thereof, except in an established cemetery. 
(Code 1973, § 13-4) 
Secs. 15-5-15-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CONTAGIOUS DISEASES 

Sec. 15-16. - Quarantine, vaccination regulations. 
    The health officer is hereby authorized to make such reasonable rules as may be necessary regarding quarantine and vaccination, for the prevention of the spread of contagious diseases. 
(Code 1973, § 13-15) 
Sec. 15-17. - Spreading disease prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to spread, wilfully or carelessly, any contagious disease or to so cause the spread of the same. 
(Code 1973, § 13-19) 
Sec. 15-18. - Report required. 
    Every physician called in to care for or treat a person afflicted with a contagious disease or any epidemic disease shall make a report of the same within 24 hours of such call to the health officer. In case no physician is in attendance it shall be the duty of the person in charge or having the care of such person to make a report within 24 hours from the time the disease is recognized. 
(Code 1973, § 13-16) 
Sec. 15-19. - Quarantine authorized. 
    The health officer shall have charge of the enforcement of all the quarantine rules. He shall have the power and the authority to place or have placed any premises within which a contagious or epidemic disease occurs under quarantine, and he shall determine the time when the quarantine ends. 
(Code 1973, § 13-17) 
Sec. 15-20. - Fumigation required. 
    Premises which have been quarantined in accordance with the terms of this article shall be thoroughly fumigated or otherwise freed from all risk of contagious disease under the direction of the health officer before the quarantine shall end. 
(Code 1973, § 13-18) 
Sec. 15-21. - Deliveries to quarantined premises. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person engaged in the delivery of food or drink intended for human consumption to enter any premises which are quarantined because of the existence of a contagious or epidemic disease. No containers or bottles shall be removed from any such premises until the termination of the quarantine, and no such container which has been left at such premises during the quarantine shall be placed in use for carrying food or drink until it has been thoroughly sterilized. 
(Code 1973, § 13-20) 
Sec. 15-22. - Violations. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article or violating any of the reasonable rules of the health officer with regard to quarantined premises, or disturbing or disregarding any notice of quarantine placed by or under the direction of the health officer shall be guilty of a violation of this Code. 
(Code 1973, § 13-21) 
Secs. 15-23-15-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - EXTERMINATION OF RATS 

Sec. 15-31. - Notice to abate. 
    If it is determined by the village president, the chief of police, the administrator or the public health officer that rats exist or are breeding in any area of the village, they shall notify the property owners and tenants that such condition exists on their property, and that abatement of such condition must begin within 24 hours by an exterminator licensed by the State of Illinois. 
(Ord. No. 82-488, § 1, 5-3-82) 
Sec. 15-32. - Abatement by municipality; lien. 
    If such abatement is not completed, the corporate authorities shall take all necessary steps to abate the rats and their breeding grounds. The cost of expense of such abatement shall be a lien upon the real estate affected, superior to all other existing liens and encumbrances except tax liens if within 60 days after such costs and expenses incurred, the municipality or person performing the service by authority of the municipality, in his or its own name files a notice of lien in the office of the Recorder of Deeds of Kankakee County, Illinois. 
(Ord. No. 82-488, § 2, 5-3-82) 
Sec. 15-33. - Notice of lien; release; foreclosure. 
(a)  The notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting out: 
(1)  A description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof; 
(2)  The amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred or payable for the service; 
(3)  The date or dates which costs and expenses were incurred by the municipality. 
(b)  Upon payment of the cost and expense by the owner or persons interested in the property, after notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be released by the municipality or person in whose name the lien has been filed, and the release may be filed of record as in the case of the filing notice of lien. 
(c)  The lien may be enforced by proceedings to foreclose as in cases of mortgages or mechanics' liens. 
(d)  Suit to foreclose this lien shall be commenced within one year after the date of filing notice of lien. 
(Ord. No. 82-488, §§ 3-6, 5-3-82) 
Chapter 16 - HISTORIC PRESERVATION 

Sec. 16-1. - Title. 
    This chapter shall be known, referred to and cited as the "Historic Preservation Ordinance" of the Village of Bourbonnais. 
(Ord. No. 85-562, § 1(A), 11-4-85) 
Sec. 16-2. - Purpose and scope. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to provide a mechanism whereby landmarks and districts in the Village of Bourbonnais identified as having historical and/or architectural significance may be preserved and enjoyed in a suitable harmonious environment. 
(1)  Such landmarks and districts which embody a sense of time and place unique to the Village of Bourbonnais or which may exemplify or reflect the history of the nation, state or community or which may be representative of the distinguishing characteristics of an architectural type of a period, style, method of construction or of local materials or craftsmanship upon designation shall be protected from alteration. 
(2)  The purpose of this chapter is to promote the educational, cultural, economic and general welfare of the community by: 
a.  Protecting, enhancing and perpetuating the distinctive historical and/or architectural characteristics of Bourbonnais, which represent elements of the village's cultural, social, economic, political and architectural history; 
b.  Fostering civic pride in the beauty and noble accomplishments of the past as represented in Bourbonnais' landmarks and historic districts; 
c.  Stabilizing and improving property values of Bourbonnais' landmarks and historic districts; 
d.  Protecting and enhancing the village's attractiveness to tourists and visitors and the support of business and industry thereby provided. 
(Ord. No. 85-562, § 1(B), 11-4-85) 
Sec. 16-3. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, certain words, phrases and terms shall be construed as set out in this section. 
    Alteration. Any act or process which changes one or more of the "exterior architectural features" of a building or structure designated for preservation. 
    Architectural significance. 
(1)  The building(s) or structure(s) is the work of or associated with a nationally or locally noted architect, builder or architectural firm. 
(2)  The building(s) or structure(s) is an example of a particular style (whether local or typical) in terms of detail, material, workmanship and with no or negligible alteration to the original structure. 
(3)  The building(s) or structure(s) is one of the few remaining examples of a particular style, use or an example which does not clearly represent a major style and has undergone little or no alteration since its construction. 
(4)  The building(s) or structure(s) is one of a contiguous grouping of such which have a sense of cohesiveness expressed through a similarity of characteristics of a style, period or method of construction and accenting the architectural significance of the area. 
(5)  The detail, material and workmanship can be valued in and of themselves as reflective of or similar to those of the majority of the other visual elements in the area. 
    Board. The president and board of trustees of the Village of Bourbonnais. 
    Building. A structure created to shelter any form of human activity, such as a house, barn, church, hotel or similar structure. Buildings may refer to a historically-related complex such as a courthouse and jail or a house and barn. 
    Certificate of appropriateness. A certificate from the commission authorizing plans for alterations, construction, removal or demolition of an improvement(s) within its jurisdiction as defined by this chapter. 
    Commission. Landmark commission. 
    Demolition. Any act or process which destroys, in part or in whole, a building, structure or object. 
    Design criteria. A standard of appropriate activity that will preserve the historical and architectural character of the building, structure, object or area. 
    Exterior architectural appearance. Includes the architectural character, general composition and general arrangement of the exterior of a building or structure, including the kind and texture of the building material and the type and character of all windows, doors, light fixtures, signs and appurtenant elements visible from public streets and thoroughfares. 
    Historical significance. 
(1)  The building(s) has a strong association with the life or activities of a person or persons who have contributed to or participated in the historic events of the nation, state or community. 
(2)  The building(s) or structure(s) is associated with an organization or group (whether formal or informal) from which they have contributed to or participated in the historic events of the nation, state or community. 
(3)  The building(s) or structure(s) or object(s) is associated with an antiquated use due to technological or social changes in the nation, state or community such as, but not limited to, a blacksmith shop, covered bridge, and hitching post. 
(4)  The object(s) is a monument to or a cemetery of historic personages. 
    Improvement. Any building, structure, object, parking facility, fence, gate, wall, work of art or other object constituting a physical betterment of real property, or part of such betterment. 
    Landmark. Any "improvement" which has special character or special historical and/or architectural interest or value as part of the development, heritage or cultural characteristics of the Village of Bourbonnais, the State of Illinois or the nation which has been designated as a "landmark" in compliance with the provisions of this chapter. 
    Object. A material thing of functional, architectural, cultural, historical or scientific value that may be, by nature or design, movable yet related to a specific setting or environment. 
    Structure. A work made up of interdependent and interrelated parts in a definite pattern of organization. Constructed by man, it is often an engineering project large in scale. 
(Ord. No. 85-562, § 2, 11-4-85) 
Sec. 16-4. - Landmark commission-Created; membership; quorum; meetings. 
(a)  Creation and composition of landmark commission. There is hereby created a landmark commission which shall consist of five members. At least one member shall be a representative of the Bourbonnais Historical Society; at least one member shall be an architect or designer; and the remaining three members at large shall have demonstrated an interest in historic preservation. All members shall be residents of the Village of Bourbonnais or own real estate therein except that an architect or designer may be appointed to the commission who is not a resident of the village. 
(b)  Term. The mayor shall appoint, subject to the approval of the board of trustees, the members of the landmark commission for terms of three years. Initial members shall serve staggered terms of: one member for three years; two members for two years; and the remaining two members for one year. Members may serve for more than one term. 
(c)  Officers. The commission shall elect from its membership a chairperson and a vice-chairperson who shall serve for terms of one year and who shall be eligible for reelection. The chairperson shall preside over meetings. In the absence of the chairperson, the vice-chairperson shall perform the duties of the chairperson. 
(d)  Quorum; attendance requirement. A quorum shall consist of a majority of the members. All recommendations to the president and board of trustees shall be made by a majority vote of those members present at any meeting where a quorum exists. Persons on the commission must attend two-thirds of all meetings scheduled or called, or they may be replaced by another person as recommended by the mayor and approved by the board of trustees. 
(e)  Meetings. Meetings shall be held at regularly scheduled times or at the call of the chairperson. Proceedings of each meeting shall be recorded by the secretary of the commission who shall be designated by the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 85-562, § 3(A), 11-4-85; Ord. No. 86-577, 4-21-86) 
Sec. 16-5. - Powers and duties. 
    The commission shall have two categories of duties and powers: the first dealing with general activities involving landmark identification; and the second dealing specifically with landmarks. 
(1)  Landmark identification. 
a.  Standards and criteria for identification of landmarks shall be derived from the characteristics of historical significance and/or architectural significance in the building, structure, object and/or area. 
b.  The commission shall conduct, within the corporate limits of the Village of Bourbonnais, a survey from which all buildings and structures shall be classified and designated on the historical and architectural building map to be reviewed by the board of trustees and made part of a series of official maps. Such buildings and structures shall be divided into three categories, the first two of which are not mutually exclusive: 
1.  Historically significant. 
2.  Architecturally significant. 
3.  Noncompatible-A building(s), structure(s), or object(s) which has no historical and architectural significance. 
c.  The village clerk will be the depository for all maps and reports created by and for the landmark commission. This historic preservation material shall be available to the public. 
d.  The commission shall have the power to retain consultants to advise the commission, subject to the approval of the board of trustees. Any contract which involves an expenditure of village funds shall be subject to the prior approval of the board of trustees. 
e.  The commission shall work for the continuing education of the Village of Bourbonnais with respect to the historical and architectural heritage of the village and the landmarks designated under the provisions of this chapter. It shall keep current and publish a register of landmarks. 
(2)  Concerning landmarks. 
a.  The landmark commission shall establish a design criteria which shall be applied to landmarks requesting certificates of appropriateness (see subsection 16-10(c)). 
b.  The commission shall keep a register of all buildings, structures and objects within the corporate limits of Bourbonnais which have been designated a landmark as set forth by procedures in this chapter. This register will include the formation required for each landmark designation and appropriate maps. 
c.  The commission shall hold public hearings and make subsequent recommendations to the board of trustees on applications for improvements to be designated as landmarks within the corporate limits of Bourbonnais. Designation is subject to the guidelines and procedures set forth by this chapter. 
d.  The commission shall hold public hearings and make recommendations to the board of trustees on all matters relating to certificates of appropriateness concerning landmarks under its jurisdiction subject to the standards set forth in this chapter. 
e.  The commission shall act as a resource consultant for owners of designated landmarks. The commission will keep a current file of architects, historians, preservationists and restorationists concerned with historic preservation. 
(Ord. No. 85-562, § 3(B), 11-4-85) 
Sec. 16-6. - Landmark designation. 
(a)  [Criteria established.] There are hereby created criteria and procedures for the designation of landmark(s) within the corporate limits of the Village of Bourbonnais. Designation of a landmark is subject to the procedures and guidelines as set forth in this chapter. 
(b)  Criteria for landmark designation. The following criteria shall be utilized by the landmark commission in determining the designation of landmarks: 
(1)  Historical significance; or 
(2)  Architectural significance; and 
(3)  Economic and functional potentials-The economic and functional potentials of the improvement are to be considered; and 
(4)  Other qualities and characteristics-Such other qualities and characteristics as in the judgment of the commission shall be considered for the designation of a landmark. 
(c)  Procedures for designation for landmarks. 
(1)  Application. Any person, group of persons or association may request an historic landmark designation for any improvement within the corporate limits of the Village of Bourbonnais which may have historic or architectural significance as set forth in section 16-5(1). The secretary of the commission shall supply, upon request, the application forms. Completed forms shall be submitted to the secretary of the commission. 
(2)  [Notification.] The commission shall thereafter notify the owner of such real property of the proposed designation. Whenever possible, the landmark commission shall secure the owner's written consent to the proposed designation. In the event that such owner shall refuse or decline to give his or her written consent to the proposed designation, the commission shall require a petition to be submitted with a minimum of 25 signatures of real property owners or residents of the Village of Bourbonnais. 
(3)  Public hearing. Upon receipt of such application or petition, the secretary of the commission shall schedule a public hearing, to be held within 15 days from the receipt of such application or petition, on the question of proposed designation, setting forth a date, time and place and causing written notice to be given to the owner or any person having a legal or equitable interest in the property being proposed for designation (not including people with a leasehold interest). The commission shall cause a legal notice to be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the Village of Bourbonnais setting forth in the nature of the hearing, the property involved and the date, time and place of the scheduled meeting. 
(4)  [Review; evaluation.] During the public hearing, the commission shall review and evaluate the application or petition according to the criteria established in section 16-6(b). 
(5)  [Compilation of information.] Following the public hearing, the secretary of the commission shall prepare the commission's evaluation, recommendation and all available information for submission to the board of trustees. 
(6)  [Submission to clerk.] At the next regularly scheduled meeting of the board of trustees following the public hearing, the chairperson of the commission shall submit in writing the commission's evaluation, recommendation and all available information to the village clerk. 
(7)  [Board action.] The board of trustees shall act upon designation within 30 days from the submission by the chairperson of the commission. A simple majority vote by the board of trustees is necessary for approval of landmark designation. If the board of trustees approves the application or petition for designation, a notice will be sent to the property owner and recorded with the county recorder of deeds. If the board of trustees denies the petition or application, no petitioner or applicant can file for 90 days to the secretary of the commission. 
(d)  [Consideration period.] The consideration period on proposed landmark(s) shall commence at the time of the submission of the application to the secretary of the commission and continue until the final board of trustees decision. During this period, the code enforcement officer for the Village of Bourbonnais shall impose a moratorium on any construction, alteration, demolition or removal of improvements on the property proposed for landmark designation. 
(Ord. No. 85-562, § 4, 11-4-85) 
Sec. 16-7. - Procedures and guidelines for actions of the landmark commission. 
(a)  [Certificate of appropriateness.] A certificate of appropriateness issued by the commission shall be required before a landmark visible from a public way is: 
(1)  Changed or modified; 
(2)  Reconstructed; 
(3)  Erected, wholly or in part; 
(4)  Moved; or 
(5)  Demolished, wholly or in part. 
Exterior paint schemes, storm doors, storm windows, screens, window air conditioners, antennae, and similar cosmetic items are not subject to a certificate of appropriateness. 
(1)  No individual, group, organization or village department shall commence such action in this subsection (a), paragraphs (1) through (5), without first obtaining a certificate of appropriateness. 
(2)  A certificate of appropriateness shall be required for any of the actions listed in this subsection (a), paragraphs (1) through (5), even when the action does not require a building or demolition permit. 
(3)  No building or demolition permit shall be issued for work visible from a public way on any landmark unless a certificate of appropriateness has been issued for such work. 
(4)  Notwithstanding, a certificate of appropriateness shall be issued if the applicant shows to the commission that a failure to grant the permit will cause an imminent threat to life, health or property. 
(b)  [Application.] The application for the certificate of appropriateness, available from the building inspector and returned to same, shall include the following information: 
(1)  Street address of property involved. 
(2)  Legal description of the property involved. 
(3)  Brief description of the existing improvements situated on the property. 
(4)  Detailed description of the construction, alteration, demolition or use proposed together with any architectural drawings or sketches if these services have been utilized by the applicant; and if not, a sufficient description of the construction, alteration, demolition and use to enable anyone to determine what the final appearage of the real estate will be. 
(5)  Owner. 
(6)  Developer, if different from owner. 
(7)  Architect, if utilized or retained. 
(8)  Each application shall be accompanied by such sketches, drawings, photographs, descriptions or other information not to exceed the size of eight and one-half inches by 14 inches, as may be reasonably required by the commission to make a decision. 
The code enforcement officer shall, within five working days, submit copies of the completed application for certificate of appropriateness to the village administrator and the secretary of the commission. 
The application for certificate of appropriateness shall be reviewed at the next meeting of the commission following its receipt by the secretary of the commission from the code enforcement officer. 
The secretary of the commission shall submit to the code enforcement officer a current list of landmarks. 
(c)  Criteria for issuance of certificate of appropriateness for landmarks. 
(1)  The application for certificate of appropriateness shall be reviewed at the next meeting of the landmark commission following its receipt by the secretary of the landmark commission. 
(2)  If the landmark commission finds that the activity proposed by the application: 
a.  Will not adversely affect the significant historical or architectural character cited in the application for landmark designation as called for in section 16-6(b); and 
b.  Is appropriate and consistent with the design criteria established for the landmark as created by section 16-10(c); or 
c.  Will remedy conditions imminently dangerous to life, health or property as determined in writing by the code enforcement officer; 
then the landmark commission shall issue a certificate of appropriateness. 
(d)  Denial of certificate of appropriateness for landmarks. 
(1)  If the landmark commission finds the activity proposed by the applicant as not meeting any of the subheadings in section 16-7(c)(2), then the commission shall disapprove the application and so advise the applicant and code enforcement officer in writing of the denial. 
(2)  Following the denial of the certificate of appropriateness by the landmark commission, the secretary of the landmark commission shall transmit to the owner a letter within five working days stating changes requested by the landmark commission before the certificate of appropriateness will be issued. The letter will address itself to the appropriate criteria. If the owner agrees to such changes in writing to the commission and the commission is satisfied that the criteria in section 16-7(c) will be met, it shall issue a certificate of appropriateness; if not, the certificate of appropriateness shall be denied subject to appeal. 
(e)  Demolition or removal of a landmark or structure. 
(1)  Demolition or removal procedure. The commission secretary shall notify the commission of any application for a certificate of appropriateness involving the demolition, partial demolition or removal of a structure or significant accessory structure. The commission shall schedule a public hearing within 21 days of the receipt of the application for a certificate of appropriateness with proper notification through the newspaper and shall notify the applicant in writing. At the hearing, the commission shall request the following information: 
a.  A report from the code enforcement officer on the state of repair and structural stability of the structure under consideration. 
b.  Information and graphics on the extent and process of demolition or removal, including information on any proposed changes in landscaping. 
c.  Evidence of any hardship that would result in substantial economic loss to the applicant from denial of the petition. 
d.  An assessment of any alterations in the essential character of the area which would occur as a result of demolition or removal action. 
(2)  Decision of commission towards demolition or removal. If the commission's decision is to postpone the demolition or removal, the commission shall notify the owner in writing. During the period set forth for postponement of the requested action, the commission shall explore alternatives to demolition or removal. Such alternatives may include consultation with private civic groups, interested private citizens and other public boards or agencies in an effort to find a persuasive means of preserving the structure. If sale of property is considered a feasible alternative to the owner, the building must remain on the open market, dependent on its classification, for the following lengths of time: 
a.  Historically and architecturally significant: Six months. 
b.  Noncompatible: No waiting period. 
If, after a period not to exceed six months, no alternative agreement has been reached with the applicant, the commission shall issue a certificate of appropriateness for demolition or removal of the structure in question. 
(f)  [Commission recommendations.] In granting the certificate of appropriateness, the commission shall recommend conditions necessary to minimize the adverse impact of the requested activity as outlined in section 16-7(a). 
(g)  Appeals. Where the commission has denied issuance of a certificate of appropriateness, the applicant for such certificate may appeal to the board of trustees. Such appeal must be filed with the village clerk within 15 days after the decision of the commission. The board of trustees shall hold a public hearing and shall vote on such appeal within 45 days of its receipt. 
(1)  A simple majority vote of the board of trustees in opposition to the denial must be recorded in order for a denial by the landmark commission to be overturned. 
(2)  A simple majority vote of the board of trustees in support of the denial must be recorded in order for a denial by the landmark commission to stand. The board of trustees shall transmit their decision in writing to the code enforcement officer and the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 85-562, § 5, 11-4-85) 
Sec. 16-8. - Enforcement and penalties for violation. 
(a)  Any person who fails to perform any act required herein or performs any act prohibited herein shall be fined, upon conviction, not less than $250.00, or not more than $500.00 for each offense. Every day such violation exists shall constitute a separate violation and a separate offense. 
(b)  In addition to the penalty provided above, the Village of Bourbonnais may bring an appropriate action in the circuit court to enjoin any action undertaken by any person in violation of this chapter and to restore any property to its condition prior to such unauthorized action. 
(Ord. No. 85-562, § 6, 11-4-85) 
Sec. 16-9. - Relation to other ordinances. 
(a)  Nothing herein is to be construed as repealing any requirement relating to the proper wiring, plumbing and construction of any building or structure, all work to be in conformity with the building codes and ordinances of the Village of Bourbonnais as now in effect or as provided by ordinance. If such a permit would otherwise be required, an application for a building or demolition permit shall be submitted in conjunction with the application for a certificate of appropriateness. 
(b)  All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are, to the extent of such conflict, hereby repealed. 
(Ord. No. 85-562, § 7, 11-4-85) 
Sec. 16-10. - Severability; time requirements. 
(a)  If any provision, clause or phrase of this chapter or the application thereof to any person or circumstances is held invalid, such invalidity shall affect other provisions or applications of this chapter which can be given effect without the invalid provisions or applications, and to this end the provisions of this chapter are declared to be separable. 
(b)  It shall be the responsibility of the mayor to appoint, subject to approval of the board of trustees, the five persons to serve on the commission, as established in section 16-4(a), within 60 days of the passage of this chapter. 
(c)  It shall be the responsibility of the commission to prepare guidelines for design criteria necessary in the issuance of a certificate of appropriateness for landmarks and submit such guidelines for approval by the board of trustees within 60 days of the passage of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 85-562, § 8, 11-4-85) 
Chapter 17 - HOUSING[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Alarms, Ch. 3; building regulations generally, Ch. 7; one and two family dwelling code adopted, § 7-81; moving buildings, § 7-121 et seq.; electricity, Ch. 9; fire prevention, Ch. 11; flood damage prevention, Ch. 12; garbage and trash, Ch. 14; extermination of rats, § 15-31 et seq.; historic preservation, Ch. 16; nursing and care homes, Ch. 21; peddlers and solicitors, Ch. 24; plumbing, Ch. 26; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 29; house numbering, § 29-91 et seq. 

Sec. 17-1. - Code adopted. 
    The village hereby adopts by reference the most recent edition of the CABO One and Two Family Dwelling Code promulgated by the Building Officials Conference of America, Inc. 
Sec. 17-2. - Minimum value established. 
    No person shall in the village erect any new building to be used for occupancy as a dwelling, either for himself or for others, or shall convert any building to be used for occupancy as a dwelling either for himself or others, unless the cost of such building so being built or so being converted is at least the amount of $30,000.00. 
Sec. 17-3. - Penalty. 
    Whenever in this chapter any act is prohibited or made or declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor, or whenever in such chapter the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision of this chapter shall be punished by fine of not more than $500.00. Each day any violation of any provision of this chapter shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
Chapter 18 - LICENSES AND BUSINESS REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Alarms, Ch. 3; alcoholic liquors, Ch. 4; amusements, Ch. 5; food and food handlers, Ch. 13; scavengers, § 14-16 et seq.; business nuisances, § 20-8; nursing and care homes, Ch. 21; peddlers and solicitors, Ch. 24; signs, Ch. 28; paving by private persons, § 29-46 et seq.; swimming pools, Ch. 31; taxation, Ch. 32; vehicles for hire, Ch. 34. 
State Law reference- Authority of village to fix the amount, terms and manner of issuing and revoking licenses, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 11-60-1. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - License required. 
    Whenever a license is required for the maintenance, operation or conduct of any business or establishment, or for doing business or engaging in any activity or occupation, any person shall be subject to the requirement if by himself or through an agent, employee or partner, he holds himself forth as being engaged in the business or occupation; or solicits patronage therefor, actively or passively; or performs or attempts to perform any part of such business or occupation in the village. 
(Code 1973, § 15-2) 
Sec. 18-2. - To whom application made; contents. 
    Applications for all licenses and permits required by ordinance shall be made in writing to the clerk in the absence of a provision to the contrary. Each application shall state the name of the applicant, the permit or license desired, the location to be used, if any, the time covered and the fee to be paid; and each application shall contain such additional information as may be required by ordinance or as may be needed for the proper guidance of village officials in issuing the permit or license. 
(Code 1973, § 15-1) 
Sec. 18-3. - Forms. 
    Forms for all licenses, permits and applications therefor shall be prepared and kept on file by the clerk. 
(Code 1973, § 15-3) 
Sec. 18-4. - Referral, investigation of application. 
    Upon the receipt of an application for a license or permit where the ordinance of the village necessitates an inspection or investigation before the issuance of such permit or license, the clerk shall refer such application to the proper officer for making such investigation within 48 hours of the time of receipt. The officer charged with the duty of making an investigation or inspection shall make a report thereon, favorable or otherwise, within ten days after receiving the application or a copy thereof. The health officer shall make or cause to be made an investigation in regard to such licenses in connection with the care and handling of food and the prevention of nuisances and the spread of disease, for the protection of health. All other investigations except where otherwise provided shall be made by the chief of police or some other officer designated by the president. 
(Code 1973, § 15-4) 
Sec. 18-5. - Fees. 
    In the absence of provision to the contrary, all fees and charges for licenses or permits shall be paid in advance at the time application therefor is made to the clerk. When an applicant has not engaged in the business until after the expiration of part of the current license year, the license fee shall be prorated by quarters and the fee paid for each quarter or fraction thereof during which the business has been or will be pursued. Except as otherwise provided, all license fees shall become a part of the corporate fund. 
(Code 1973, § 15-5) 
Sec. 18-6. - Termination of licenses. 
    All annual licenses shall terminate on the last day of April of each year, where no provision to the contrary is made. 
(Code 1973, § 15-6) 
Sec. 18-7. - Compliance with other ordinances. 
    No license shall be issued for the conduct of any business and no permit shall be issued for any thing or act, if the premises and building to be used for the purpose do not fully comply with the requirements of the ordinances of the village. No such license or permit shall be issued for the conduct of any business or performance of any act which would involve a violation of the zoning ordinances of the village. 
(Code 1973, § 15-7) 
Sec. 18-8. - Change of location. 
    The location of any licensed business or occupation, or of any permitted act, may be changed, provided ten days' notice thereof is given to the clerk, in the absence of any provision to the contrary, provided that the building, zoning and frontage consent requirements of the ordinances are complied with. 
(Code 1973, § 15-8) 
Sec. 18-9. - Cooperation in inspections, analyses. 
(a)  Whenever inspections of the premises used for or in connection with the operation of a licensed business or occupation are provided for or required by ordinance, or are reasonably necessary thereto to secure compliance with any ordinance provision or to detect violations thereof, it shall be the duty of the licensee, or the person in charge of the premises to be inspected, to admit thereto for the purpose of making the inspection any officer or employee of the village who is authorized or directed to make such inspection at any reasonable time that admission is requested. 
(b)  Whenever an analysis of any commodity or material is reasonably necessary to secure conformance with any ordinance provision to detect violation thereof, it shall be the duty of the licensee of the village whose business is governed by the provision to give any authorized officer or employee of the village requesting the same sufficient samples of such material or commodity for such analysis upon request. 
(c)  In addition to any other penalty which may be provided, the president and the board of trustees may revoke the license of any licensed proprietor of any licensed business in the village who refuses to permit any such officer or employee who is authorized to make such inspection or take such sample to make the inspection, or to take an adequate sample of the commodity, or who interferes with such officer or employee while in the performance of his duty in making such inspection, provided that no license shall be revoked for such cause unless written demand is made upon the licensee or person in charge of the premises, in the name of the village, stating that such inspection or sample is desired at the time it is sought to make the inspection or to obtain the sample. 
(Code 1973, § 15-9) 
Sec. 18-10. - Posting license. 
    It shall be the duty of any person conducting a licensed business in the village to keep his license posted in a prominent place on the premises used for such business at all times. 
(Code 1973, § 15-10) 
Sec. 18-11. - Vehicle tags. 
    Whenever the number of vehicles used is a basis of a license fee, the clerk shall furnish each licensee with a tag or sticker for each vehicle covered by the license, and such tag or sticker shall be posted in a conspicuous place on each such vehicle while it is in use. 
(Code 1973, § 15-11) 
Sec. 18-12. - Penalty. 
    Whenever in this chapter any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor, or whenever in such chapter the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision of this chapter shall be punished by a fine of not more than $500.00. Each day any violation of any provision of this chapter shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 80-450, 10-27-80) 
Sec. 18-13. - Revocation of license or permit. 
    Any license or permit issued for any business within the village pursuant to the applicable ordinances may be revoked for any violation of the terms and conditions upon which the license or permit was issued, or any ordinance relating to the license or permit or the subject matter thereof, and it is unlawful to continue to exercise any privilege or authority granted by any license or permit issued by the village or any of its duly authorized officers or employees, after such license or permit has been so revoked. 
(Ord. No. 03-1353, § 1, 3-17-03) 
Sec. 18-14. - Revocation hearing notice. 
    Notice of the hearing for revocation of a license shall be given in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of the complaint and the time and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be set by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the licensee at his/her last known address at least five days prior to the date set for the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 03-1353, § 1, 3-17-03) 
Sec. 18-15. - Revocation hearing procedures. 
    The village attorney shall present the complaint and shall represent the village. The licensee shall be permitted counsel and shall have the right to submit evidence and to cross-examine witnesses. The village president shall preside and shall render the decision. 
(Ord. No. 03-1353, § 1, 3-17-03) 
Sec. 18-16. - Revocation appeal. 
    Any person aggrieved by the decision of the village president in regard to the denial of the application or in connection with the revocation of a license shall have the right to appeal to the corporate authorities. Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the village clerk, within ten days after notice of a denial of an application or a revocation, a written statement under oath setting forth specially the grounds for appeal. The village clerk, in consultation with the board of trustees, shall thereupon set the time and place for a hearing on such appeal, and notice of such hearing shall be given to the applicant or licensee in the same manner as provided in section 18-14. The decision of the board of trustees on such appeal shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 03-1353, § 1, 3-17-03) 
Secs. 18-17-18-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - VENDING MACHINES 

Sec. 18-21. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, unless the context otherwise indicates, certain words and terms shall be defined as follows: 
    Cigarette vending machine. Any automatic vending machine used for the sale of cigarettes and matches, and controlled by the insertion of a coin or coins. It shall not include machines or devices used solely for the vending of service, food or confections. 
    Distributor. As used herein means any person or entity that provides an electronic card machine or device for any location in the village. 
    Electronic card game machine or device. Any machine or device which upon the insertion of a token or U.S. currency or payment of any fee by any member of the general public in order to use the machine for the playing of a card game or other game and commonly referred to, but not limited to, poker machines, electronic poker machines, joker-poker machines or cherry machines. 
    Juke box. Any music vending machine, contrivance or device which, upon the insertion of a coin, slug, token, plate, disc, or key into any slot, crevice, or other opening, or by the payment of any price, operates or may be operated for the emission of songs, music or similar amusement. 
    Person, firm, corporation or association. As used herein shall include the following: any person, firm, corporation or association which owns, leases, maintains or displays any mechanical or electronic amusement machine or device; the person, firm, corporation or association in whose place of business any such machine or device is placed for use by the public; and the person, firm, corporation or association having control over such machine or device; provided, however, that the payment of such fee by any person, firm, corporation or association enumerated herein shall be deemed a compliance with this section of this article. 
(Ord. No. 81-457, 1-19-81; Ord. No. 97-1117, § 1, 5-19-97) 
Sec. 18-22. - Gambling devices not permitted. 
    Nothing in this article shall in any way be construed to authorize, license or permit any gambling devices whatsoever, or any mechanism that has been judicially determined to be a gambling device, or in any way contrary to law, or that may be contrary to any future laws of the State of Illinois. 
(Ord. No. 81-457, 1-19-81) 
Cross reference- Gambling, § 22-56 et seq. 
Sec. 18-23. - License required. 
    Any distributor displaying for public patronage or keeping for operation any cigarette vending machine, jukebox, mechanical or electronic amusement machine or device for profit as herein defined by section 18-21, shall be required to obtain a license from the Village of Bourbonnais, upon payment of a license fee. Application for such license shall be made to the chief of police upon a form to be supplied by the village clerk for that purpose. Each license shall become effective as of January first of each year and expire as of the following December thirty-first. Each license shall recite the following information: 
(1)  The name of the distributor to whom the license is issued; 
(2)  The premises upon which the machines or devices are situated; 
(3)  The number of machines or devices authorized to be placed on such premises pursuant to the terms herein; and 
(4)  The total license fee paid pursuant to section 18-26 herein. 
(Ord. No. 81-457, 1-19-81; Ord. No. 83-514, § 1, 6-20-83; Ord. No. 97-1117, § 2, 5-19-97) 
Sec. 18-24. - Application. 
    The application for such license shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name, address, age, date and place of birth, social security number and business identification number of each person having a legal or equitable interest in a proprietorship or partnership applying for a license. 
(2)  The name, address, age, date and place of birth, social security number and business identification number of any person or corporation holding five percent or more of the outstanding shares of the corporation making application. 
(3)  A list of all criminal convictions of any persons, entities or corporations listed in subparagraphs (1) and (2), together with the date and place of their convictions and the disposition thereof. 
(4)  The place where each machine or device is to be displayed or operated and the business conducted at that place. 
(5)  A description of each machine or device to be covered by the license, mechanical features, names of manufacturer and serial number. 
    No license shall be issued to any applicant unless he shall be over 21 years of age and a citizen of the United States. 
(Ord. No. 81-457, 1-19-81) 
Sec. 18-25. - Inspection. 
    Application for license shall be made out in duplicate, one copy being referred to the chief of police and the other copy to the village electrical inspector. 
(1)  The chief of police shall investigate the location wherein it is proposed to operate such machine(s) or device(s), and conduct a background investigation on each person named in subparagraph (1) and (2) of the application. The board of trustees shall either approve or disapprove the application. Conviction of a crime or the commission of an act of moral turpitude by any person named in the application shall be grounds for disapproving the application. 
The Board of Trustees may consider other grounds in approving or disapproving the application other than the grounds stated aforesaid. 
(2)  The electrical inspector shall inspect all wiring, the connections to the machine(s) or device(s), to determine if the same complies with the electrical code of the Village of Bourbonnais. 
(Ord. No. 81-457, 1-19-81) 
Cross reference- Electricity, Ch. 9. 
Sec. 18-26. - License fees. 
    Every distributor before being granted a license to distribute any cigarette, juke box or electronic amusement or card machine or device shall pay the following fees on an annual basis: 
(1)  For the privilege of distributing in the village any electronic amusement, electronic card machine games or devices or cigarette vending machines the sum of $400.00 per year. 
(2)  For distributing any electronic amusement machine or device, the sum of $25.00 per machine per year. 
(3)  For distributing any cigarette vending machine the sum of $100.00 per machine per year. 
(4)  For distributing any electronic card game machine or device the sum of $100.00 per machine per year. 
(5)  All annual fees set forth hereunder and any penalty assessed by reason of a violation of this chapter shall be paid in full in advance before the license to distribute shall be granted. 
(Ord. No. 81-457, 1-19-81; ord. No. 97-1117, § 3, 5-19-97) 
Cross reference- Pinball machine operator's license fee, § 5-18. 
Sec. 18-27. - Display of license. 
(a)  The license or licenses herein provided for shall be posted permanently or conspicuously at the location of the machine(s) or device(s) in the premises wherein the machine(s) or device(s) is to be operated or maintained to be operated. 
(b)  Each machine or device shall have a village sticker as designated by the village clerk, affixed thereto in a prominent or conspicuous location. 
(Ord. No. 81-457, 1-19-81; Ord. No. 83-514, § 2, 6-20-83) 
Sec. 18-28. - Provocation of license. 
    Each license issued under this article is subject to the right, which is hereby expressly reserved, to revoke the same should the licensee directly or indirectly permit the operation of any cigarette vending machine, juke box or mechanical or electronic amusement machine or device contrary to the provisions of this article, and the ordinances of the Village of Bourbonnais, or the law of the State of Illinois. Such license may be revoked by the board of trustees after written notice of the licensee, which notice shall specify the ordinance or law violations with which the licensee is charged if after a hearing the licensee is found to be guilty of such violations. Ten days' notice of the hearing shall be given the licensee. At such hearing the licensee and his attorney may present and submit evidence and witnesses in his defense. 
(Ord. No. 81-457, 1-19-81) 
Sec. 18-29. - Seizure and destruction of machine or device. 
    If the chief of police shall have reason to believe any mechanical or electronic amusement machine or device is used as a gambling device, such machine or device may be seized by the police and impounded and if upon trial of the exhibitor be found guilty, such machine or device shall be destroyed by the police. 
(Ord. No. 81-457, 1-19-81) 
Sec. 18-30. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm, corporation or association violating any of the provisions of this article, in addition to the revocation of his or its license, shall be liable to a fine or penalty of not more than $500.00 for each offense. Each day of noncompliance or violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 81-457, 1-19-81) 
Sec. 18-31. - Injunctive relief. 
    In the event any violation of this article is of a continuing nature, the chief of police is hereby authorized to seek an injunction in the circuit court to enjoin the operation of the offending amusement establishment as a nuisance and the operation of the mechanical or electronic amusement device(s), cigarette machine(s) or juke box(es) located therein. The chief of police shall bring such action in the name of the Village of Bourbonnais. 
(Ord. No. 81-457, 1-19-81) 
Sec. 18-32. - Limitation on number of electronic amusement and card game machines. 
    There shall be allowed no more than one licensed electronic card game machine or device for every 1,000 net square feet of building space, premises or business and no more than five such machines per building or premises or business in total. Provided, however, that any building premises or business containing more than five such machines or more than one machine per 1,000 square feet, as of the effective date of Ordinance No. 97-1117, shall not be subject to the conditions of this section until the business containing such machines shall be sold or leased to a third party, whereupon the building, premises or business containing such machines shall contain no more than five machines regardless of square footage. 
(Ord. No. 97-1117, § 2, 5-19-97) 
Secs. 18-33-18-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE COMPANIES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 11. 

Sec. 18-41. - Compliance with provisions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any corporation or association not incorporated under the laws of the state to engage in effecting fire insurance in the village without fully complying with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 10-33) 
Sec. 18-42. - Fees required. 
(a)  Any foreign fire insurance corporation or association shall pay to the treasurer of the village for the maintenance, use and benefit of the fire department, a sum of money equal to two percent of the gross receipts each year received from premiums by any and all agents of any such corporation or association or received as premiums in any way for fire insurance policies on any property in the village. 
(b)  All payments under the provisions of this article shall be made on or before July 15 following the termination of the year for which such payments are made. Such payments shall be made for the year ending July 1 each year. 
(Code 1973, §§ 10-34, 10-36) 
Sec. 18-43. - Reports required. 
    Every person acting as representative for or on behalf of any foreign insurance company or association shall, on or before July 15 of each year, render to the village treasurer a full, true and just account, verified by oath, of all premiums which have been received by him on behalf of the company or association during the year ending the preceding July 1 on fire insurance policies. 
(Code 1973, § 10-35) 
Secs. 18-44-18-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - LIVE ENTERTAINMENT 

Sec. 18-50. - Definitions. 
    Live entertainment/dancing. This use includes any establishment that is utilized for live performers or patrons engaged in singing, performing, dancing or playing musical instruments. "Live entertainment/dancing" shall not include "theaters," "indoor or outdoor amusement center" or "indoor or outdoor recreation" facilities where live performances may occasionally be held, as defined herein. 
    Indoor amusement.
