(c)  Term. The members of the commission shall serve for terms of four years, except as hereinafter provided. The members initially appointed to the commission shall, by lottery, draw staggered terms ranging from one to four years. 
(Ord. No. 86-598, §§ 2-4, 12-15-86) 
Sec. 25-38. - Ex-officio member. 
    The president of the village shall appoint one member of the board of trustees who shall serve as an ex-officio member of the commission and shall report to the president and board of trustees on a monthly basis regarding the activities of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 86-598, § 7, 12-15-86) 
Sec. 25-39. - Clerk. 
    The commission may identify one officer or employee of the village to serve as clerk of the commission in order to superintend the affairs of the commission and to ensure the orderly process of business before the commission. 
(Ord. No. 86-598, § 8, 12-15-86) 
Sec. 25-40. - Duties. 
    The commission shall undertake the following duties: 
(1)  To prepare a comprehensive economic development plan for submission to the president and board of trustees of the Village of Bourbonnais. 
(2)  To coordinate a marketing program for and on behalf of the Village of Bourbonnais in order to retain existing industrial, commercial and service enterprises and to encourage the location of such enterprises within the corporate boundaries. 
(3)  To review all applications for industrial development bonds and to forward specific findings on each application to the president and board of trustees for action. 
(4)  To set forth specific development incentives that can be applied to particular development projects and to recommend the application of such incentives on selected projects to the president and board of trustees. 
(5)  To work in concert with the plan commission, the zoning board of appeals, and other public bodies in the furtherance of the objectives of the local economic development plan. 
(6)  To cooperate with all public and private agencies in the County of Kankakee and State of Illinois engaged in economic development activities. 
(7)  To identify public and private funding sources to support economic development activities, and with the consent of the president and board of trustees to make application for funding from such sources. 
(8)  To conduct commercial, industrial and service enterprise retention activities. 
(9)  To encourage existing commercial, industrial and service facilities within the Village of Bourbonnais through the conduct of recognition programs. 
(10)  To undertake such other activities as are deemed appropriate, necessary and within the scope of the commission's authority. 
(Ord. No. 86-598, § 5, 12-15-86) 
Sec. 25-41. - Actions not binding. 
    All actions of the commission shall be advisory in nature and shall not bind the Village of Bourbonnais. 
(Ord. No. 86-598, § 6, 12-15-86) 
Sec. 25-42. - Funding. 
    The commission shall be afforded such funding under the budget of the Village of Bourbonnais as may be necessary and appropriate to carry forward its assigned duties and tasks. 
(Ord. No. 86-598, § 9, 12-15-86) 
Chapter 26 - PLUMBING[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Building regulations, Ch. 7; electricity, Ch. 9; sewer use, § 35-16 et seq. 

Sec. 26-1. - Plumbing codes adopted. 
    The village hereby adopts the State of Illinois Plumbing Code (current edition) and BOCA Plumbing Code (current edition), as the plumbing codes for the village. 
Sec. 26-2. - Inspection of work. 
    In all buildings hereafter erected, both public and private, and in all buildings already built or erected in which any plumbing is installed or in which any sewer-connected pipe is repaired or changed, except for minor repairs, on the sewer side of the trap, the drain, the soil, rainwater and other pipe or pipes connected directly or indirectly to any drain, soil or waste pipe, and all traps, shall be exposed to view for inspection and test by the code enforcement officer, and shall not be covered until such test is made. 
(Code 1973, § 20-2) 
Sec. 26-3. - Specifications for certain plumbing materials. 
    Sump pumps. Sump pumps are required in specific areas of the village. Structures requiring sump pumps will be so designated at the time of application for building permit by building and zoning administrators. Sump pumps must be installed in pits of concrete, tile, fiberglass or other approved materials, for sump pumps which receive rain water, surface water or footing drains. Sewerage sump basins must be separate and must be sealed to prevent entry of storm and surface water. Downspouts and roof drains must discharge outside of building unless separate storm drains are brought into the building to receive them. 
(Code 1973, § 20-3; Ord. No. 75-268, 1-20-75) 
Sec. 26-4. - Additional requirements. 
(a)  Sewer and water service shall be separated not less than ten feet horizontally. 
(b)  Sewer service at the points of connection must remain exposed for inspection. 
(c)  Connection to stub shall be to a hub, or a nonshear coupling may be used. 
(d)  Crown of sewer pipe shall remain exposed to verify proper grade on pipe. 
(e)  Sewer shall be bedded in gravel with no void under pipe. 
(f)  Excavated drives and walk areas shall be filled to grade with gravel after sewer and water approval. 
(g)  Sewer and water shall be capped to prevent surface water or debris from entering system. 
(h)  A licensed plumber, working for, or as, a plumbing contractor registered with the State of Illinois Department of Public Health, shall install water service, as indicated on sewer and water contractor form. 
(i)  Installation will not be approved if unqualified personnel are found connecting water service or if requested information as indicated herein has not been provided. 
(j)  At the time of permit application the following information shall be provided: 
(1)  Address of property; 
(2)  Name of plumbing contractor; 
(3)  state contractor registration number; 
(4)  Date of application; 
(5)  License number of plumber; 
(6)  Signature of plumber. 
(k)  Water service shall be installed four inches below grade. 
(l)  K-type copper to be used on all services two inches and under. All water supply and distribution lines for residential and light commercial use shall be of type "L" copper for above ground and type "K" copper for underground. 
(m)  All joints to remain exposed for inspection. 
(n)  Properly patch and waterproof foundation walls. 
(o)  Water service shall be bedded in sand or equal soft aggregate at least six inches above and below pipe. 
(Ord. No. 05-1511, 5-16-05; Ord. No. 08-1753, § 2, 1-23-08) 
Sec. 26-5. - Penalty for violations. 
    Whenever in this chapter any act is prohibited or made or declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor, or whenever in such chapter the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision of this chapter shall be punished by a fine of not more than $500.00. Each day any violation of any provision of this chapter shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 80-452, 10-27-80; Ord. No. 05-1511, 5-16-05) 
Chapter 27 - POLICE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Powers of arrest, § 2-57; board of fire and police commissioners, § 2-201 et seq.; alarms, Ch. 3; animals and fowl, Ch. 6; civil defense and emergencies, Ch. 8; motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 19; nuisances, Ch. 20; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, Ch. 22. 
State Law reference- Power of village to prescribe the duties of police officers, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 11-1-2; Police Training Act, Ch. 85, § 501 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 27-1. - Department created, composition. 
(a)  There is hereby created a police department, an executive department of the village. The police department shall consist of the office of the chief of police, deputy chief of police, sergeant, patrol officer, and such additional members as may be determined, from time to time, by the village president and the village trustees. 
(b)  One deputy chief of police and seven sergeant positions be and hereby are created. 
(c)  There shall be in the village police department the position of deputy chief who shall be appointed by the chief of the police department. The deputy chief position shall be an exempt rank immediately below that of chief. The deputy chief may be appointed from any rank of sworn, full-time officers of the village police department, but must have at least five years of full-time service as a police officer in the department. The deputy chief shall serve at the discretion of the chief and, if removed from the position, shall revert to the rank held immediately prior to appointment to the deputy chief position. A deputy chief of police having been appointed from any rank of sworn officers of the village police department, shall be permitted, regardless of rank, to take promotional exams and be promoted to a higher classified rank than he or she currently holds, without having to resign as deputy chief of police. 
(d)  The board of fire and police commissioners shall appoint all police officers of the police department, except the chief of police, deputy chief of police and civilian staff. Any and all promotion of such officers of the department shall require validated testing and certification and be in accordance with the provisions of 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-15. In accordance with those provisions, the village president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, shall appoint and remove the chief of police. No person shall be entitled to appointment or promotion as a matter of right under this section. 
(e)  A condition precedent to appointment to promotion to the rank of lieutenant shall be that the appointee holds the rank of sergeant in the Bourbonnais Police Department at the time of his or her appointment. 
(f)  The chief of police and all police officers shall, before entering upon their duties, take and subscribe to the oath provided by law. If a newly hired officer has received training paid for by the village, his or her oath shall not become effective until after the officer has signed an agreement with the village regarding reimbursement of said training expenses on a form provided by the village. 
(g)  Uniforms. 
1.  Each police officer shall wear an appropriate uniform or a badge of office. 
2.  The chief of police shall appoint and regulate the style and quality of the uniforms to be worn by all members of the police department in accordance with subsection (a) of this section. All uniforms shall be alike in style and cut, material used, color, and in accordance with the samples furnished and approved by the chief of police. 
3.  All members of the police department, while on duty, shall keep themselves neatly dressed and clean. 
(h)  Powers and duties of members. Each member of the police department shall have the powers conferred upon police officers and conservators of the peace by law, and such other powers and duties as may from time to time be lawfully provided by United States or state law, or by the provisions of this Code or by village ordinance. Each police officer shall be a conservator of the peace and aid in the preservation of the public peace and the observance and enforcement of the provisions of this Code or other ordinances of the village and the laws of the state. 
(i)  Resignation . To resign in good standing, a police officer shall submit his resignation in writing one calendar month in advance of the effective date of his resignation. 
(j)  Return of equipment . Upon the termination of the office or employment by a member of the police department, any badge, weapon or other property belonging to the village shall be returned to the chief of police in as good condition as received. 
(Code 1973, § 21-1; Ord. No. 01-1243, §§ 1-5, 3-5-01; Ord. No. 10-1866, § 2, 11-1-10; Ord. No. 10-1870, § 2, 12-6-10; Ord. No. 13-1937, § 2, 7-15-13; Ord. No. 16-2039, § 2, 12-5-16; Ord. No. 16-2041, § 2, 12-19-16; Ord. No. 17-2052 , § 2, 3-20-17) 
Sec. 27-2. - Residency requirement. 
    Any person employed by the village as a member of the police department shall reside and make his or her principal residence either within the corporate limits of the Village of Bourbonnais, Illinois, or within an unincorporated area that is not more than five miles from the corporate limits of the village, excluding property south of the Kankakee River, not later than 30 days subsequent to his or her appointment to the police department of the Village of Bourbonnais or not later than 30 days subsequent to his or her successful completion of the required training course. 
    If any person employed by the village as a member of the police department is residing or later resides in an unincorporated area and, after purchasing a residence, that area would be incorporated, said employee shall not be required to move from the incorporated area. 
(Ord. No. 76-294, 11-1-76; Ord. No. 88-694, § 1, 1-17-89) 
Sec. 27-3. - Special policemen. 
    The president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, may appoint any reputable person as a special policeman to serve for such term and on such conditions as may be designated by the terms of such appointment. Special policemen shall have the powers and duties of a conservator of the peace, and shall receive no compensation from the village, unless such compensation is ordered by the board of trustees. Appointments may be revoked at any time by the president, the board of trustees, or the chief of police. 
(Code 1973, § 21-8) 
Sec. 27-4. - Powers and duties of police. 
    It shall be the duty of the members of the police department to see to the enforcement of all ordinances of the village, of all statutes effective in the village, and to preserve order and prevent infractions of the law and to arrest violators thereof. Every member of the police department is hereby declared to be a conservator of the peace. 
(Code 1973, § 21-3) 
Sec. 27-5. - Powers and duties of police chief. 
(a)  General responsibility and authority. The chief of police shall transport all persons arrested to the county jail to be incarcerated therein. He shall keep such records and make such reports concerning the activities of his department as may be required by statute or ordinance. The chief shall be responsible for the performance by the police department of all its functions and all persons who are members of the department shall serve subject to the orders of the chief of police. 
(b)  Custody of property. The chief of police shall be custodian of all lost, abandoned or stolen property in the village. 
(c)  Serving process. The chief of police shall be authorized to serve writs, summons, and other processes, but no patrolman shall serve any such summons or process except on the order of the chief of police or of the president. 
(Code 1973, §§ 21-4-21-6) 
Cross reference- Authority to abate nuisances, § 20-1. 
Sec. 27-6. - Resisting or obstructing police. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly resist or obstruct the performance of one known to the person to be a peace officer of any authorized act within his official capacity. 
(b)  No person shall obstruct or impede the enforcement of this Code. 
(Code 1973, § 17-28) 
Sec. 27-7. - Refusing to aid an officer. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, upon command, to refuse or knowingly fail to reasonably aid a person known by him to be a peace officer in: 
(1)  Apprehending a person whom the officer is authorized to apprehend; or 
(2)  Preventing the commission of another of any offense. 
(Code 1973, § 17-29) 
Sec. 27-8. - Aiding escape. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, with intent to aid any prisoner escaping from any penal institution, to convey into the institution or transfer to the prisoner anything for use in escaping. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly aid a person convicted of a crime or charged with the commission of a crime in escaping from any penal institution or from the custody of any employee of that institution. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly aid a person in escaping from any public institution, other than a penal institution, in which he is lawfully detained, or from the custody of an employee of that institution. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly aid a person in the lawful custody of a peace officer in escaping from custody. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any officer or employee of any penal institution to recklessly permit any prisoner in his custody to escape. 
(Code 1973, § 17-30) 
Sec. 27-9. - Impersonating police officer. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to falsely represent any member of a police agency, or to represent himself as a member of a police agency, or to maliciously, or with intent to deceive, use or imitate any sign, signal or device used by the agency, or, not being a police officer, to wear in public the police uniform. 
Sec. 27-10. - Compensation of police. 
    The compensation of police shall be determined by ordinance adopted by the president and the board of trustees. 
Sec. 27-11. - Appearance as witness, fees. 
    Every member of the police department shall appear as a witness whenever it is necessary in a prosecution for a violation of a village ordinance or a state or federal law, but no such member shall receive any witness fee for such service in any action or suit to which the village is a party. All fees due for such services shall, if paid, be turned over to the village treasurer. 
(Code 1973, § 21-7) 
Sec. 27-12. - Collective bargaining agreement adopted. 
    The collective bargaining agreement between the Village of Bourbonnais, the Fraternal Order of Police Lodge No. 64 and the Illinois Fraternal Order of Police Labor Council, a copy of which is attached to Ord. No. 88-686 and made a part of this section, is hereby approved and adopted. 
(Ord. No. 88-686, § 1, 12-5-88) 
Editor's note- Inclusion of § 1 of nonamendatory Ord. No. 88-686, adopted Dec. 5, 1988, as § 27-12 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 27-13-27-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - AUXILIARY POLICE FORCE 

Sec. 27-21. - Appointments. 
    The village president is hereby authorized to appoint up to 25 auxiliary policemen as employees, subject to the advice and consent of the village board. Prior to appointment, all proposed auxiliary policemen shall be fingerprinted and their fingerprints shall be checked with the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Washington, D.C., for any possible criminal record. No person shall be appointed as an auxiliary policeman if he has been convicted of a felony or any crime involving moral turpitude. The appointment of any or all auxiliary policemen may be determined by the village president subject to the advice and consent of the village board. 
Sec. 27-22. - Qualifications, restrictions and direction. 
    Such auxiliary policemen shall not be members of the regular police department of the village. Auxiliary policemen shall be either residents of the village or residents of Bourbonnais Township, Kankakee County, Illinois. Identification symbols worn by such auxiliary policemen shall be different and distinct from those used by the regular police department and shall be elected and chosen by the chief of police. Auxiliary policemen shall at all times during the performance of their duties be subject to the direction and control of the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 89-731, § 1, 10-16-89) 
Sec. 27-23. - Training required. 
    Auxiliary policemen, prior to entering upon any of their duties, shall receive a course of training in the use of weapons and other police procedures by the chief of police. Such course of training shall include not less than 40 hours of firearms training and not less than 40 hours of classroom instruction. The course must include a presentation of the ethical, moral and legal consideration to be taken into account by any person who uses a firearm. Upon completion of the course of training, the chief of police shall file a certificate attesting to the auxiliary policemen's completion of such course, with the village clerk. 
(Ord. No. 89-731, § 2, 10-16-89) 
Sec. 27-24. - Compensation for court appearance. 
    Auxiliary policemen shall be paid at the rate of $15.00 for each court appearance they attend in the performance of their duties, provided such performance is at the direction of the chief of police. 
Sec. 27-25. - Power and duties. 
    Auxiliary policemen shall have the following powers and duties when properly assigned and on duty: 
(1)  To aid or direct traffic in the municipality. 
(2)  To aid in control of natural or manmade disasters. 
(3)  To aid in case of civil disorder. 
(4)  To perform normal and regular police duties when assigned by the chief of police on occasions when it is impractical for members of the regular police department to perform normal and regular police duties. 
(5)  To arrest or cause to be arrested, without process, all persons who break the peace or are found violating any Village Code provision or any criminal law of the state. 
(6)  To commit arrested persons for examination. 
(7)  If necessary, to detain arrested persons in custody overnight or Sunday in any safe place, or until they can be brought before the proper officer. 
(8)  To serve and execute all warrants for the violation of Village Code provisions, or the state criminal law, within the limits of the village. 
(9)  Without limiting the generality of the proceeding powers and duties, Auxiliary police officers shall not under any circumstances be considered as members of the regular Police Department. 
(10)  Without limiting the generality of the proceeding powers and duties, auxiliary police officers shall not under any circumstances be conservators of the peace. 
(Ord. No. 06-1683, § 2, 12-18-06) 
State Law reference- Powers of conservators of the peace, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 3-9-4. 
Sec. 27-26. - Use of firearms. 
    Auxiliary policemen shall not carry firearms except with the permission of the chief of police, and only then in conformance with Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 28, § 24.2(1), and having completed the requirements of entitled training course for peace officers, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 85, § 516, and then only when in uniform and in the performance of their duties. 
(Ord. No. 78-358, 10-16-78) 
Secs. 27-27-27-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - POLICE PENSION BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Police pensions generally, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 1081/2, § 3-101 et seq. 

Sec. 27-36. - Created; composition, term. 
    There shall be a police pension board consisting of five members. Of these members, two shall be appointed by the president, with the consent of the board of trustees, to serve a term of two years each; two shall be elected from the regular police force of the village; and one shall be elected from the beneficiaries of the pension. Each member shall serve for two years and elected members shall be selected in the manner provided by law. 
(Code 1973, § 21-19) 
Sec. 27-37. - Duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the members of the police pension board to manage, invest and control the police pension fund and all monies pertaining thereto in the manner provided by statute and to pay beneficiaries as provided by law. 
(Code 1973, § 21-20) 
State Law reference- Powers and duties of police pension board, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 1081/2, § 3-131 et seq. 
Sec. 27-38. - Deposits in fund. 
    There shall be deposited in the police pension fund the amounts provided for by statute. 
(Code 1973, § 21-21) 
State Law reference- Financing of fund, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 1081/2, § 3-125. 
Chapter 29 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Board of local improvements, §§ 2-216 et seq.; use of streets for storage of building materials, § 7-25; obstructing, removing sidewalks during building operations, § 7-26; moving buildings, § 7-121 et seq.; vehicles obstructing streets, § 19-44; pedestrians, § 19-131 et seq.; nuisances on streets and public places, § 20-7; peddlers and solicitors, Ch. 24; signs, Ch. 28; trees, shrubs and weeds, Ch. 33; water and sewers, Ch. 35. 
State Law reference- Streets and public ways, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, art.11, div. 80 et seq.; municipal street system, Ch. 121, § 2-104; municipal administration of streets, Ch. 121, art.7. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 29-1. - Supervision. 
    All public streets, alleys, sidewalks and other public ways shall be under the supervision of the public works superintendent. He shall have supervision over all work thereon, and the cleaning thereof, and shall be charged with the enforcement of all ordinance provisions relating to such public places (except traffic ordinances) and is hereby authorized to enforce such ordinances. 
(Code 1973, § 23-1; Ord. No. 00-1219, § 9, 7-17-00) 
Sec. 29-2. - Damage to pavements. 
    It shall be unlawful to walk upon or drive any vehicle or animal upon, or damage any newly laid street or alley pavement while the same is guarded by a warning sign or barricade; or to knowingly damage any street, sidewalk or alley pavement. 
(Code 1973, § 23-2) 
Sec. 29-3. - Report of defects. 
    It shall be the duty of every village officer or employee becoming cognizant of any defect in any street, alley or sidewalk, or any obstruction thereof, to report the same to the maintenance supervisor as soon as possible. 
(Code 1973, § 23-3) 
Sec. 29-4. - Repairs. 
    All public streets, alley and sidewalk pavements shall be in good repair. Such repair work, whether done by the village or the abutting owner, shall be under the supervision of the maintenance supervisor who shall be notified prior to the commencement of any repairs. 
(Code of 1973, § 23-4) 
Sec. 29-5. - Private use prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place as space for the display of goods or merchandise for sale, or to write or mark any signs or advertisements on any such pavement. 
(Code 1973, § 23-4) 
Sec. 29-6. - Obstructions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, create or maintain any obstruction of any street, alley, sidewalk or other public way, except as may be specifically authorized by ordinance or resolution. 
(Code 1973, § 23-6) 
Sec. 29-6.1. - Construction of mail boxes and basketball hoops. 
(a)  Mail boxes. No mail box or mail box support located in the public street right-of-way shall be constructed consisting all or in part of brick, stone, concrete, masonry or other non-break away material. 
(b)  Basketball hoops. No basketball hoops and supporting structures shall be erected in the public street right-of-way. 
(c)  Notice of violation; penalty. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to violate any provision of this section. The code enforcement officer shall serve a notice of violation or order on the person responsible for the erection, construction, alteration, extension, repair or use of a structure in violation of the provisions of this section. Such order shall direct the discontinuance of the illegal action or condition and the abatement of the violation. 
(2)  If the notice of violation is not complied with promptly, the code enforcement officer shall request the legal counsel of the jurisdiction to institute the appropriate proceeding at law or in equity to restrain, correct, or abate such violation or to require the removal or termination of the unlawful use of the building or structure in violation of the provisions of this section or of the order or direction in violation of the provisions of this section or of the order or direction made pursuant thereto. 
(3)  Any person who shall violate a provision of this section shall fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof or who shall erect, construct, alter or repair a structure in violation of an approved plan or directive of the code enforcement officer, or of a permit or certificate issued under the provisions of this section, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not more than $500.00. Each day that a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(4)  The imposition of the penalties herein prescribed shall not preclude the legal officer of the jurisdiction from instituting appropriate action to prevent unlawful construction or to restrain, correct or abate a violation, structure or to stop an illegal act, conduct, business or use of a structure on or about any premises. 
(Ord. No. 92-885, §§ 1-3, 5-4-92) 
Sec. 29-7. - Encroachments. 
    It shall be unlawful to erect or maintain any building or structure which encroaches upon any public street or property. 
(Code 1973, § 23-7) 
Sec. 29-8. - Permission required for poles and wires. 
    It shall be unlawful to erect any poles or wires or maintain any poles or wires over any public place, street, alley or other public way without first having secured permission from the board of trustees. 
(Code 1973, § 23-8) 
Sec. 29-9. - Barricades and safety precautions required. 
    Any person laying or repairing any pavement on a street, sidewalk or other public place or making an excavation in the same shall maintain suitable barricades to prevent injury of any person or vehicle by reason of the work. The installation and maintenance of all barricades and signs shall be in accordance with all applicable sections or articles of the Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction in Illinois, adopted by the Illinois Department of Transportation, and in accordance with all applicable standards as provided in the Standards Manual by the Illinois Department of Transportation, and also as provided for in the Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices. Such barricades shall be protected by suitable lights at nighttime. 
    Any defect in any such pavement shall be barricaded to prevent injury; and any person properly maintaining any opening or excavation in any such place shall guard such opening or excavation while the same remains open by proper barricades and lights. 
(Code 1973, § 23-9) 
Cross reference- Paving by private persons, § 29-46 et seq.; excavations generally § 29-61 et seq. 
Sec. 29-10. - Disturbing barricades, safety precautions. 
    It shall be unlawful to disturb or interfere with any barricade or light lawfully placed to protect or mark any new pavement or excavation or opening in any public street, alley or sidewalk. 
(Code 1973, § 23-10) 
Sec. 29-11. - Openings. 
    It shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any opening or stairway in any public street, alley, sidewalk or other public place without a permit from the board of trustees. 
    All such lawfully maintained openings shall be guarded by a suitable strong cover or railing built to the approval of the maintenance supervisor. 
(Code 1973, § 23-11) 
State Law reference- Openings in streets, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 11-80-7. 
Sec. 29-12. - Deposits on streets. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to deposit on any street any material which may be harmful to the pavement thereof, or any waste material, leaves, grass, or rubbish, or any glass, or articles which may cause injury to any person, animal or property. 
(b)  Coal or other materials may be deposited on streets preparatory to delivery for use, provided that such deposit does not reduce the usable width of the street or roadway at that point to less than 18 feet, and provided that such material or coal, other than material used in actual building construction, shall not be permitted to remain in such street for more than three hours. 
(c)  Any such material or coal shall be guarded by lights if the same remains upon any street after nighttime. 
(Code 1973, § 23-12) 
Sec. 29-13. - Deposits on sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful to deposit on any public sidewalk any material which may be harmful to the pavement thereof, or any waste material, or any glass or other articles which might cause injury to persons, animals or property. 
    Merchandise or other articles may be deposited on sidewalks preparatory to delivery, provided that the usable width of the sidewalk is not thereby reduced to less than four feet; and provided that no such article shall remain on such walk for more than one-half hour. 
(Code 1973, § 23-13) 
Cross reference- Obstructing sidewalks during building operations, § 7-26. 
Sec. 29-14. - Using sidewalk for steps, open area. 
    The use of any part of the sidewalk for steps is prohibited. 
(Code 1973, § 23-14) 
Sec. 29-15. - Scaffolds, ladders. 
    Any scaffold or ladder placed in such a way that they overhang or can fall onto any public street, alley or other public place in the village shall be firmly constructed and safeguarded; and it shall be unlawful to place or leave any tools or articles on any such place in such a manner that the same can fall onto any such street, sidewalk, alley or other public place from a height greater than four feet. 
(Code 1973, § 23-15) 
Sec. 29-16. - Articles on windows. 
    It shall be unlawful to place any movable articles on any window ledge abutting on a public street, alley or other public place at a height above four feet from the ground in such a manner that the same can be or is in danger of falling onto any street, sidewalk, alley or other public place. 
(Code 1973, § 23-16) 
Sec. 29-17. - Street name signs. 
    The names of all streets shall be placed on street corners. It shall be unlawful for any person to damage or obstruct any such sign. 
(Code 1973, § 23-17) 
Sec. 29-18. - Penalty for violations. 
    Whenever in this chapter any act is prohibited or made or declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor, or whenever in such chapter the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision of this chapter shall be punished by a fine of not more than $500.00. Each day any violation of any provision of this chapter shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
Secs. 29-19-29-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PUBLIC DEMONSTRATIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Public demonstrations, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 38, § 85-1 et seq.; mass gatherings, Ch. 1111/2, § 901 et seq. 

Sec. 29-31. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known as the "Bourbonnais Public Demonstration Ordinance." 
(Code 1973, § 17-46) 
Sec. 29-32. - Declaration of purpose. 
    It is declared to be the public policy of this village: 
(1)  That the maintenance of good order on roadways, as defined in this Code, is a paramount responsibility of democratic government; and 
(2)  That the public health, welfare and safety of the community require that the movement of vehicular traffic on such roadways be unlawfully conducted with a minimum of disruption; and 
(3)  That the practice of unhindered or unrestrained picketing or demonstrating on such roadways has caused disruption of police, fire and emergency services, and injury to persons regardless of participation in the march, assembly or demonstration; and 
(4)  That the practice of multiple demonstrations on the same day in different locations has unreasonably deprived the citizens of police, fire and emergency services; and 
(5)  That the provisions herein enacted are necessary for the protection of the health, welfare and safety of the public. 
(Code 1973, § 17-47) 
Sec. 29-33. - Permission required. 
    It is unlawful for any person, group or organization to conduct or participate in any march, assembly, meeting or gathering on roadways in more than one specific area of or location in the village, on any given day, unless it is acting with permission of the chief of police. 
(Code 1973, § 17-48) 
Sec. 29-34. - Advance notice required. 
    It is unlawful for any group or organization to conduct or participate in any march, assembly, meeting or gathering on roadways unless the chief of police has been given notice in writing of the location, the maximum number of persons participating, and the names and addresses of the organizers of any such march, assembly, meeting or gathering, its route, and its time of inception and duration at least 24 hours before such inception. 
(Code 1973, § 17-50) 
Sec. 29-35. - Number of participants limited. 
    It is unlawful for any group or organization or any individual acting with such group or organization to conduct or participate in any march, assembly, meeting or gathering on roadways unless such march, assembly, meeting or gathering is limited to such numbers as, in the opinion of the chief of police, will not obstruct pedestrian or vehicular traffic in an unreasonable manner. The chief of police shall, within 12 hours of receiving the notice required by section 29-34, inform the group or organization as to the limitation on number of persons allowed to participate. 
(Code 1973, § 17-49) 
Sec. 29-36. - Hours of restriction. 
    It is unlawful for any group, organization, or any individual to conduct or participate in any march, assembly, meeting or gathering on roadways during peak traffic periods unless authorized by the chief of police. Peak traffic periods are for the purposes of this article declared to be 7:30 a.m. to 9:00 a.m. in the forenoon, and from 4:30 p.m. to 6:00 p.m. in the afternoon, Monday through Friday, except for state and national holidays. 
(Code 1973, § 17-51) 
Secs. 29-37-29-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PAVING BY PRIVATE PERSONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Barricades and safety precautions required, § 29-9. 

Sec. 29-46. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful to construct or lay any pavement on any public street, sidewalk, alley or other public way, or to replace the same, without having first secured a permit therefor. 
(Code 1973, § 23-28) 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations, Ch. 18. 
Sec. 29-47. - Sidewalk permit prohibited if it will narrow street. 
    No permit shall be issued for the installation, construction or replacement of any sidewalk, if the construction, installation or replacement of such sidewalk shall reduce the width of any improved street from the face of the curb on one side to the face of the curb on the other side the greater of either 33 feet or the width of the right-of-way of such street. 
(Code 1973, § 23-29) 
Sec. 29-48. - Sidewalk width. 
    No permit shall be issued to construct a sidewalk less than four feet in width except for the area bordering Brown Boulevard and its arteries. Along Brown Boulevard and its arteries, all sidewalks shall not be less than eight feet in width. The term "arteries" is meant to include all streets or accessways off of Brown Boulevard for which sidewalks are required. 
(Code 1973, § 23-30; Ord. No. 94-1017, § 2, 8-1-94) 
Sec. 29-49. - To whom application made; referral. 
    Applications for permits required by this article shall be made to the code enforcement officer, who shall in turn bring them to the attention of the board of trustees. 
(Code 1973, § 23-31) 
Sec. 29-50. - Contents of application. 
    The application for a permit required by this article shall state the location of the intended pavement or repair, the extent thereof, and the person who is to do the actual construction work. 
(Code 1973, § 23-32) 
Sec. 29-51. - Trustees to approve permit. 
    No permit required by this article shall be issued except on order or resolution of the board of trustees. 
(Code 1973, § 23-33) 
Sec. 29-52. - Bond required. 
    Each applicant for a permit required by this article shall file a bond in the amount of $5,000.00 with sureties to be approved by the board of trustees, conditioned to indemnify the village for any loss or damage resulting from the work undertaken or the manner of doing the same, or for failure to complete the same. 
Cross reference- Requirements for surety bonds generally, § 2-67. 
Secs. 29-53-29-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - EXCAVATIONS AND TUNNELING[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Barricades and safety precautions required, § 29-9. 
State Law reference- Opening in streets, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 11-80-7. 

Sec. 29-61. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful to make any excavation in or tunnel under any public street, alley, sidewalk or other public place in the village, without having first secured a permit therefor. 
(Code 1973, § 23-45) 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations, Ch. 18. 
Sec. 29-62. - To whom application made; contents. 
    Applications for permits required by this article shall be made to the code enforcement officer and shall specify the intended location and the purpose of the excavation. 
(Code 1973, § 23-46) 
Sec. 29-63. - Bond or insurance required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make any excavation or tunnel without first having secured and furnished the village with a copy or certificate of a bond or policy conditioned to indemnify and hold the village harmless from any loss, damage or liability resulting from the work done or any acts or omissions in connection therewith. 
(Code 1973, § 23-47) 
Cross reference- General requirements for surety bonds, § 2-67. 
Sec. 29-64. - Supervision. 
    All excavations, refills and resurfacing shall be made subject to the supervision and under the direction of the maintenance supervisor. 
(Code 1973, § 23-48) 
Sec. 29-65. - Refilling, resurfacing. 
    Any person making any excavation shall refill the same properly and shall restore the surface to its condition before the excavation was made, as soon as possible pursuant to the written specifications of the village engineer. Said specifications shall remain on file with the village clerk for public inspection during normal business hours. 
(Code 1973, § 23-49) 
Secs. 29-66-29-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - DRIVEWAYS 

Sec. 29-76. - Permit required to construct. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to construct a driveway for vehicles or animals across any sidewalk in the village without first having obtained a permit therefor. 
(Code 1973, § 23-60) 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations, Ch. 18. 
Sec. 29-77. - Application for construction permit. 
    Applications for driveway construction permits shall be made to the code enforcement officer and shall be accompanied by the fee required. 
(Code 1973, § 23-61) 
Sec. 29-78. - Approval of construction permit by trustees. 
    No permit for construction of a driveway for commercial use, or for the habitual use of other than the owner or occupant of the premises served, shall be issued except upon the order of the board of trustees. 
(Code 1973, § 23-62) 
Sec. 29-79. - Permit fee. 
    The fee for all driveway construction permits shall be set by written resolution. 
(Code 1973, § 23-63) 
Sec. 29-80. - Grade, surfaces. 
    No driveway shall be so constructed or graded as to leave a step, sharp depression or other obstruction in the sidewalk. The grade shall be as nearly as possible the same as that of the adjoining sidewalk. It shall be unlawful to have the surface finish of any driveway where the same crosses the sidewalk constructed of such materials as to render it slippery and hazardous to pedestrians, or to have the grade of such portion vary from the grade of the sidewalk, or be other than level. 
(Code 1973, § 23-64) 
Sec. 29-81. - Construction specifications. 
    Driveways across sidewalks shall be constructed in compliance with specifications adopted by the board of trustees. 
(Code 1973, § 23-65) 
Sec. 29-82. - Maintenance. 
    It shall be the duty of the person maintaining the driveway to keep the same in good repair where it crosses the sidewalk, and free from obstructions and openings. 
(Code 1973, § 23-66) 
Sec. 29-83. - Permission required to enlarge. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to enlarge or widen any existing driveway abutting and adjacent to a sidewalk unless permission to do so has been secured from the code enforcement officer and the board of trustees in writing. 
(Code 1973, § 23-67) 
Secs. 29-84-29-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - HOUSE NUMBERING 

Sec. 29-91. - Required. 
    All lots, buildings and structures in the village shall be numbered by the code enforcement officer in accordance with the system prescribed by the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1973, § 23-78) 
Sec. 29-92. - Chart required. 
    The code enforcement officer shall keep a chart showing the proper street number of every lot in the village which shall be open to the public for inspection by anyone interested. 
(Code 1973, § 23-79) 
Sec. 29-93. - Duty to display number. 
    It is hereby made the duty of the owner, agent or person in possession of any building in the village to number it in the prescribed manner. 
(Code 1973, § 23-80) 
Chapter 30 - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 06-1574, § 1, adopted June 12, 2006, amended Ch. 30 and enacted similar provisions as set out herein. The former Ch. 30 derived from Ord. No. 95-1043, §§ I-XII, adopted March 6, 1995; Ord. No. 98-1139, § 2, adopted Feb. 17, 1998; Ord. No. 99-1185, § 1, adopted May 3, 1999; Ord. No. 99-1198, § 1, adopted Aug. 16, 1999; Ord No. 01-1280, § 1, adopted Dec. 17, 2001; Ord. No. 02-1316, § 3, adopted June 3, 2002; Ord. No. 03-1362, § 3, adopted May 19, 2003; Ord. No. 04-1402, §§ 1, 2, adopted Jan. 20, 2004; Ord. No. 04-1441, §§ 2, 3, adopted Sept. 20, 2004; Ord. No. 04-1442, §§ 2-5, adopted Sept. 20, 2004; Ord. No. 05-1492, § 1, adopted Feb. 22, 2005; and Ord. No. 05-1526, §§ 6, 7, 13, adopted Oct. 3, 2005. 
Cross reference- Board of local improvements, § 2-216 et seq.; building regulations, Ch. 7; enterprise zones, Ch. 10; flood damage prevention, Ch. 12; historic preservation, Ch. 16; housing, Ch. 17; nursing and care homes, Ch. 21; parks and recreation, Ch. 23; planning and development, Ch. 25; signs, Ch. 28; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 29; trees, shrubs and weeds, Ch. 33; water and sewers, Ch. 35. 
State Law reference- Subdivision regulations generally, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 11-12-7 et seq.; plans generally, Ch. 109. 

Sec. 30-1. - Title. 
    This chapter shall be known and may be cited and referred to as the "Subdivision Ordinance for the Village of Bourbonnais, Illinois". 
(Ord. No. 06-1574, § 1, 6-12-06) 
Sec. 30-2. - Official status. 
    This chapter is hereby made a part of the official plan of the village. 
(Ord. No. 06-1574, § 1, 6-12-06) 
Sec. 30-3. - Intent and purpose. 
    This chapter is adopted for the following purposes: 
(1)  To insure sound, harmonious subdivision development and community growth, and to safeguard the interests of the homeowner, the subdivider, the investor and the village. 
(2)  To provide permanent assets to the locality and to the village. 
(3)  To prevent scattered development beyond existing public utilities and prevent excessive development costs. 
(4)  To assure the development of land for the highest possible use with all the necessary protection against deterioration and obsolescence. 
(5)  To provide common grounds of understanding and a sound working relationship between the village and the developer. 
(Ord. No. 06-1574, § 1, 6-12-06) 
Sec. 30-4. - Application of regulations. 
    No person shall subdivide any tract of land which is located within the village or in any unincorporated area which is located entirely or in part within one and one-half miles of the nearest limits of the village except in conformity with the provisions of this chapter. 
    The subdivision plans and plats, proposed improvements to be installed, and all procedures relating thereto shall in all respects be in full compliance with the regulations herein. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall also apply to all planned developments whether residential, commercial, or otherwise in nature, and to any other developments whether a subdivision is required or not under the law, statutes, ordinances, or regulations of the governmental body or agency having jurisdiction regardless of whether the same is labeled a subdivision or not, it being the intent of this ordinance to apply to all types of development, both within the village and to areas lying within one and one-half miles of the corporate limits of the village. 
(Ord. No. 06-1574, § 1, 6-12-06) 
Sec. 30-5. - General provisions. 
(a)  Whenever any subdivision of land shall hereafter be laid out within the incorporated limits of the village, or within territory not more than one and one-half miles beyond the incorporated boundary of the village, provided such territory is not included in any other municipality, the subdivider thereof or his agent shall submit both a preliminary and final subdivision plat to the plan commissioners for their approval. The subdivision plats and all procedures relating thereto shall in all respects be in full compliance with these regulations. The developer shall submit a time schedule of activities as well as a timetable for completion of the project to the plan commission. 
(1)  No final engineering shall be approved until the preliminary plat for the subdivision is approved. 
(2)  No work may be laid out or improvements made to the natural land until the final engineering has been approved and a site development permit granted. For work within the village and within one-and-one-half miles thereof that is under the jurisdiction of other local or state agencies, i.e., IDOT, Kankakee County, etc., the developer shall provide the village with three copies of applicable and approved site development permit. 
(3)  No final plat shall be approved until the final engineering is approved and a site development permit is granted. Application for a site development permit shall be accompanied by a bond, pursuant to subsection 30-7(a)(4) herein, that guarantees the improvements shall be completed in one year and shall not fail for one year following Village acceptance and final inspection of the improvements. 
(b)  Until plats and plans for the subdivision are approved: 
(1)  No land shall be subdivided, nor any street laid out, nor any improvements made to the natural land. 
(2)  No lot, tract, or parcel of land within any subdivision shall be offered for sale nor shall any sale, contract for sale, or option be made or given. 
(3)  No improvements, such as sidewalks, water supply, stormwater drainage, sanitary sewerage facilities, gas service, electric service, lighting, grading, paving or surfacing of streets shall hereafter be made by any owner or owners or his or their agent, or by any public service corporation at the request of such owner or owners or his or their agent. 
(4)  There shall be no final approval unless the final storm sewer and sanitary sewer laterals, water lines, curbs and base course are in, and lot elevations established within four inches. 
(c)  All offerings or dedications of land to the village for use as streets, highways, alleys, schools, parks, playgrounds, or other public uses, shall be referred to the plan commission for review and recommendation before being accepted by the village board or by any other governing authority of the village. 
(d)  Where a tract of land proposed for subdivision is part of a larger, logical subdivision unit in relation to the village as a whole, the plan commission may, before approval, cause to be prepared a plan for the entire area or neighborhood, such plan to be used by the plan commission as an aid in judging the proposed plat. The village engineer shall cooperate with the plan commission in the preparation of this plan and shall furnish such surveys and data as may be necessary. 
(e)  Whenever an area is subdivided into lots of 30,000 square feet or more and there are indications that such lots will eventually be resubdivided into smaller building lots, consideration shall be given to the street and lot arrangement of the original subdivision so that additional minor streets can be located which will permit a logical arrangement of smaller lots. 
(f)  Interpretation. 
(1)  In their interpretation and application, the provisions of this chapter shall be held to be the minimum requirements. 
(2)  Where the conditions imposed by any provision of this chapter upon the use of land are either more restrictive or less restrictive than comparable conditions imposed by any other provision of this chapter or of any other law, ordinance, resolution, rule or regulation of any kind, the regulations which are more restrictive or which impose higher standards or requirements shall govern. 
(3)  This chapter is not intended to abrogate any easement, covenant, or any other private agreement, provided that where the regulations of this chapter are more restrictive or impose higher standards or requirements than such easements, covenants, or other private agreements, the requirements of this chapter shall govern. 
(4)  If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, or portion of this chapter is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct, and independent provision and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions thereof. 
(g)  The developer shall be required to meet all architectural and engineering obligations imposed by state and federal law, including but not limited to any requirements imposed by the Americans with Disabilities Act (A.D.A.). In the event that the requirements of state and/or federal law differ from this chapter, the stricter requirements must be met. 
(Ord. No. 06-1574, § 1, 6-12-06) 
Sec. 30-6. - Rules and definitions. 
    In an interpretation of this chapter the rules and definitions contained in this section shall be observed and applied, except when the context clearly indicates otherwise. 
(a)  Rules. 
(1)  Words used in the present tense shall include the future; and words used in the singular number shall include the plural number, and the plural number the singular. 
(2)  The word "shall" is mandatory and not discretionary. 
(3)  The word "may" is permissive. 
(4)  The word "lot" shall include the words "plot, "piece", and "parcel". 
(5)  The phrase "used for" shall include the phrases "arranged for", "designed for", "intended for", "maintained for", and "occupied for". 
(b)  Definitions. 
    Alley. A public right-of-way primarily for vehicular traffic along the side or in the rear of properties which affords only a secondary means of access to abutting properties. 
    Applicant. The person or persons responsible for preparing and recording the plats of the subdivision and for carrying out all appropriate requirements relating thereto as outlined in this chapter. 
    Avenue. An area which primarily serves or is intended to serve as a vehicular and pedestrian access to abutting lands or to other streets or avenues. The word "avenue" refers to right-of-way or easement running in a north/south direction in the village. 
    Bituminous base course (BBC). Bituminous base course material shall conform to specification as specified in section 355 of the "Standard Specification For Road and Bridge Construction" adopted by the State of Illinois Department of Transportation. 
    Block. A tract of land bounded by streets, or by a combination of streets and public parks, cemeteries, railroad rights-of-way, bulkhead lines or shorelines of waterways, or corporate boundary lines of the village. 
    Boulevard. Any primary or secondary thoroughfare meeting standards and specifications of the village which is shown on the subdivision plat and is, or is to be, dedicated for public use running in any direction in the village. 
    Building. Any structure designed, built, or intended for the shelter, enclosure, or protection of persons, animals, chattels, or movable property of any kind. 
    Building setback line. A line within a lot or other parcel of land which determines the area on the land where the erection of a building or accessory building is prohibited. The area between the building setback line and the adjacent boundary of the street which the lot abuts is the area on which the erection of a building or accessory building is prohibited. 
    Crosswalk. A public right-of-way located across a block to provide pedestrian access to adjacent streets or areas. 
    Cul-de-sac. A minor street having one open end and being permanently terminated by a vehicle turnaround. 
    Developer. The person(s) having site control over real estate being subdivided to erect any structure, or to install any improvements on a tract of land, or to undertake any activities such as grading in preparation therefor. 
    Easement. A grant by a property owner for the use of a strip of land by the general public, a corporation, or a certain person or persons for a specific purpose or purposes. 
    Highway. A right-of-way for vehicular traffic which traverses a non-urban area, usually a state or federal numbered route. 
    Lot. A portion of a subdivision or other parcel of land intended for transfer of ownership or for building development. 
    Outlot. A tract or portion of land in a subdivision or other parcels of land authorized or granted for use for one or more specific purposes intended as a unit, whether for immediate or future development. The lot shall be reserved and recorded as an outlot. 
    Parkway. A route intended to be used primarily by passenger vehicles and whose right-of-way is or is intended to be developed in a park-like character. 
    Pavements. See "Roadway". 
    Plan commission. The advisory body that provides initial review of sketch plans, preliminary plats, and final plats; they are an advisory body to the village board. The village board will take final action on all three recommendations. 
    Plat. A plan, map, drawing, or chart on which the subdivider's plan for the subdivision of land is presented and which he submits for approval and intends to record in final form. 
    Plat, final. The drawings and documents presented for final approval and as described in subsection 30-7(c). 
    Plat, preliminary. The drawings and documents presented for final approval and as described in subsection 30-7(b). 
    Roadway. The paved area within a street right-of-way intended for vehicular traffic, including all curb and gutter facilities. 
    Street. An area which primarily serves or is intended to serve as a vehicular and pedestrian access to abutting lands or to other streets. The word "street" refers to the right-of-way or easement, avenue, highway, road, boulevard, lane, drive or thoroughfare, whether public or private, running in an east and west direction in the village, and not to the roadway or paving or other improvement within the street right-of-way. 
    Street, approved. Any street whether public or private, meeting standards and specifications of the village. 
    Street, private and public access. A minor street which is adjacent to highways and primary thoroughfares and which provides access to abutting properties and protection to local traffic from fast, through-moving traffic on the highways and primary thoroughfares. 
    Street, minor. A street intended primarily as access to abutting properties. 
    Street, private. Any street which is under the jurisdiction of an individual, corporation, or trustee, or any street which is privately owned or established. 
    Street, public. Any primary or secondary thoroughfare or minor street which is shown on the subdivision plat and is or is to be dedicated for public use. 
    Subdivider. The title holder(s) of real estate which is being subdivided. 
    Subdivision. The division of land into two or more parts, any of which is less than five acres, for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of transfer of ownership or building development, including all public streets, alleys, ways for public service facilities, parks, playgrounds, school grounds or public grounds, and all the tracts, parcels, lots, or blocks and numbering all such lots, blocks, or parcels by progressive numbers, giving their precise dimensions; provided, however, that the following shall not be considered a subdivision and shall be exempt from the requirements of this chapter: 
(1)  The division or subdivision of land into parcels or tracts of five acres or more in size which does not involve any new streets or easements of access; 
(2)  Reserved; 
(3)  The sale or exchange of parcels of land between owners of adjoining and contiguous land; 
(4)  The conveyance of parcels of land or interests therein for use as right-of-way for railroads or other public utility facilities which does not involve any new streets or easements of access; 
(5)  The conveyance of land owned by a railroad or other public utility which does not involve any new streets or easements of access; 
(6)  The conveyance of land for highway or other public purposes or grants or conveyances relating to the dedication of land for public use or instruments relating to the vacation of land impressed with a public use; 
(7)  Conveyances made to correct descriptions in prior conveyances; 
(8)  The sale or exchange of parcels or tracts of land existing on July 17, 1959, into no more than two parts and not involving any new streets or easements of access. 
    Notwithstanding the above, no diminishment in the land area of an existing lot of record shall be permitted if the resulting diminishment results in any lot becoming nonconforming in size, area, length or width for the zoning district in which it is located. Moreover, no residential lot of record shall be reduced in size, area, length or width to an amount less than the average size, area, length or width of the two adjoining residential lots on the respective side yard of lots located on the same street side as the lot in question. 
    Thoroughfare, primary. A street of considerable continuity which serves or is intended to serve as a principal traffic artery between the various sections of the Bourbonnais area and is so designated as a primary thoroughfare on the general development plan. 
    Thoroughfare, secondary. A street which carries traffic from minor streets to the primary thoroughfare system, or between primary thoroughfares, and is so designated as a secondary thoroughfare on the general development plan. 
    Village board. The [village board has the] legal authority to approve sketch plans, preliminary plats, and final plats of subdivisions after recommendations have been made by the plan commission. 
(Ord. No. 06-1574, § 1, 6-12-06) 
Sec. 30-7. - Procedure for approval. 
(a)  General. 
(1)  Sketch plans. 
a.  The developer/subdivider shall schedule a preapplication meeting with the village before preparing the preliminary plat in order to become thoroughly familiar with any regulations or conditions affecting the territory and the goals and objectives of the village's plan. 
b.  Following a meeting with village staff, the developer/subdivider may submit said plans to the plan commission for additional review and comments. The plan commission may provide general comments regarding a sketch plan submitted by subdivider. The plan commission does not approve or deny sketch plans. Sketch plans are considered for informational purposes only. 
(2)  Fees and costs. 
a.  All applications for development or subdivision shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable application fee in the amount as hereinafter set forth in section 30-14 herein. 
b.  No plan shall be forwarded to the planning commission for review without this fee having first been paid. Payment of the fee is in no way contingent on whether the plat of development or subdivision submitted is approved or disapproved. In addition, the applicant shall submit, as part of their application, evidence of title or other information demonstrating that they have a valid contract or option to purchase the land for which the application is made, or is the owner of record for that land. 
c.  All costs incurred by the village for review of plans and specifications, inspection of construction improvements, as may be required, and any costs as incurred by the village engineer, village attorney, and other individuals, as may be needed, shall be paid first by the village, and reimbursed to the village by the developer/subdivider. 
d.  Cash escrow. Prior to commencement of public improvements, the developer shall provide to the village a cash escrow, to be held in a noninterest-bearing account by the village and shall be returned to the applicant upon acceptance by the village of the public improvements as required herein, and submittal of as-built plans, as further required herein. The amount of the cash escrow shall be the lesser of one percent of the estimated cost of improvements as verified by the village's engineer, or $200.00 per lot created, but in no case shall the amount of the escrow be less than $5,000.00. 
(3)  Completion of public improvements. 
a.  A site development permit is required prior to beginning construction of public improvements. Application for a site development permit shall be accompanied by a guarantee the improvements shall be completed in one year and shall not fail for one year following village acceptance and final inspection of the improvements as specified in subsections (1) through (4) herein. 
b.  All public improvements required under the provisions of this chapter to be provided at the subdivider's/developer's expense, and shall be fully completed within one year after receipt of a site development permit, in accordance with the final plans and specifications approved by the village's engineer. 
c.  All contracts for the construction of public improvements shall be subject, upon request, to review and approval by the village engineer prior to the commencement of construction, and all such contracts shall contain contractor's warranties of material and workmanship in form and substance approved by the village engineer. All contracts for construction shall include a requirement that contractor maintain, during the course of construction, "all-risk" builder's risk insurance which names the contractor, subdivider, developer, Village of Bourbonnais, the village's engineer and their officers, employees and agents as additional insured. 
d.  At all times during the progress of construction of the public improvements, the subdivider shall permit the village, village engineer, and their duly authorized representatives to observe any portion thereof. If the village engineer shall determine that the improvements or any portions thereof are not being constructed in accordance with the final plans and specifications previously approved by the village engineer, the village administrator or his duly authorized representative shall have the right, with notice to the owner, to stop the work of any contractor. The work shall not be resumed until the contractor shall receive written authorization from the village administrator for the resumption of the work. 
e.  The developer or the contractor shall notify the village administrator or appointee and village engineer at least 48 hours before construction is to begin or end. This provision shall apply also to the resumption of construction after a break of three days or more and to the temporary halting of construction as for holidays or vacations. Significant changes in the construction schedule shall be reported to the village engineer. 
f.  The village engineer shall be notified when the following work is completed: 
1.  Road subgrade is completed and ready for proof roll. 
(a)  Aggregate road in place to grade ready for proof roll before curbs are installed. 
(b)  Aggregate road base is in place, to grade and ready for proof roll before curbs are installed. All utility crossings are to be inspected before trench backfill to ensure Illinois Environmental Protection Agency requirements are adhered to. 
2.  All utilities are to be inspected before the trench backfill is installed to ensure Illinois Environmental Protection Agency requirements are adhered to. 
3.  Curbs are completed, aggregate road base is in place and ready for inspection before binder is installed. 
4.  Sanitary and storm sewer manholes are installed and grouted. 
5.  Final backfilling and grading are complete. 
g.  The obligation of the subdivider/developer to provide public improvements shall include, without limitation, the furnishing of all necessary surveys, engineering drawings, working drawings, determination of grade and location, communications with contractors, review and approval of periodic payment estimates, collection of lien waivers, and all other services customarily performed by a registered professional engineer and licensed surveyor providing general supervision of such work, and the village shall have no liability or responsibility for such services. 
h.  During the construction phase of the subdivision, and prior to acceptance by the village of the public improvements, the subdivider/developer shall maintain in good condition and restore all existing public improvements to prevent material deterioration thereof, and to assure that no imminent hazard to life or property within the subdivision or areas adjacent thereto shall exist. In the event the subdivider fails to properly maintain or restore existing public improvements, as required herein, the village may, upon ten days' written notice to the subdivider, perform or have performed on its behalf, any maintenance or restoration work reasonably necessary to assure that material deterioration of existing public improvements will not occur. In the event it is determined by the village administrator or his duly authorized representative that failure of the subdivider/developer to properly maintain or restore existing public improvements will result in imminent hazard to life or property within the subdivision or in areas adjacent thereto, the village may, without prior notice to the subdivider/developer perform or have performed on its behalf any maintenance or restoration work reasonably necessary to prevent such hazards. Within ten days thereafter, the subdivider shall be notified in writing by the village administrator of the performance of such work by the village, and the cost thereof. In the event that the maintenance or restoration work is performed by or on behalf of the village, the village may withdraw the security required by this chapter in an amount equal to the cost of that work, plus ten percent thereof, for administrative purposes. 
i.  Upon completion of the public improvements required under the provisions of this chapter, the subdivider/developer shall file with the village engineer, a certificate, certified by a registered professional engineer licensed to practice engineering in the State of Illinois, to the effect that all such public improvements have been substantially completed in accordance with the final plans and specifications approved by the village engineer. In addition, the subdivider shall furnish to the village engineer three complete sets of as-built plans, and one electronic copy on CD in AutoCAD or comparable format, as recommended by the village engineer. The neighborhood drainage plan sheet shall be signed and certified as provided in this chapter. Upon receipt of the plans, the village engineer shall forward one complete set to the village department of public works, one complete set to the village department of building standards and shall retain one set for his own files. 
j.  If the public improvements have been completed within one year from the receipt of a site development permit, the owner or subdivider has filed the certificate, and as-built engineering plans required herein, the village engineer shall make a site visit and observe the public improvements. If he determines that the public improvements are in conformance with the as-built engineering plans, approved plans, and all codes and ordinances of the village, the village engineer shall forward to the village administrator his recommendation that the public improvements to be approved and accepted by the village board as satisfactory. Within 30 days following receipt of such recommendation, the village board shall approve and accept the public improvements and shall authorize the village administrator to release or refund to the depositor thereof, the guarantee for the public improvements provided pursuant to the regulations herein. However, the village shall hold the additional ten percent guarantee in escrow for a period of one year. 
k.  If the subdivider/developer shall fail to complete all the required public improvements, or shall fail to complete the improvements in conformance with the approved final plans and specifications within one year from receipt of a site development permit, the village may withdraw all funds provided as security pursuant to the provisions herein, and may utilize those funds to cause the performance of any work necessary to complete the public improvements or to bring them into conformance with the approved final plans and specifications, codes or ordinances of the village. The subdivider shall be obligated to reimburse the village for any costs incurred in excess of those funds in order to complete the required public improvements. 
l.  Approval of the preliminary or final plat by the village board shall not constitute an acceptance of any dedicated streets and improvements for maintenance purposes, irrespective of any act or acts by any officer, agent or employee of the village with respect to those streets and improvements for maintenance purposes shall be made only by the adoption of a resolution by the village board after there has been filed with the village clerk a certificate or letter by the village administrator and village engineer certifying that all improvements required to be constructed or installed in connection with the approval of the final plat of subdivision or development have been fully completed and the construction or installation thereof has been approved by the village engineer. 
m.  Special requirements for bituminous pavement. The following qualifications and requirements shall apply to bituminous pavements regardless of design methods used: 
1.  No construction required by this section shall be permitted after November 1 without written authorization of the village engineer. 
2.  In new construction, the final asphalt surface shall not be installed until at least 80 percent of the lots in the phase currently being constructed have been developed, or for a period of at least one year from construction of the roadway, whichever shall occur first. The final asphalt surface shall not be installed until inspected by village engineer and the developer has repaired failed bituminous concrete binder course. 
n.  Television inspection. All public sanitary and storm sewers shall be internally video taped by remote camera. Tapes shall be in color of VHS or DVD format and submitted with written reports to the village engineer for his review and approval prior to acceptance of the sewer improvements by the village. 
(4)  Acceptance of streets and improvements. Final approval of a plat by the village board shall not constitute an acceptance of any dedicated streets and improvements for maintenance purposes, irrespective of any act or acts by any officer, agent or employee of the village with respect to those streets or improvements. Final acceptance of all streets and improvements for maintenance purposes shall be made only by the adoption of a resolution by the village board after there has been filed with the village clerk a certificate or letter by the village administrator and village engineer certifying that all improvements required to be constructed or installed in connection with the approval of the final plat of subdivision or development have been fully completed and the construction or installation thereof has been approved by the village engineer. 
(5)  Guarantee of public improvements. 
a.  The owner or developer/subdivider shall guarantee the public improvements for a period of one year from the date the village board accepts those improvements. during this one-year period, the owner or developer/subdivider shall be obligated, upon written notice from the village administrator, as provided herein, to repair or reconstruct any public improvement or portion thereof which may deteriorate, fail, or otherwise cease to meet the standards established by the engineer's certificate or as-built plans, provided that ordinary maintenance shall not be the obligation of the owner or developer/subdivider. 
b.  The village administrator shall provide written notice to the owner or developer/subdivider of deterioration of public improvements, specifying a time period in which the deterioration is to be remedied; and the owner or developer/subdivider shall perform the necessary repair or reconstruction at his own expense within the time specified. 
c.  In the event that it is determined by the village administrator or his authorized representative that failure of the owner or developer/subdivider to restore existing public improvements will result in imminent hazard to life or property within the development or subdivision or in areas adjacent thereto, the village may, without prior written notice to the owner or developer/subdivider, perform, or have performed on its behalf, any restoration work reasonably necessary to prevent that hazard. Within ten days thereafter, the owner or developer/subdivider shall be notified in writing by the village administrator of the performance of the work and of the cost thereof. 
d.  To secure the performance of the obligations imposed by this section, the owner or developer/subdivider shall provide to the village a performance bond, issued by a surety authorized to do business in the state, in an amount equal to 110 percent of the village engineer's written estimate of the total cost of the public improvements. This bond is to expire no earlier than one year after the village board's acceptance of the public improvements. 
e.  In the event that during the one-year guarantee period, the owner or developer/subdivider shall fail to repair, reconstruct, or otherwise remedy conditions of deterioration of public improvement in the development or subdivision within the time specified in the village's written notice of those conditions, or shall fail to reimburse the village for the cost of emergency restoration performed by or on behalf of the village pursuant to this section within 30 days of receiving notice of such cost, the village may file a claim against the bond required herein for performance of the obligation by the surety. 
(6)  Restriction on issuance of building permits. No building permits shall be issued to erect a structure on property within the village limits until that property has been subdivided in compliance with this chapter. No building permit shall be issued to erect a structure on any subdivided property within the village, which property is being resubdivided, until:
