a.  That property has been resubdivided in compliance with this chapter; 
b.  A development permit has been granted by the building department; 
c.  The lot corners have been clearly marked; and 
d.  Adequate survey benchmarks have been set for foundation location surveyor certification. 
However, at the discretion of the village administrator, a building permit for any structure to be erected on any lot in the subdivision may be denied until such time as the subdivider shall have completed such public improvements as are determined by the village engineer to be necessary to provide reasonable access, adequate drainage, and proper water and sanitary sewage facilities to serve the lot on which the structure is built. 
(7)  Enforcement. No plat of any subdivision on any development plan shall be entitled to be recorded in the recorder's office or have any validity until it has been approved in a manner prescribed by this chapter. 
(8)  Procedure for conditional approval of preliminary plat. 
a.  On reaching conclusions, informally, as recommended in paragraph (a)(2) above, regarding his general program and objectives, the subdivider/developer shall cause to be prepared a preliminary plat. 
b.  Fourteen full-size copies and ten reduced copies (11" × 17") of the preliminary plat shall be submitted, along with a written application for approval at least 21 days prior to the meeting at which it is to be considered. Three of the full-size copies shall be accompanied by the documents and data required in this chapter. These copies, documents and data are to be distributed to the village administrator (or his designee), the village attorney and the village engineer. 
c.  The first meeting with the plan commission may be considered a workshop. The subdivider will be allowed to deliver a short presentation at the workshop. The plan commission will provide comments to the subdivider and may provide copies of comments provided by the village's staff and others. The plan commission will often table consideration of the preliminary plat at this first meeting to give the subdivider opportunity to address various comments. 
d.  Following review of the preliminary plat and other data submitted in compliance with these regulations, and following negotiations with the subdivider on changes deemed advisable and the kind and extent of improvement to be made by him, the plan commission shall, within 60 days or at the first regularly scheduled meeting after resubmittal, act on the preliminary plat and data as submitted or modified, the plan commission shall express its decision as a "recommendation to the village board" and state the conditions of such recommendation, if any. 
e.  Following recommendation by the plan commission and following negotiations with the subdivider on changes deemed advisable and the kind and extent of improvement to be made by him, the village board shall, within 30 days, act on the preliminary plat and data as submitted or modified, and, if approved, the village board shall express its approval and state the conditions of such approval, if any, or, if disapproved, the village board shall express its disapproval and its reasons therefor. 
f.  Approval of a preliminary plat shall not constitute approval of the final plat. Rather it shall be deemed an expression of approval to the layout submitted on the preliminary plat as a guide to the preparation of the final plans and specifications and the final plat. 
(b)  Procedure for approval of final plans and specifications. Four copies of the final plans and specifications, along with all supporting documentation, shall be submitted to the village, for distribution to the public works department, building department and the village administrator; one complete set of final plans and specifications, along with all supporting documentation, shall be delivered directly to the village engineer. The village engineer shall provide written comments to the subdivider's/developer's design engineer for consideration. The final plans and specifications shall not be approved until they conform to the approved preliminary plat, village codes and ordinances, and accepted engineering practices, and copies of all other applicable agency permits have been received by the village engineer. The village engineer shall be copied on all agency correspondence throughout the permitting process. 
(c)  Procedure for approval of final plat. 
(1)  The final plat shall conform substantially to the preliminary plat as approved, and, if desired by the applicant, it may constitute only that portion of the approved preliminary plat which he proposed to record and develop at the time, provided, however, that such portion conforms to all requirements of these regulations and phasing indicated on the preliminary plat. 
(2)  Fourteen full-size copies and ten reduced copies (11" × 17") of the final plat shall be submitted to the plan commission along with a written application for approval at least 15 days prior to the meeting at which it is to be considered. Three of the full-size copies shall be accompanied by the required conditions, covenants and restrictions, and other documents required to be recorded with the final plat. These copies and documents are to be distributed to the village administrator (or his designee), village attorney and village engineer. 
(3)  The final plat and other exhibits required for approval shall be prepared and shall be submitted to the plan commission within two years after approval of the preliminary plat; otherwise such approval shall become null and void unless application for an extension of time is made to and granted by the village board. 
(4)  The Final plat submitted to the plan commission for approval shall be accompanied by a letter from the village engineer approving the final engineering specifications, and supporting documentation, and a certificate by the subdivider/developer and the subdivider's/developer's engineer disclosing and detailing all revisions of the preliminary plat. It shall be the duty of the developer to make a complete disclosure of all differences of any type between the preliminary and final plats. 
(5)  Within 30 days after application for approval of the final plat, the plan commission shall approve or disapprove it. If the plan commission approves, it shall affix its seal upon the plat together with the certifying signature of its chairman and secretary. If it disapproves, it shall set forth its reasons in its own records and provide the applicant with a copy. 
(6)  Filing. 
a.  After approval of the final plat by the plan commission, and the fulfillment of the requirements of these regulations, 12 copies of the final plat of the subdivision, drawn in accordance with the standards established by the Kankakee County Recorder of Deeds and the laws of the State of Illinois, shall be submitted to the village board for approval. 
b.  Action must be taken by the village board within 30 days after the final plat has been submitted for approval. 
c.  The final plat submitted to the village board for approval shall be accompanied by one of the following: 
1.  A certificate by the village engineer that all improvements and installations to the subdivision required for its approval have been made or installed in accordance with the approved specifications; and a certificate of insurance, good for one year, from the date of acceptance of said improvements by the village in an amount equal to ten percent of the cost of said improvements, as recommended by the village engineer; or 
2.  A bond which shall: 
i.  Run to the president and board of trustees of the village; 
ii.  Be in the amount of 110 percent of the infrastructure improvements shown on the approved final plans and specifications, said amount to be determined by the subdivider's/developer's engineer, and approved by the village engineer; 
iii.  Be in one of the following forms: 
 Surety by a company licensed to do business in the state; 
 Cash; 
 An irrevocable letter of credit; or 
 An escrow account set up in a manner acceptable to the village attorney; 
iv.  Specify the time for the completion of the improvements and installations. The time limit for completion shall be no longer than one year from the date of final plat approval by the village. 
v.  Any surety, bond or letter of credit required by this chapter shall be maintained and renewed by the owner/applicant and shall be held in escrow by the village. Failure of the owner/applicant to maintain and renew the surety, bond or letter of credit shall be punishable by a fine of between $100.00 and $300.00 per day. The letter of credit shall be in a form satisfactory to the village attorney and each shall be from a bank acceptable to the village in its reasonable determination, with an office located in Illinois. Each surety, bond and letter of credit shall, at a minimum, provide that (a) it shall not be canceled without the prior consent of the village, (b) it shall not require the consent of the owner/applicant prior to any draw on it by the village, provided it may require a certification, under oath, by the village administrator which identifies the work which has not been completed or otherwise sets forth the default which exists, and (c) if at any time it will expire within 45 or any lesser number of days, and if it has not been renewed, and if any applicable obligation of the owner/applicant for which it is security remains uncompleted or unsatisfactory, then the village may call and draw down the letter of credit and thereafter either hold all proceeds as security for the satisfactory completion of the obligations or employ the proceeds to complete the obligations and reimburse the village for any and all costs and expenses, including without limitation legal fees, village engineer's fees and administrative costs, incurred by the village, as the village shall determine. 
d.  Upon approval by the village board, receipt of a site development permit and signing by the village president, the developer shall record the plat with the County Recorder of Kankakee County within four months. If not recorded within this time, the approval shall be null and void. Immediately after recording two certified copies shall be filed with the village clerk. 
(d)  Reduction in letters of credit. Reductions in letters of credit may be authorized by the village administrator, following a request for same by the developer or the developer's representative, provided: 
(1)  The village engineer has issued a written recommendation stating the reduction is warranted, and specifying the amount of reduction; and 
(2)  There are no other outstanding issues relating to the development for which developer's action is being requested. 
(3)  The reduction in the letter of credit shall not be greater than the amount as recommended by the village engineer. 
(Ord. No. 06-1574, § 1, 6-12-06; Ord. No. 10-1840, § 2, 2-16-10) 
Sec. 30-8. - Acceptance of ponds. 
(a)  All stormwater management improvements shall be designed and constructed according to applicable regulations of the village, and prior to acceptance by the village, shall be further certified by the village engineer that all improvements have been constructed in accordance with said regulations. 
(b)  Any "wet bottom" stormwater area intended to be dedicated to the village shall be designed and constructed in accordance with the standards as outlined in appendix "A" hereof, entitled "Naturalized Detention Basins-Installation and Maintenance". 
(c)  Any "wet bottom" stormwater areas not designed in accordance with appendix "A", entitled "Naturalized Detention Basins-Installation and Maintenance" shall be certified by the village engineer that all improvements have been constructed in accordance with applicable standards of the village, and are to become the responsibility: 
(1)  Of a homeowners association, as approved by the village; or 
(2)  Homes immediately adjacent to the stormwater area, the lots of said adjacent houses shall encompass the entire stormwater area in a drainage easement; or 
(3)  Of a single property owner, as approved by the village. 
(d)  Regardless of tiered-ownership options, the village reserves the right to create a special service area to address costs associated with maintenance of stormwater management areas. Said ordinance shall be substantially in the following form: 
An Ordinance Establishing a Special Service Area 
In the Village of Bourbonnais, Kankakee County, Illinois

Sec. 30-9. - Design standards. 
(a)  Streets. 
(1)  All streets shall be considered in their relation to existing and planned streets, to topographical conditions, to public convenience and safety, and to the proposed uses of the land to be served by such streets. 
(2)  Where such is not shown on the general development plan, the arrangement of streets in a subdivision shall either: 
a.  Provide for the continuation or appropriate projection of existing principal streets in surrounding areas; or 
b.  Conform to a plan for the area or neighborhood approved or adopted by the plan commission to meet a particular situation where topographical or other conditions make continuance or conformance to existing streets impracticable. 
(3)  Minor streets shall be so laid out that their use by through traffic will be discouraged. 
(4)  Where a subdivision abuts or contains an existing or proposed highway or primary thoroughfare, as shown on the general development plan, the plan commission may require marginal access streets; reverse frontage with screen planting contained in a nonaccess reservation, at least ten feet wide, along the rear property line; deep lots with rear service alleys; or such other treatment as may be necessary for adequate protection of residential properties and to afford separation of through and local traffic. 
(5)  Where a subdivision borders on or contains a railroad or highway, the plan commission may require a street approximately parallel to and on each side of such railroad or highway, at a distance suitable for the appropriate use of the intervening land, as for park purposes in residential districts, or for commercial or industrial purposes in appropriate districts. Such distances shall also be determined with due regard for the requirements of approach grades and future grade separations. 
(6)  Reserve strips controlling access to streets or alleys shall be prohibited. 
(7)  All street intersections and confluences should encourage safe traffic flow. 
(8)  Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than 125 feet shall be avoided. 
(9)  Tangents shall be introduced between reverse horizontal curves on all streets (see "Minimum Standards for Street Design" herein). 
(10)  When connecting street lines deflect from each other at any one point by more than ten degrees, they shall be connected by a curve with a radius adequate to insure clear sight distances (see "Minimum Standards for Street Design" herein). 
(11)  Streets shall be laid out so as to intersect as nearly as possible at right angles, and no street shall intersect any other street at less than 60 degrees. 
(12)  Property lines at street intersections shall be rounded with a radius as specified in "Minimum Standards for Street Design" herein. The plan commission may permit comparable cut-offs or chords in place of rounded corners. 
(13)  Street right-of-way widths shall be as specified in "Minimum Standards for Street Design" herein. 
(14)  Half streets shall be prohibited, except where essential to the reasonable development of the subdivision in conformity with the other requirements of these regulations and where the plan commission finds it will be practicable to require the dedication of the other half when the adjoining property is subdivided. Wherever a half street is adjacent to a tract to be subdivided, the other half of the street shall be platted within such tract. 
(15)  Dead-end streets (cul-de-sacs), designed to be so permanently, shall not be longer than 500 feet from the intersection of the origin through the center of the circle to the end of the right-of-way, and shall be provided at the closed end with a turn-around having an outside pavement diameter of at least 80 feet and a street property line diameter of at least 112 feet. 
(16)  No street names shall be used which will duplicate or be confused with the names of existing streets. Existing street names shall be projected wherever possible. Street names shall be subject to the approval of the plan commission. 
(17)  Street gradients and vertical curves shall be as specified in "Minimum Standards for Street Design" herein. 
(18)  Street grades shall provide proper relation between the street and the first floor elevation of the houses or buildings and permit convenient and economical access to and drainage of the lots. 
(19)  In addition to meeting these minimum design standards, all roadways shall meet or exceed AASHTO standards.

(b)  Alleys. 
(1)  Alleys shall be provided in commercial, business, and industrial districts, except that the plan commission may waive this requirement where other definite and assured provisions are made for service access, such as off-street loading, unloading, and parking, consistent with and adequate for the uses proposed. 
(2)  Alleys in residential areas shall not be permitted, except where deemed necessary and on the recommendation of the plan commission. 
(3)  The width of an alley, where permitted, shall be 30 feet. 
(4)  Alley intersections and sharp changes in alley alignment shall be avoided, but, where necessary, corners may be cut off sufficiently to permit safe vehicular movement. 
(5)  Dead-end alleys shall be avoided where possible, but if unavoidable, they shall be provided with adequate turnaround facilities at the dead end, as determined by the plan commission. 
(c)  Easements. 
(1)  Easements across lots or centered on rear or side lines shall be provided for utilities where necessary and shall be at least 12 feet wide, except easements dedicated solely as street light easements which may be eight feet wide. 
(2)  Easements shall be designed to provide continuity from block to block. 
(3)  Where a subdivision is traversed by a water course, drainageway, channel, or stream, there shall be provided a stormwater easement or drainage right-of-way conforming substantially with the line of such water course and shall include such further width or construction, or both, as will be adequate for the purpose and as determined by the village engineer. A minimum of ten feet shall be provided on either side of the ditch measured from the top of the bank away from the centerline of the drainageway. Parallel streets or parkways may be required in connection therewith. 
(d)  Blocks. 
(1)  The lengths, widths, and shapes of blocks shall be determined with due regard to: 
a.  Provision of adequate building sites suitable to the special needs of the type of use contemplated. 
b.  Zoning requirements as to lot sizes and dimensions within the corporate limits of the village. 
c.  Needs for convenient access, circulation, control and safety of street traffic. 
d.  Limitations and opportunities of topography. 
(2)  Block lengths shall not exceed 1,500 feet, or be less than 600 feet. 
(3)  Pedestrian crosswalk right-of-ways not less than ten feet wide shall be required where deemed necessary by the plan commission to provide for pedestrian circulation or access to schools, playgrounds, shopping centers, transportation, and other community facilities. 
(4)  Blocks or portions thereof intended for commercial or industrial use shall be designated as such, and the plan shall show adequate off-street areas to provide for parking, loading docks, and other such facilities. 
(e)  Lots. 
(1)  The lot size, width, depth, shape, and orientation shall be appropriate for the location of the subdivision and for the type of development and use contemplated. 
(2)  Lot dimensions and areas shall conform to the requirements of the Bourbonnais Zoning Ordinance where applicable, but in no case shall a lot for residential purposes in a new subdivision be less than 50 feet wide at the building line, nor less than 6,000 square feet in area. However: 
a.  Residential lots where not served by public sanitary sewers and water supply shall be not less than 100 feet wide at the building line nor less than 20,000 square feet in area. Where either public sanitary sewers or water supply is provided, a lot shall be not less than 80 feet wide nor less than 10,000 square feet in area or as outlined by the county health department. 
b.  Where unusual soil conditions or other physical factors exist which may impair the health and safety of the residents of the neighborhood in which a or the Kankakee County Public Health Department, the plan commission may increase lot area requirements as may be necessary. 
c.  Lots abutting a watercourse, drainageway, channel, or stream shall have minimum width or depth as required to provide an adequate building site and to afford the minimum usable area required in this chapter or the Bourbonnais zoning ordinance for front, rear, and side yards. 
d.  Depths and widths of lots or properties reserved or laid out for commercial, business, or industrial purposes shall be adequate to provide for the off-street service and parking facilities required in the Bourbonnais Zoning Ordinance. 
(3)  Corner lots for residential use shall have a minimum of ten percent extra width to permit appropriate building setback from and to permit appropriate orientation to both streets on which they abut. 
(4)  All lots shall abut on a publicly-dedicated street and/or an easement dedicated for a roadway. 
(5)  Double frontage and reverse frontage lots shall be avoided except where essential to provide separation of residential development from highways or primary thoroughfares or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography and orientation. A planting screen easement of at least ten feet, and across which there shall be no right of access, shall be provided along the line of lots abutting such highways and primary thoroughfares or other disadvantageous use. 
(6)  Side lot lines shall be substantially at right angles or radial to street lines. 
(f)  Building setback lines. Building setback lines in residential areas of new subdivisions shall conform to the front yard provisions of the Bourbonnais Zoning Ordinance, except that in no case shall the building setback line be less than 25 feet from the front property line. A corner lot shall maintain not less than the minimum building setback lines required on both streets on which the lot abuts. 
(g)  Parks, schools, and public areas. As a condition of approval of a final plat of subdivision, a final plat of resubdivision or of a final development plan (including a planned unit development), each subdivider or developer will be required to dedicate land and donate money for public park and recreational uses to serve the immediate and future needs of the residents of the development, or a cash contribution in lieu of actual land dedication, or a combination of both, at the option of the village in accordance with the following criteria and formulae: 
(1)  Criteria for requiring park and recreational land dedication and cash payments. 
a.  Requirements and population ratio. The ultimate population of a proposed development shall bear directly upon the amount of land required for dedication. The total requirement shall be ten acres of land per thousand of ultimate population in a subdivision or planned unit development, plus the sum of cash per dwelling unit as outlined in "appendix exhibit C". (Appendix exhibit C is not set out herein, but is on file and available for inspection in the office of the village clerk). 
In the event the ultimate population of a subdivision or planned unit development will be less than or greater than 1,000 persons, the amount of land required for dedication will be determined by using the ratio of six acres per 1,000 population as the determining standard. (See appendix exhibit C.) 
The money contribution shall be used by the village for park land acquisition, park site preparation and construction, equipment and other related improvement costs. 
b.  Location. A location which will serve the entire development is most desirable. In large developments these sites can be located throughout the development. 
c.  Retention requirements. Land dedication required by this chapter may include land required for drainage or retention purposes pending approval of the village engineer, park board and plan commission. 
d.  Credit for private open spaces and recreation areas. When subdividers or developers provide their own open space for private use, it has the effect of reducing the demand for local public land service. Depending on the size of the development, a portion of the park and recreation area in subdivisions or planned unit developments may, at the option of the board of trustees be provided in the form of "private" open space in lieu of dedicated "public" open space. The extent of same shall be determined by the board of trustees based upon the needs of the estimated population and in conformance to the total park and recreation land for the general area. 
In general, a substitution of "private" open space for park and recreation land will imply a substantially higher degree of improvement and the installation of recreational facilities, including equipment by the developer as part of his obligation. Detailed plans of such areas, including specifications of facilities to be installed, must be approved by the board of trustees, and before any credit is given for "private" open space areas, the subdivider or developer must guarantee in form satisfactory to the board of trustees, that those "private" open space areas will be permanently maintained for such use. Private "swimming clubs" are included in this provision. When an adjustment for "private" open space areas is warranted, it will be necessary to compute the total park and recreation land dedication that would have been required from the subdivision or planned unit development and then subtract the credit to be given. 
(2)  Criteria for requiring a contribution to cash in lieu of park and recreation land. Where the development is small and the resulting site is too small to be practical or when the available land is inappropriate for park and recreational land use, or when land for park and recreation use cannot be made contiguous to existing or proposed sites as designated by the village master plan, the village, upon recommendation of the board of trustees shall require the subdivider or developer to pay cash contributions in lieu of the land dedication that would have been required. The cash contributions in lieu of park and recreation use shall be held in trust by the village solely for the acquisition of land for parks and recreation which will be available to serve the immediate and future needs of the residents of the subdivision or development or for the improvement of other existing park and recreation facilities within the village which already serve such needs. It shall be the policy of the village to use its best efforts to use the cash contributions in the general area of the development for which they were contributed. 
a.  Fair market value. The cash contributions in lieu of land shall be based on the fair market value of the acres of land in the area improved as specified herein, that otherwise would have been dedicated for park and recreation purposes. It has been determined that fair market value of such improved land in and surrounding the village is as follows: 
$25,000.00 per acre; 
and the applicable figure shall be used in making any calculation herein unless the subdivider or developer files a written objection thereto with the board of trustees. 
In the event of any such objection, the subdivider or developer shall submit an appraisal showing the fair market value of such improved land in the area of in his development or other evidence thereof and a final determination of said fair market value per acre of such improved land shall be made by the board of trustees based upon such information submitted by the subdivider or developer and from other sources which may be obtained by the board of trustees, the village park board, or others. The fair market value shall be reviewed and adjusted annually commencing one year after the adoption of this chapter. The board of trustees will review fair market value annually to accurately reflect land value within the village and within the planning jurisdiction of the village. In the event that the board of trustees fails to review and adjust the fair market value on an annual basis, such value shall automatically increase at a rate of the assessed value of land per annum commencing on each anniversary of adoption of this chapter. In any event, if the board of trustees fails to review and adjust the fair market value on an annual basis, such failure shall not be deemed to invalidate this chapter, or any parts thereof.

Notes: 
1.  Developers are required to donate land for each unit to be constructed. 
2.  This donation will be made in either actual acreage per the schedule in column A or as cash in lieu of land per the schedule in column B, or as a combination thereof, as determined by the village board. 
3.  Developers are also required to contribute for equipment and site development, as outlined in schedule in column C. 
(3)  Criteria for requiring dedication and a contribution. There will be situations in subdivisions or planned unit developments when a combination of land dedication and a contribution in lieu of land are both necessary. These occasions will arise when: 
a.  Only a portion of the land to be developed is proposed as the location for land for park and recreation use. That portion of the land within the subdivision or planned unit development falling within the park and recreational use location shall be dedicated as a site, as aforesaid, and a cash contribution in lieu thereof shall be required for any additional land that would have been required to be dedicated. 
b.  A major part of the local park and recreation land has already been acquired and only a small portion of land is needed from the subdivision or development to complete the site. The small portion shall be dedicated and a cash contribution shall be required in lieu of any additional land that would have been required for dedication. 
(4)  Density formula. A document entitled "Population Per Unit-Naperville, Illinois", prepared by Associated Municipal Consultants Inc., is attached as "appendix exhibit C" and incorporated herein by reference. Such table is generally indicative of current and short-range projected trends in family size for new construction and shall be used in calculating the amount of required dedication of acres and land or cash contribution thereof. It is recognized that population density, age distribution and local conditions change over period of time; therefore, the table shall be updated every two years, if deemed necessary in the opinion of the board of trustees, after passage of this chapter, to reflect the latest table published by Associated Municipal Consultants or any comparably reliable source. If the board of trustees fails to renew said table and update same, such failure shall not be deemed to invalidate this chapter or any parts thereof. A subdivider or developer may file with the board of trustees a written objection to the table listed herein. In the event a subdivider or developer files a written objection to such table, he shall submit his own demographic study showing the estimated additional population to be generated from the subdivision or planned unit development and in that event a determination of the density formula to be used in calculating the dedication or contribution required herein shall be made by the board of trustees after review of such demographic information. 
(5)  Reservation of additional land. Where the comprehensive plan or the designation by the village calls for a larger amount of land for park or recreational use in a particular subdivision or planned unit development than the subdivider or developer is required to dedicate, the land needed beyond the subdivider's or developer's contribution shall be reserved for subsequent purchase (or condemnation) by the village in accordance with the applicable requirements of the Illinois Municipal Code. 
(6)  Combining with adjoining developments. Where the subdivision or planned unit development is less than 40 acres, park and recreation lands which are to be dedicated should be, where possible, and in the best interests of the village, combined with dedications from the adjoining developments in order to produce usable park lands and thereby minimize the hardship on a particular subdivider or developer. 
(7)  Topography and grading. The slope, topography and geology of the dedicated site as well as its surroundings must be suitable for its intended purpose. A subdivider or developer shall allow the village to have access to proposed sites for the purpose of conducting soil boring tests. 
(8)  Combining park and recreation land and land for a school site. Wherever possible, and whenever in the best interests of the village and the effected school district, land dedication for park and recreation sites shall be contiguous to land dedicated for a school site. 
(9)  Time of conveyance or payment. 
a.  Conveyance. A subdivider or developer shall convey to the village the land required under this chapter at the time of final approval by the board of trustees of the subdivision or resubdivision plat, or final development plan by the delivery of the following documents: 
1.  A good and sufficient trustee's or warranty deed conveying fee simple title free and clear of all encumbrances (except liens or encumbrances dischargeable by cash accompanying said deed) except for current real estate taxes; 
2.  Preliminary commitment for title insurance issued by a title insurance company acceptable to the board of trustees covering a date not more than 30 days prior to the date of conveyance in the amount of the fair market value of the land to be conveyed as established herein, subject only to the matters hereof, and to such other matters acceptable to the board of trustees; 
3.  An affidavit of title to the real estate; 
4.  Completed Illinois Department of Revenue and Kankakee County real estate declarations; 
5.  A deposit of money sufficient to cover the real estate taxes for the entire year in which the deed is delivered; and 
6.  A plat of survey containing thereon the legal description of the property to be conveyed and any other matters which may be required by the village engineer. 
b.  Payment. Cash contributions required under this chapter shall be paid as follows: 
1.  One hundred percent of the sum determined shall be paid at the time of final approval of the plat of subdivision, resubdivision or final development plan or otherwise provided to the village in the village's sole discretion by agreement between the developer and the village. 
In no event shall the balance due to the village be paid more than three years from the final approval of developer's project. 
2.  It shall be the duty of the village treasurer to establish regulations and procedures for the collection and administration of the cash contributions required under this chapter. 
(10)  Credit for land and cash or contribution of cash in lieu of land given under annexation agreements. If a subdivider or developer has given land and a contribution of money or a contribution of cash in lieu of land as part of an annexation agreement and thereafter the subdivider or developer or their successors submit a plan of subdivision or resubdivision or final development plan which will increase the density of population in those areas covered by the annexation agreement, then the subdivider or developer shall be required to make an additional contribution of park and recreation land, or of cash in lieu thereof as outlined above. The additional land or cash in lieu of land to be contributed shall be the difference between that land or cash in lieu of land required as determined from the plat of subdivision or resubdivision or final development plan and that land or cash in lieu of land previously contributed under the annexation agreement. 
(11)  Developer agreements. The village may enter into a developer agreement with any subdivider or developer which sets forth the time and manner of compliance with the terms of this chapter and implementation of any other provisions of the village's subdivision regulations. If any developer agreement has been previously entered into between the village and a subdivider and that agreement remains in full force and effect, the provisions of that agreement shall control and this chapter shall have no force and effect, provided that subdivider complies with the terms of such agreement; also, if an agreement specifies a dollar amount that the subdivider is required to pay to the village then this chapter shall have no force or effect. In all other cases, the subdivider is required to pay fees pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, and the village shall utilize the fees set forth herein to determine the appropriate exaction amount, less credits, if any. Further, if the development contemplated by a subdivider or developer has increased the population density in excess of the amount previously estimated by reason of resubdivision or rezoning, then the developer agreement previously entered into between the subdivider and the village shall be amended and the subdivider or developer shall pay an additional pro-rata fee based on the fee schedule set forth in this chapter. 
(h)  Driveways, curbs and gutters, and sidewalks. 
(1)  Materials and minimum thickness. Driveways shall be constructed using accepted procedures and equipment of one of the following alternates: 
a.  All new construction shall require the following: 
1.  Portland cement concrete. Four-inch thickness reinforced with six-inch by six-inch wire reinforcing mesh or fiber mesh concrete, over a four-inch compacted aggregate base, or 
2.  Any alternate materials other than those mentioned above shall be presented to the village engineer for his approval in writing prior to the use thereof. No asphalt nor any oil and chip surfaces will be allowed. 
b.  Any existing asphalt driveway may be replaced or repaired with asphalt. Any existing stone, tar and chip, dirt or earthen driveway shall be repaired or replaced by Portland cement concrete as required herein for new construction. 
(2)  Curb cuts. All curb cuts necessary for driveways, wheelchair ramps, and bicycle crossings accessing on village streets shall be completed as follows in accordance with all applicable A.D.A. standards: 
a.  The complete existing combination concrete curb and gutter shall be removed and then replaced with a new combination concrete curb and gutter (depressed) according to the "Standard Specification For Road and Bridge Construction" adopted by the State of Illinois Department of Transportation. 
b.  Driveways may be finished off to match the top of the existing curb without a curb-cut, if and only if such curb is a modified M-3:12 or at a height less than three inches measured up from the gutter pan flow line. 
c.  Removal of back of curb by special saw-cut method using machinery specifically designed for that purpose. 
(3)  Gutter pans. All gutter pans or gutters shall be kept clear of all materials. No concrete, asphalt or any other material will be permitted in the gutter pan. This prohibitive restriction also applies to pipes or any other device placed in the gutter pans to provide a better approach to the driveway. 
(4)  Driveway slope. No driveway shall be constructed at a grade that exceeds eight percent from the garage to the street unless the village engineer specifically approves a greater slope. 
(5)  Public sidewalks intersecting with street curb and gutter. The back of the curb at this point of intersection shall not exceed one and one-half inches elevation over the flow line of the gutter pan and shall meet all A.D.A. requirements. 
(6)  General. Any damage done to the village infrastructure system at the time of construction shall be repaired to the satisfaction of the village engineer or the appointed village official. At no time shall any portion of the combination concrete curb and gutter be poured as an integral part of the driveway. A joint using performed [preformed] joint filler shall be provided between the back of the curb and the driveway portion. 
(7)  Distance from property line. No driveway surfaces shall be installed within three feet from side lot lines, so as to prevent sheet drainage onto adjacent properties. 
(8)  Enforcement. The building inspector of the village is charged with the responsibility to enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(i)  No fence/no access/landscape easements. For all new residential developments adjacent to section line roads, including but not limited to Roadway 5000 North, Roadway 6000 North, Career Center Road, and other roads as designated by the planning commission, developers shall provide, in addition to any and all required rights-of-way, a 30-foot-wide no fence landscape easement in all residential rear yards, beyond the rear yard setbacks. As part of the village's review of the preliminary plat, developer shall prepare a landscape plan showing proposed improvement of said landscape area, including berming, type and quantity of planting materials, and other enhancements. Upon completion, said area shall be maintained either by the adjoining homeowner or any homeowners association as may be required. 
  

(Ord. No. 06-1574, § 1, 6-12-06; Ord. No. 07-1746, § 2, 1-23-08) 
Sec. 30-10. - Required land improvements. 
    Before a subdivision shall be approved, the village engineer shall certify that the improvements described in the subdivider's plans and specifications, together with agreements, meet the minimum requirements of all ordinances of the village and that they comply with the following: 
(a)  Monuments and markers. Monuments shall be placed at all corners and angle points of the outside boundary but no further than one-quarter mile apart. The monuments shall be of concrete, not less than six inches in diameter and 36 inches deep, with a center metal dowel rod at least 12 inches long cast in place. Iron pipe or steel bars not less than one-half-inch in diameter and 18 inches long shall be set at the intersection of street centerlines and at all corners of lots not marked by monuments. The monuments and markers shall be set level with the finished grade. 
(b)  Minimum standards for required utilities and street and lot improvements. 
(1)  Public water. Per Illinois EPA, Village, and Aqua Illinois Water Company specifications and connected to the water distribution system of the village. All fire hydrants shall be spaced to provide coverage for all buildings within 300 feet radius of a hydrant. The fire chief of the Bourbonnais fire protection district or his designee may require additional hydrants where deemed necessary. 

Typical Hydrant Installation 
(2)  Public sanitary sewers. Per "Standards for Sewer and Water Main Construction in Illinois", as published by the Illinois EPA (current edition). 
(3)  Primary thoroughfares. Cross sections in accordance with the general development plan and as determined by the village engineer and the plan commission. 
(4)  Secondary thoroughfares. Eighty-foot right-of-way, 40-foot pavements. 
(5)  Streets. In accordance with "Minimum Standards for Street Design" as set forth in this chapter, streets shall be constructed by the developer on all public street right-of-ways as shown on the approved engineering plans and approved preliminary subdivision plat unless otherwise determined by the village plan commission or village engineer. Sidewalks shall be placed along all street right-of-ways and intersect the connecting street curbs with wheelchair ramps to be constructed in accordance with A.D.A. standards. The developer shall be responsible for the construction of all sidewalks that front all public and nonbuildable areas. All sidewalks shall be placed on the dedicated public right-of-way a distance of one foot off of the property line. The back or property line side of the four-foot-wide sidewalk shall be constructed four inches above the back of curb elevation with a slope of one quarter inches per foot toward the street, unless otherwise approved by the village plan commission or the village engineer. The sidewalks, along with the designed grades shall be shown on the approved development plans. The subdivider shall improve any existing platted road adjacent to the proposed subdivision. The road may be under the jurisdiction of the county, township or village. This improvement shall conform to the design specified in this chapter for the type of road specified, as shown in the general development plan. The subdivider will be required to construct these improvements for the half of the road adjacent to the proposed subdivision. The remaining half of the road may be improved by the agency having jurisdiction, or a subdivider adjacent to the road on the opposite side of the road, and these improvements may be constructed at a later date. 
(6)  Street lights. Shall be located at all street intersections and at intervals not to exceed 350 feet throughout the remainder of any subdivision, or as specified by the plan commission and village engineer. Shall be constructed in accordance to current street lighting ordinance. No occupancy permits will be issued for a subdivision until the street lights are activated. 
(7)  Streets along development boundaries, and streets connecting development with existing improved street system. Cross sections as determined by the village engineer and the plan commission. 
(8)  Alleys. Paved per village specifications. 
(9)  Lot and street grading. Per plans and profiles approved by the village engineer. 
(10)  Storm sewer laterals. The storm sewer system shall be constructed in a manner that provides a storm sewer connector to every lot for a sump pump connections. These storm laterals shall not be permitted to drain to the gutter. 
A supplemental storm system with a minimum diameter of eight inches is permissible in rear yards providing no surface drains are installed on the supplemental storm system. 
Storm Sewer Laterals 
(11)  Curb and gutter. 
a.  Portland cement concrete per Illinois Department of Transportation specifications. 
b.  Rolled Portland cement concrete per Illinois Department of Transportation specifications. 
(12)  Pavement base: 
a.  Compacted aggregate base course per "Illinois Department of Transportation Design Standards" for flexible pavements, 20-year design period minimum thickness of ten inches. 
b.  Portland cement concrete per Illinois Department of Transportation design standards for rigid pavement, 20-year design period. 
(13)  Wearing surface. Asphaltic concrete, plant mixed, per Illinois Department of Transportation specifications-Minimum thicknesses shall be one and one-half inches of bituminous concrete binder course and two and one-half inches of bituminous concrete surface course. The final asphalt surface shall not be installed until at least 80 percent of the lots in the phase currently being constructed have been developed, or for a period of at least one year from construction of the roadway, whichever shall occur first. The final asphalt surface shall not be installed until inspected by village engineer and failed bituminous concrete binder course have been repaired by the developer. 
(14)  Driveways. Per village specifications. 
(15)  Sidewalk: 
a.  Residential. Four-inch thick and four-foot wide Portland cement concrete per village specifications. All sidewalks to be installed by property owners at their expense. For property to be dedicated to the village, open areas or other property not to be sold, built upon or further developed where sidewalk would otherwise be required, the developer shall install the sidewalk at his expense. All empty lots shall have a sidewalk installed when sidewalks are installed on both sides of the lot within 12 months of the installation of both adjacent sidewalks. 
b.  Commercial and industrial. Four-inch-thick and five-foot-wide Portland cement concrete per village specifications. All sidewalks to be installed by property owners at their expense. For property to be dedicated to the village, open areas or other property not to be sold, built upon or further developed where sidewalk would otherwise be required, the developer shall install the sidewalk at his expense. All empty lots shall have a sidewalk installed when sidewalks are installed on both sides of the lot within 12 months of the installation of both adjacent sidewalks. 
(16)  Seeding of planting strips in streets. Per village specifications. 
(17)  Street signs. At all intersections per village specifications. Regulatory signing as per village engineer approval. 
(18)  Telephone and electric service. In rear or side lot easements, installed at least 18 inches underground. 
(19)  Gas. In street planting strip, installed at least 18 inches underground. 
(20)  Cable/pay TV. In rear or side lot easements, installed at least six inches underground. 
(21)  Lot grading. Per neighborhood drainage plan. 
    All plans and specifications for utility and street improvements shall be prepared by and certified by an Illinois registered professional engineer. 
    The design of and materials used in the construction of sanitary sewer collection systems, sanitary sewer pumping stations, force mains, appurtenances, and related items of construction shall be in accordance with the standards provided in the applicable sections and paragraphs of the latest edition of the "Standard Specification for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois". 
    The design of and the materials used in the construction of water distribution systems shall be in accordance with the applicable sections and paragraphs of the latest edition of the "Standard Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois" and also in accordance with the standards for design and materials as adopted by Aqua Illinois. 
    The design of and materials used in the construction of streets, storm sewer systems, appurtenances, and related items of construction shall be in conformance with all applicable articles, sections, and paragraphs of the latest edition of the "Standard Specification for Road and Bridge Construction" as adopted by the State of Illinois Department of Transportation, all applicable supplemental specifications, and recurring special provisions. 
(Ord. No. 06-1574, § 1, 6-12-06) 
Sec. 30-11. - Plats and data. 
(a)  Preapplication: sketch plans and data. 
(1)  General subdivision data shall describe or outline the existing conditions of the site and the proposed development as necessary to supplement the drawings required below. This shall include information on existing covenants, existing adjacent zoning, land characteristics, available community facilities, utilities, and information describing the subdivision proposal such as number of residential lots; typical lot width and depth; business areas; school, playground, and park areas; other public areas; proposed protective covenants; proposed utilities; and proposed street improvements. 
(2)  Sketch plan on topographic survey shall show in simple sketch form the proposed layout of streets, lots, and other features in relation to existing conditions. The sketch plan may be a free-hand pencil sketch made directly on a print of the topographic survey. The sketch plan shall include the existing topographic data sufficient to show drainage patterns, any designated wetlands from the National Wetlands Inventory Map, and any designated floodways or floodplains. 
(b)  Preliminary plat and data for conditional approval. 
(1)  Topographic data required as a basis for the preliminary plat shall include existing conditions as follows, except when otherwise specified by the plan commission: 
a.  Boundary lines. Bearings and distances. 
b.  Easements. Location, width, and purpose. 
c.  Streets on and adjacent to the tract. Name and right-of-way width and location; type and width of surfacing; walks, curbs, gutters, culverts, etc. 
d.  Utilities on and adjacent to the tract. Location, size, and invert elevation of sanitary, storm, and combined sewers; location and size of water mains; location of gas lines, fire hydrants, electric and telephone poles, and street lights; if water mains and sewers are not on or adjacent to the tract, indicate the direction and distance to, and the sizes of nearest ones, showing invert elevation of sewers. 
e.  Ground elevations on the tract. Based on the USGS datum plane. For land that slopes less than one-half percent show not less than one-foot contours; for land that slopes one-half to two percent show not less than two-foot contours; and for land that slopes more than two percent to show not less than five-foot contours. 
f.  Subsurface conditions on the tract, if required by the plan commission. Location and results of tests made to ascertain subsurface soil, rock, and ground water conditions; depth to ground water unless test pits are dry at a depth of five feet; written approval from the Kankakee County Health Department if individual sewage disposal systems are proposed and proof that the county health department has approved the individual sewage. 
g.  Other conditions on the tract. Water courses, marshes, rock outcrop, wooded areas, isolated preservable trees one foot or more in diameter, structures and other significant features. 
h.  Other conditions on adjacent land. Approximate direction and gradient of ground slope, including any embankments or retaining walls; character and location of buildings, railroads, power lines, towers, and other nearby nonresidential land uses or adverse influences; and owners of adjacent unplatted land (for adjacent platted land refer to subdivision plat by name, recording date, and number, and show approximate percent built up). 
i.  Photographs, if required by the plan commission. Camera locations, directions of views, and key numbers. 
j.  Zoning. Zoning on and adjacent to the tract. 
k.  Proposed public improvements. Highways or other major improvements planned by public authorities for future construction on or near the tract. 
l.  Key plan. Key plan showing location of the tract. 
m.  Title and certificates. Title under which proposed subdivision is to be recorded, with names and addresses of owners, notation stating acreage, scale, and north arrow. 
n.  National Wetlands Inventory Map. 
o.  Floodplains and/or floodways. 
(2)  Preliminary plat shall be at a scale of 100 feet to one inch or, using two or more sheets as necessary. On all plans, the minimum font size shall not be less than 0.08 point. It shall show all existing conditions required above in "topographic data", and shall show all proposals including the following: 
a.  Streets. Names and right-of-way widths. 
b.  Other right-of-way or easements. Location, width, and purpose. 
c.  Lot, block data. Lot lines, lot dimensions, lot numbers, and block numbers. 
d.  Reserved or dedicated sites. Sites, if any, to be reserved or dedicated for schools, parks, playgrounds, or other public uses. 
e.  Nonpublic uses. Sites, if any, for multifamily dwellings, shopping centers, churches, industry, or other nonpublic uses exclusive of single-family dwellings. 
f.  Proposed setbacks. Proposed building setback lines. 
g.  Site data. Site data, including number of residential lots, typical lot size, acres of parks, etc. 
h.  Name. Proposed name of the subdivision. 
i.  Location. Location by section, township and range. 
j.  Data on developer. Name and address of the developer (and if a land trust, the name and address of all equitable beneficiaries). 
k.  Data on planner; engineer. Name and address of the planner or engineer. 
l.  Title, etc. Title, scale, north point, and date. 
m.  [Plan view of water mains, etc.] Plan view of proposed water mains, sanitary sewer, storm sewers, fire hydrants and street lights. 
n.  [Aggregate grades.] Approximate grades of foundations, storm sewer inlets, and drainage routes. 
o.  [Stormwater detention facilities.] Approximate dimensions and grades of stormwater detention facilities (note if facility is dry bottom, wetland or wet bottom). 
p.  [Curves, etc., on streets.] Approximate radii of all curves, length of tangents, and central angles on all streets. 
q.  [Streets, alleys, etc.] Typical details or cross sections of all streets, alleys, entrances, paths and waterways. 
r.  No access/no fence/landscape easement. 
(3)  The preliminary plat shall be accompanied by the following documents and data: 
a.  Stormwater detention calculations; 
b.  Two standards for street lights: 
1.  Within subdivision limits, set forth in subsection 30-10(6). 
2.  Along major roads, 45 feet with sidewalk lighting. 

Street Light Detail-Concrete Foundation Detail 
c.  Photocopy of FEMA Firm of Flood Boundary Map, Soils Map, USGS Map and Wetlands Map indicating location of proposed subdivision; 
d.  A report, certification, wetland delineation, or other reliable source of information regarding the existence and extent of Wetlands or other Waters of the U.S. on the property; 
e.  Preliminary storm calculations for all waterways with a tributary drainage area of greater than 80 acres. The calculations should indicate existing and proposed conditions of water surface elevations in the event of a 100-year frequency rainfall event; 
f.  Draft of all protective covenants, homeowner association bylaws and other development restrictions. Association bylaws shall provide: 
1.  List and election of officers; 
2.  Timetable for transfer of control from developer to association; 
3.  Description of all areas to be conveyed to association for ownership and maintenance including, but not limited to, parks, stormwater management areas, landscape buffers and easements, and other common areas; 
4.  Amount of initial monthly or annual assessments to be charged; 
5.  Manner in which association has ability to command payment of fees and enforcement of same. 
(4)  Draft of protective covenants, whereby the applicant proposes to regulate land use in the subdivision and otherwise protect the proposed development. 
(c)  Final plat and data for final approval. 
(1)  The final plat shall be drawn in ink on velum or mylar on sheets not to exceed 29 inches wide by 36 inches long and shall be at a scale of 100 feet to one inch. Where necessary, the plat may be on several sheets accompanied by an index sheet showing the entire subdivision. For large subdivisions the final plat may be submitted for approval progressively in contiguous sections satisfactory to the plan commission. The final plat shall show the following: 
a.  Dimensions, angles, bearings, and similar data shall be shown on the plat to tie all primary control points to the subdivision. 
b.  Tract boundary lines, right-of-way lines of streets, easements, and other right-of-way, and property lines of residential lots and other sites, with accurate dimensions, bearings, or deflection angles, and radii, arcs, and central angles of all curves. 
c.  Names and right-of-way width of each street or other right-of-way. 
d.  Location, dimensions, and purpose of any easement. 
e.  Number to identify each lot or site and block. 
f.  Purpose for which sites, other than residential lots, are dedicated or reserved. 
g.  Proposed building setback line on all lots and other sites. 
h.  Location and description of monuments. 
i.  Certification by surveyor certifying to accuracy of survey and plat. 
j.  Certification of title showing that applicant is landowner. 
k.  Statement by owner dedicating street, right-of-ways, and any sites for public uses pursuant to state law. 
l.  Certification of approval by the plan commission. 
m.  Name of subdivision. 
n.  Location by section, township and range. 
o.  Title, scale, north arrow and date. 
(2)  As-built engineering plans for all subdivision improvements if the improvements are completed at the time of final plat approval. In the event that any subdivision improvements are not completed at the time of final plat approval, such as-built plans shall be provided to the village at the time of the completion of the improvement and prior to the release of the bond or security posted by the developer. The profiles shall be drawn to village standard scales and elevations and shall be based on USGS datum plane. 
(3)  A notice from the village board stating that there has been filed with and approved by the board, one of the following: 
a.  A certificate by the village engineer that all improvements and installations to the subdivision required for its approval have been made or installed in accordance with the specifications; or 
b.  A bond has been posted pursuant to subsection 30-7(c)(4)b. in sufficient amount to assure completion of all required improvements. 
(4)  Protective covenants in form for recording. 
(5)  Such other certificates, affidavits, endorsements, or dedications as may be required by the plan commission in the enforcement of these regulations. 
(Ord. No. 06-1574, § 1, 6-12-06) 
Sec. 30-12. - Variances. 
    Where the plan commission finds that extraordinary hardships may result from strict compliance with these regulations, it may vary enforcement of the regulations so that substantial justice may be done and the public interest secured, provided such variation will not have the effect of nullifying the intent and purpose of the official comprehensive plan of the village or these regulations. 
(Ord. No. 06-1574, § 1, 6-12-06) 
Sec. 30-13. - Recapture. 
    Whenever the village: 
(1)  Requests or requires the installation of sanitary sewers, storm sewers, drains, streets, curbs, sidewalks, or similar improvements or other similar improvements and appurtenant facilities as a condition precedent to the acceptance of a final plat of subdivision, or the approval of an application for a special permit or variation; and 
(2)  Determines that, in the opinion of the board of trustees of the village, such facilities may be used for the benefits of property not in the subdivision or in the development for which the special permit or variation has been granted, and the sanitary sewer, drain, streets, curbs, sidewalks or similar improvements are to be dedicated to the public; 
    The board of trustees may adopt an ordinance providing for the recapture of a portion of the cost of such facilities from fees charged to the owners of the property not within such subdivision nor within the property which is the subject of such special permit or variation, when and as collected from the owners thereof. 
(Ord. No. 06-1574, § 1, 6-12-06) 
Sec. 30-14. - Fees and costs/inspection at subdivider's expense. 
(a)  Observation. The village engineer shall periodically observe all public improvements proposed to be made under the provisions of this chapter or a duly designated deputy as set forth in subsection 30-7(e)(3). All fees and costs connected with such observation and with reviewing the sketches, plats, plans, and specifications for such improvements shall be paid by the subdivider/developer as set forth in subsection 30-7(a)(1). 
All costs incurred by the village for review of agreements, sketches, plats, plans, and specifications, observation of construction improvements, as may be required, and any costs as incurred by the village engineer, village attorney, and other individuals, as may be needed, shall be paid by the subdivider/developer. 
(b)  [Payment required.] No preliminary plat or final plat shall be forwarded to the planning commission for review without this fee having first been paid. Payment of the fee is in no way contingent on whether the plat of development or subdivision submitted is approved or disapproved. In addition, the applicant shall submit, as part of their application, evidence of title or other information demonstrating that they have a valid contract or option to purchase the land for which the application is made, or is the owner of record for that land. 
(c)  Timetable for fee payment. 
(1)  Preliminary plat. The application for approval of the preliminary plat shall be accompanied by a certified check or money order payable to the village in the amount of $1,000.00 plus $25.00 for each lot in the proposed subdivision or $250.00 for minor subdivision or lot consolidations to cover the administrative cost of checking and verifying the proposed plat. Upon the acceptance of the application by the plan commission, the secretary shall surrender the check or money order to the village treasurer for deposit in the general fund of the village. 
(2)  Final plat. The application for approval of the final plat shall be accompanied by a certified check or money order payable to the village in the amount of $250.00 to cover the administrative cost of checking and verifying the proposed plat and collecting data for the village's geographic information system. Upon the acceptance of the application by the plan commission, the secretary shall surrender the check or money order to the village treasurer for deposit in the general fund of the village. 
(Ord. No. 06-1574, § 1, 6-12-06) 
Sec. 30-15. - Certification of plats. 
    When the village board shall, upon motion and majority vote, approve the final plat, the president and village clerk shall be authorized to sign the original tracing. The certificates on the final plat shall be in the following form, with the signatures of the chairman of the Kankakee County Board, the township highway commissioner, the county engineer, the chairman of the county planning and zoning committee, and the county clerk to be necessary only where the plat covers land in the unincorporated areas. 
    The following certificates shall appear on all final plats: 
Ownership certificate

    A perpetual easement is hereby granted to the Village of Bourbonnais, Municipal Corporation of Illinois, its successors and assigns, for the full and free right and authority to install, construct, and otherwise establish, relocate, remove, renew, replace, operate, inspect, repair, and maintain water mains, fire hydrants valves, and water service facilities, sanitary sewer pipes, manholes, and sewer connections, storm sewer pipes, manholes, inlets, stormwater detention facilities, stormwater conveyance paths and storm sewer services connections, electric transmission and distribution wires and cables, community antenna television systems, and such other appurtenances and facilities as may be necessary or conveniently related to said water mains, sanitary sewer pipes, storm sewer pipes, stormwater detention, stormwater conveyance paths, electric transmission and distribution wires and cables, community antenna television system, in, on, upon, over, through, across, and under all of that real estate hereon described and designated as within public utility and drainage easements, said easements being designated by the dashed lines and designations of width. 
UTILITY EASEMENT 
    An easement is hereby reserved for the public for Public Utility Service, as shown by the dotted lines on this plat, for overhead or underground for the purpose of serving the subdivision and adjoining property and the right to use the highway where necessary including the right and authority to cross any lots in said subdivision with aerial service to provide utility service, to trim and keep trimmed any trees that interfere with said public utility equipment; but same to be used for gardens, shrubs, landscaping, and other purposes that do not interfere with the use of said easement. 
GRANT OF INGRESS/EGRESS EASEMENT 
    An easement is hereby given, granted to and conveyed to the Village of Bourbonnais, Illinois, a Municipal Corporation (hereinafter referred to as the "Village" or "GRANTEE") for a permanent and perpetual non-exclusive ingress and egress easement to include, but not be limited to, the right to construct, install, repair, maintain, alter, and operate a street, road, or path and appurtenances thereto, privilege, right and authority to do and erect, construct, install and/or lay, and thereafter use, operate, inspect, repair, maintain, replace and remove upon, over, and through the land of the GRANTOR, situated in Kankakee County, State of Illinois, said land being set forth and shown in this plat as " ____________ ' INGRESS & EGRESS EASEMENT", together with the rights of ingress and egress over the adjacent lands of the GRANTOR, its heirs, successors and assigns, in perpetuity, for the purposes of this easement. 
    The GRANTOR shall retain all rights not herein granted, to the ownership, use and occupation of the above described easement areas, except that the GRANTOR shall place no obstruction of any kind, permanent or temporary including, but not limited to, fill, permanent buildings and structures, nor deny GRANTEE access thereto for purposes of use, maintenance, repair, improvement or replacement thereof. 
    The GRANTOR, its successors, heirs and assigns shall be responsible for mowing and maintenance of the easement area. 
    This grant shall constitute a covenant which runs with the land and shall be binding upon the heirs, executors, administrators, successors and assigns of the parties, and the terms and conditions hereinabove set forth shall be binding upon the GRANTORS. 
    The GRANTOR represents and warrants to the Village that GRANTOR is the true and lawful Owner of the Subject Property and has full rights and powers to grant and convey the rights conveyed herein. 
    This grant shall be assignable by the Village, in whole or in part, without consent of GRANTOR. 
    The placement of any landscaping not in compliance with the neighborhood drainage plan for a given property, or any accessory building or structure, swimming pool, fence, or any other improvement which in any way could cause an impediment to the overland flow of stormwater within said drainage easement is hereby prohibited. 
    That if any item or part of the foregoing ordinance shall, for any reason, be deemed invalid, it shall not be held to affect the validity of any other item or items or parts of this Ordinance which would otherwise be valid. 
    That this Ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and after its passage and publication in pamphlet form as required by law.
