NATURALIZED DETENTION BASINS 
Utilizing Native Plants 
QUALITY CONTROL PROGRAM 
(DRAFT) 
I.  INSTALLATION SPECIFICATIONS/PERFORMANCE STANDARDS 
Contractor qualifications. Contractor(s) must possess a minimum of five years experience with native prairie and wetland seed installation. Proof of successful completion of a minimum of five native wetland and prairie installation projects within the last three years with a scope that is equal or greater in complexity as the project. Each of the five projects must involve a minimum of three acres or greater of native prairie and/or wetland seed installation and 3,000 or greater live native plugs. Accompanying references are required to be submitted with the pre-qualification information. 
Installation Performance Standards Completion Schedule: 
Work Component Start Date Completion Date Preplant preparation (herbicide, mowing, raking) April 15 May 1 Native seed installation (no earlier than one week postherbicide application) May 1 June 15 Live plug installation May 1 July 1 Erosion control blanket installation May 1 June 15  
Top soil installation/preparation (requirement for excavation/mass grading contractor). This work shall consist of the furnishing and replacing of 12 inches of topsoil in the areas proposed for planting under this contract. 
At least 12 inches of topsoil shall be placed over all disturbed areas, except areas below the safety ledge of the proposed basin and areas designated for hardscape preparation. Provide a natural friable topsoil of the region, rich in organic matter, without any material toxic to plant growth and of uniform quality, free of large roots, sticks, hard clay, weeds, brush, stones over one inch in maximum dimension or other litter or waste products. Provide topsoil containing no decomposed stone, salts or alkali, and not less than 15 parts per million of available nitrates, three parts per million of available phosphorus, 15 parts per million of potash, and having a pH of not less than 6.0 nor more than 7.2 at a depth of eight inches below the surface of the field from which it is removed. Provide topsoil with a mechanical analysis as follows: 
Sieve Percentage Passing 1 inch 100 1/4-inch 97-100 No. 100 40-60  
The topsoil shall be incorporated into the subsoil by placing half of the depth, discing it in, and placing the remaining depth of soil. A soil ripping/decompaction process shall be utilized to achieve the acceptable soil compaction parameters. Soil compaction shall be measured with a penetrometer to a depth of 12 inches. 
One measurement shall be made for every 400 square feet. If readings average greater than 250 psi, then the soil shall be ripped again to a depth of 12 feet using methods approved by the site supervisor. All disturbed areas shall be covered with the required topsoil and meet the maximum compaction criteria prior to completion of the mass excavation. 
Seed stock requirement. 
Quality. All seed installed must meet a minimum of 75 percent PLS (pure live seed) per species as verified by independent laboratory test results. Test results can be no more than 12 months old. Contractor must provide verification of test results prior to install. 
Seed source. All seed must be from a verifiable source within a 150-mile radius of the project. Contractor must provide verification of seed source prior to install. 
Seeding installations with associated performance standards will include the following: 
Prescribed seed and plug installation. This work shall consist of delivery and professional installation of preapproved and designer-prescribed seeding schedules as indicated on the plans. 
Low-maintenance fescue. Plan specified area denoted as "low profile fescue" shall be finished, groomed and raked prior to seed installation so as to provide a smooth, even finish grade free from debris or irregularities. All standing vegetation shall be 100 percent killed (by aerial cover quantified by visual observation of dead or dying plant cover) via Round-Up(r) application a minimum of one week prior to installation. 
Contractor is responsible to prevent "drift" or overspray into neighboring areas not denoted as "low profile fescue" on specified plans. Prescribed seed mix shall be installed according to seed installation noted in plan. Contractor shall guarantee 80 percent aerial coverage of prescribed temporary seed crop and 20 percent aerial coverage of "native permanent" seeded species by the end of the first growing season (October 15). 
Contractor shall guarantee 45 percent aerial coverage of native "permanent" seeded species with 100 percent representation of all prescribed species by the end of the second growing season (October 15). 
Basic tall grass prairie, low profile prairie, or wet-mesic prairie. Plan specified areas, denoted as "basic tall grass prairie, low profile prairie, or wet-mesic prairie," shall be finished graded and groomed prior to seed installation. Standing vegetation shall be 100 percent killed (by aerial cover quantified by visual observation of dead or dying plant cover) via Round-Up(r) application a minimum of one week prior to installation. Contractor is responsible to prevent drift overspray into non-designated areas. Prescribed seed mix shall be installed according to seed installation notes provided in plan. 
Contractor is responsible to prevent "drift" or overspray into neighboring areas not denoted as "low profile fescue" on specified plans. Prescribed seed mix shall be installed according to seed installation noted in plan. Contractor shall guarantee 80 percent aerial coverage of prescribed temporary seed crop and 20 percent aerial coverage of "native permanent" seeded species by the end of the first growing season (October 15). 
Contractor shall guarantee 45 percent aerial coverage of native "permanent" seeded species with 100 percent representation of all prescribed species by the end of the second growing season (October 15). 
Plug installations (pond emergent, wet-mesic prairie). This work shall include deliver and installation of plan specified plant plugs within areas denoted on the owner's planting plan. Areas designated for plug planting shall be 100 percent killed (by aerial coverage quantified by visual observation) via Rodeo(r) application a minimum of one week prior to planting. All debris shall be removed prior to planting including woody debris floating at the pond edges. 
Plant plugs shall bear live, healthy, above-surface growth consisting of true leaves, not seed leaves, upon delivery. Plug containers or tray compartments shall be a minimum of two and one-quarter inch wide and four-and-one-half-inch depth with a healthy, disease-free root stock. 
Installation of plugs in "planting pods" or appropriate zones based on species will be coordinated in the field with owner's designer. Contractor is responsible and will provide for goose exclusion to prevent waterfowl herbivory of installed plugs. The owner will approve the method chosen by the contractor. 
Contractor shall guarantee 70 percent survival (by number) of all planted plugs with 100 percent representation of all prescribed species (by number) by the end of the first year following installation (July 1, 2002). 
II.  Three-year maintenance plan. The objective of this management plan is to provide requirements for maintenance activities for the various native landscaping areas installed around and within the pond during the initial three years following installation. Once this three-year mark has been reached and all plant assemblages have developed satisfactorily, a permanent site-specific maintenance plan will be developed. 
Low-maintenance fescue. 
 All fescue areas shall be inspected and policed for litter and debris prior to each mowing. 
 Mowing should occur approximately once a month to a height of four to six inches. Care should be taken to never remove more than one-third of the top growth. Fescue grasses will often produce seed-heads in mid to late spring. To maintain a more manicured lawn-like appearance, mow at four inches when seed-heads appear. 
 Fertilizer is not recommended for this turf, and should be applied sparingly if used at all. 
 Once established, water only during dry periods. Occasional, thorough soakings are preferred over frequent light sprinklings. 
 All sidewalks, curb lines, concrete slabs and planting bed edges shall be mechanically edged as needed to maintain a neat, clean appearance (approximately twice per month). Low visibility areas such as road shoulders, outlying tree circles, bed edges, etc., may be chemically contained, but at no time will there be more than one-half inch of visual desiccated plant growth along the contained areas. 
 Trimming shall be performed around all road signs, guard posts, trees, shrubs, utility poles and other obstacles paying special care to not damage trees and shrubs. The grass to be trimmed shall not be trimmed to less than the desired height of cut determined by the mowing operation. 
Natural areas maintenance. Maintenance for the prairie and emergent wetland areas will be the same for the first three years, due to the fact that all of these areas have closely related plant assemblages and will all consistently in the same stage of development as one another. For prevention and control of particular non-native species, please refer to the attached Vegetation Management Guidelines (appendix A). These guidelines detail appropriate methods of control for many of the most common offensive species. 
Maintenance for these three areas will be as follows: 
Year 1 (same year as initial installation). 
Spot herbicide control. Trained applicators shall police entire site to identify and control aggressive non-native and invasive species. Applications will be as needed and should be according to recommendations found in the attached vegetation control guidelines. 
Site mowing. Bushog-style mower should be used to mow all accessible areas to a height of six inches to prevent encroachment of woody species. Areas too wet for mechanical equipment to access will be avoided. Two mowing events should occur each year; one in late May/early June and one in early November. 
Year 2. 
Spot herbicide control. Same as Year 1. 
Site mowing. Initial site mowing should be completed in late May/early June. If sufficient fuel load has developed to conduct a fall prescribed burn, then burning should take place in lieu of the November mowing event. If sufficient fuel load does not exist, then site should be mowed a second time in November. 
Enhancement plantings. Installation of supplemental live plugs will occur in June. Planting will be performed by qualified contractors as defined under specifications. 
Possible supplemental reseeding. By late in the growing season of Year 1, an accurate assessment of the success of the initial native seeding will be possible. If the plant communities are not developing to a level commensurate with the expectations of both the owner and their restoration consultant, re-seeding will be required. The species to be reseeded will either be identical to the original species list or will be selected by a qualified restoration consultant for suitability to the most current site conditions. 
Possible prescribed burning. If sufficient fuel load has developed, the owner shall enlist the services of a trained and experienced prescribed burn contractor to perform a prescribed burn of the prairie and wetland areas of the site. If weather conditions allow, burning should take place in mid- to late November. If weather conditions prevent this from occurring, the burn shall take place in spring of Year 3. 
Year 3. 
Spot herbicide control. Same as Year 1. 
Mowing or prescribed burning. Same as Year 2. 
After three years of establishment, it is expected that the only activity required for prolonged health of the natural areas of the site will be prescribed burning or annual mowing in the fall. Prescribed burning is the ideal management technique for long-term prairie and wetland health, and will be the only form of action required on three- to five-year intervals to maintain these areas indefinitely. 
The following species are the most likely to invade native establishment areas on the site and should be monitored. Should any of these appear on the site, appropriate control activities should be engaged as described in appendix A (Vegetation Management Guidelines). 
Prairie Habitats Common burdock (Arctium minus) Smooth brome (Bromus inermis) Canada thistle (Cirsium arvense) Common teasel (Dipsacus sylvestrii) Tall sweet clover (Melilotus alba) Kentucky blue grass (Poa pratensis) Multiflora rose (Rosa multiflora) Wet-Mesic and Emergent Habitats Canada thistle (Cirsium arvense) Purple loosestrife (Lythrum salicaria) Reed canary grass (Phalaris arundinacea) Common reed (Phragmites australis) Eastern cottonwood (tree) (Populus deltoides) Willow (shrub) (Salix spp.) Cattail (Typha spp.)  
Emergent habitats continued. Based upon observations of similar detention basin plantings during the first season following installation, it is anticipated that plant survival and shoreline colonization of pond and stream emergent species will be highly successful. When provided with proper hydrology and substrate conditions, these plantings require virtually no maintenance activities. The most critical recommended action is to control aggressive cattails, which commonly invade the site immediately following initial planting. Cattail removal should occur according to the following procedure: 
 The cattail stand shall be first treated in mid- to late May. All cattails shall be cut low to the ground. A systemic herbicide shall be applied to the cut cattail stumps with a wicking applicator. 
 For each 1,000 ft 2 of cattail stand surface area treated, the recommended herbicide and application rate is four and one-half Tbsp. (2.25 fl. oz.) aquatic glyphosate (RODEO) and 3 Tbsp. nonionic surfactant (X-77 or equivalent) in two and one-fourth gallons of water. 
 If standing water is present, cattails shall be cut as low as possible below the water line to attempt to kill the plant by suffocation. Herbicide shall not be applied to plants that are cut below the water line. Cattail plants shall not be allowed to progress beyond the early flowering stage. 
 Cattail stand maintenance shall continue through the first growing season, as deemed necessary by the wetland consultant, depending on the regrowth of the removed specimens. 
This activity is will need to be performed most heavily in the first year. Some light treatment may be required during the Year 2. It is anticipated that following the Year 2 season, the native plant communities installed in these areas will have developed sufficient densities to out-compete cattails attempting to become established. If necessary, the Year 2 treatment will consist of wick application of standing cattails during early summer utilizing the same Glyphosate mix described above. 
III.  Three-year monitoring/success criteria 
Year 1. Owner shall guarantee an average 80 percent aerial coverage of prescribed temporary seed crop and average 20 percent aerial coverage of "native permanent" seeded and plugged species by the end of the first growing season within all native planting zones. 
Year 2. Owner shall guarantee an average 45 percent aerial coverage of native "permanent" seeded and plugged species with 90 percent (by number) representation of prescribed species by the end of the second growing season. 
Year 3. Owner shall guarantee an average 80 percent aerial coverage of noninvasive native species throughout all native planting zones with 90 percent (by number) representation of all prescribed species by the end of the third growing season. Not more than an average ten percent aerial coverage may consist of exotic/invasive species listed in appendix A.

Vegetation Management Guideline 
Control Techniques 
Scientific Name Common Name Burn Mechanical Chemical Biological Recommendations Alliaria petiolata Garlic mustard Intense and thorough fall or spring burns. Cut flowering stems at ground level and remove. If done in full flower, plants will not resprout. Otherwise, pull entire plants, including roots, and remove from site. Glyphosate treatment in dormant season (spring or fall). Triclopyr (Garlon 3A) and clopyralid are selective broadleaf herbicides, which can be used during the dormant season to control basal rosettes, during late fall or early spring (to avoid nontargets). Possible fungal pathogens such as Fusarium solani may be possible in the near future. Hoffman and Kearns suggested possible use by 2005. Site specific, though a combination of hand-cutting, pulling, intense burning, and herbicide treatment for several years will probably be needed. Management should be continued until seed bank is exhausted. Arctium minus Common burdock Annual burn regime. A biennial weed that can be cut/removed after flowering. Hand pull 1st-yr plants, getting roots. Triclopyr (Garlon 3A) and clopyralid are selective broadleaf herbicides that can be used during the dormant season to control basal rosettes (late fall or early spring). Spot apply glyphosate, avoiding nontargets. Early fall and/or late spring burn, followed with selective herbicide treatment. Hand-pull when applicable. Bromus inermis Smooth brome Late spring burn, repeated annually or biennially. Need fire-adapted seed bank to compete to out-compete brome. Fire is ineffective when brome is dormant. If applicable, dig up clumps by hand. Mowing is not recommended. Black plastic is also an option. Glyphosate treatment in early spring/late fall when natives are dormant. Or, apply Fusilade 2000 (selective grass herbicide) following spring burn. Eliminate seed source from entering into project site. A combination of late spring burns, followed up with a selective glyphosate treatment before natives emerge. Plants supposedly have alleopathic tendencies, so hate it. Centaurea maculosa Spotted knapweed High intensity burn. WI DNR stated that a "hot" burn reduces population anywhere from 5-90%. Repeat annually, reseeding with native competition. Small infestations can be removed by digging or pulling. This is best done where the soil is moist, removing entire root. Mowing has not proven effective, plants simply flower at a lower height. Mowing just after flowering but prior to seed maturation is optional for areas with little other vegetation. Foliar triclopyr (3%) in water-soluble formulation. Picloram at 0.25-0.5 lbs/ac applied in spring or fall for best results (takes 2-3 yrs). Dicamba at 1-2 lbs/ac, applied annually for at least 2 yrs. Clopyralid at .25 lbs/ac and/or clopyralid at .19 lbs/ac + 2,4-D at 1 lb. (WIDNR) "Several biological controls exist, including two root mining months, a flower moth, and a root mining beetle. Most promising are the two seed-head attacking flies Urophora affinis and U. quadrifasciata. Congruently, these two gall flies have reduced seed production 95% in experimental populations." (WINDR) Consult USDA for details. Detect early and remove pioneering plants. A combination of herbicide treatment, used in conjunction with an intense fire regime. Cirsium arvense Canada thistle Perform late spring burn. Early spring burns will increase sprouting and reproduction. May burns will show increase in thistle 1st yr, though 2nd-yr abundance should be lowered. Immediate reductions occur following June burns. Repeated mowing, cutting, pulling (3 per yr)-July, Aug., Sept. recommended, or at 21-day intervals for 3-4 years. When plants are in full bloom, cut close to ground and remove. Low viability when cut after flowering. Done on a regular basis, mowing can prevent seed set while also stressing the plant. Ideal herbicide treatment is when plants area 6-10" tall, glyphosate or clopyralid (selective broadleaf herbicide) at recommended rates. Fall or spring applications evoke best translocation, as do younger plants. Avoid nontargets by using spot application and/or wicking method. Addition of a nitrogen fertilizer and/or plant growth regulators (i.e. morphactins) are also highly recommended. 2,4-D, glyphosate, alyphosphate, and picloram have high ratings of effectiveness. Thistle is most sensitive to 2,4-D at bud stage. Burn late spring or early fall Dactylis glomerata Orchard grass Late spring burn, repeated annually or biennially. Need fire-adapted seed bank to compete to out-compete orchard grass. Fire is ineffective when brome is dormant. If applicable, dig up clumps by hand. Mowing is not recommended. Black plastic is also an option. Glyphosate treatment in early spring/late fall when native plants are dormant. Or, apply Fusilade 2000 (selective grass herbicide) following spring burn. Eliminate seed source from entering into project site. A combination of late spring burns, followed up with a selective glyphosate treatment before natives emerge. Dioscorea oppositifolia Chinese yam Cut-stem treatment using glyphosate (and/or triclopyr?) Trial by error. Little is known about this plant. Dipsacus sylvestris Common teasel Late spring burn for sparse populations. Hand dig rosettes with dandelion digger, getting entire root. If in flowering stage, cut and remove plants. Seeds will continue to develop and mature even after cutting. Spot apply or wick with triclopyr, clopyralid, 2,4-D amine, and/or glyphosate. Triclopyr and clopyralid are both selective broadleaf herbicide. Treat basal rosettes in early spring or late fall to avoid impact on desirable plants. N/A Chemically treat basal rosettes in early spring or late fall, used in conjunction with a burning regime. Cut-remove flowering plants if infestations are low. Euphorbia esula Leafy spurge Not effective. If hand-pulling, digging, or tilling, remove all roots. Picloram, said to be the most effective, should be applied in late spring and early fall annually (not recommended in high quality areas). Fosamine (Krenite) applied in June and July (when blooming) may also prove effective. Glyphosate and dicamba are other alternatives. Several agents (flies, beetles, fungus, etc...) are being investigated as means of biological control. Goats. Black walnuts have allelopathic effects on plants growth. Picloram readily moves through the soil. Caution should be used when applying due to its high level of soil activity and 4-yr residual. An aggressive, long term approach is needed to exhaust seed bank. Festuca elation Tall fescue Late spring burn, repeated annually or biennially. Need fire-adapted seed bank to out-compete fescue. Fire is ineffective when brome is dormant. If applicable, dig up clumps by hand. Mowing is not recommended. Black plastic is also an option. Glyphosate treatment in early spring/late fall when native are dormant. Or, apply Fusilade 2000 (selective grass herbicide) following spring burn. Eliminate seed source from entering into project site. A combination of late spring burns, followed up with a selective glyphosate treatment before natives emerge. Lonicera tatarica 
Lonicera morrowii 
Lonicera x bella 
Lonicera japonica 
Lonicera maackii Honeysuckle In fire-adapted communities, spring burns, repeated annually or biennially for 5+ years. Burning, overall, will aid in native vegetation establishment, thus increasing competition with honeysuckle. Head-fires recommended. Hand pull younger plants, removing all roots (avoid sensitive areas to lessen reinvasion). Repeated mowing, once in July and once in Sept. recommended. Cut-stump treatment, using either glyphosate (20-50%) or triclopyr. Avoid triclopyr application if rain is in forecast for the following 1-4 days. For best results, treat in late summer, fall, or dormant season. Follow up to control resprouts. Foliar glyphosate in June, just after flowers bloom. Apply fosamine (Krenite) as foliar spray. Resprouting has been documented using cut-stem treatment with tricloyr. Cattle can help control it, though not destroy it. Late fall or winter grazing is best. The European honeysuckle aphid "somewhat" inhibits flower/fruit production, though native ladybug beetles control these aphids. Site specific. A combination of annual spring burns, in conjunction with either mowing/cutting, and/or cut-stump treatment. Seedlings can be treated with a foliar spray. Use glyphosate in early spring or late summer (be selective) or fosamine in August. Lotus corniculatus Bird's foot trefoil ? ? Difficult plant to treat. Foliar treatment of glyphosate in non-sensitive areas. Clopyralid, a selective broadleaf herbicide, may also be used according to label instructions. Cut-stem treatment is an option with low frequency. Lythrum salicaria Purple loosestrife Burn removed plants. If late in flowering stage, spray, and then cut, bag, and remove inflorescence. In low infestation, hand-pull or dig and remove (burn if possible). Another method involves cutting plant and removing it, and then flooding the site. Garlon 3A (foliar triclopyr) or Roundup if water is not present, and/or glyphosate (Rodeo + surface tant + AMS) when water is present. Apply at onset of inflorescence (when flowering 1st begins) using label instructions. Retreat later in summer, following annually for complete control. Avoid over-spray. Complete coverage not necessary for control. Cut-stem treatment can also be used for selective purposes. Galerucella calariensis, G., pusilla (leaf-eating beetles), Hylobius transversovittatus (root-mining weevil), and Nanophyes marmoratus (weevil). For large infestations, peripherally treat infestation, working towards center. This involves long-term management until seed bank is exhausted and native plants are re-established. Treating twice annual for multiple years is highly recommended. Use biological control only specificity of natural area. Melilotus spp Sweet clover Need 2 or more consecutive years of burning. Only 1 year will increase populations. Recommend April burn, followed the next year by May burn. Burns should be hot and complete. Hand-pull in late fall after the 1st-year root-crowns have developed, or in early spring of second year. It helps when ground is moist, removing most of the tap root. Cutting is also effective when done after the lower leaves have died back or at early stages of flowering-before seed set. Glyphosate treatment, though care should be taken to avoid non-targets. A triclopyr application can also be used, a selective broadleaf herbicide. Mecamine at 1% can also be used. A native sweet-clover weevil has been noted in helping to control both yellow and white sweet clover. However, it has been stated that the weevil needs to be in high concentrations to be effective, and is therefore not a reliable form of control. Site specific. 
(1) Combination of cutting and pulling. Follow with late spring burn, followed up with hand-pulling. 
(2) April burn, mow 1st-yr plants in Aug., and burn again in Sept. 
(3) For large populations, burn and hand spray plants (most effective in cotyledon stage). 
(4) Burn April 1st yr and then burn May 2d yr. Myriophyllum spicatum Eurasian water milfoil N/A Mechanical cutters and harvesters are relatively common. Hand cutters work best inshore, used in conjunction with hand pulling. Another option would be to use a diver-operated suction dredge. For colonies under .75 ac or <100 plants, hand pulling may be a viable option. Herbicide treatment is not readily recommended, though 2,4-D, Sonar, and Aquathol have proven effective in milfoil control. If chemicals are to be used, 2,4-D is recommended because of its broadleaf specificity and a high level aquatic monocotism. Eurhychiopsis lecontei, an herbivorous weevil native to North America has been documented to control the exotic milfoil. The fungi Mycoleptidiscus terrestris is also under research. Grass carp have also been introduced, but are not recommended due to environmental implications. If performing mechanical control, care should be taken to avoid fragmentation. Hand pulling is preferred because of selectivity and effectiveness, though is restricted to small populations. 
Eurhychiopsis lecontei, the milfoil weevil. Eurasian water milfoil supposedly lacks a defensive compound that native milfoils evolved, and has proven effective. EnviroScience, Inc., has patented a product called Middfoil, using such biological control. Phalaris arundinacea Reed canary grass Late spring burn to inhibit spread, repeated annually for 5-6 years. Need available native seed source to compete. In small stands, hand-pulling or digging. To control seed production, mow in early to mid-June and early October before seed matures. Disking/plowing may also be used in heavy infestations. Hand-chopping the culms at flowering time may also be used to increase mortality potential. Early spring glyphosate application. Apply before native emergence. If water is present Rodeo + recommended surfactant. N/A Site specific. 
(1) With pure stand of canary grass, burn late spring to remove thatch. Apply glyphosate at 1st emergence. Follow-up treatments will be necessary until seedbank is exhausted. 
(2) Use combination of burning, herbicide, and seed elimination strategies. 
*Increase native plant potential for competition. Phragmites australis Common reed grass Burning in combination with herbicide application. Herbicide can be applied by backpack spraying, hand wicking, or tractor wicking (JFN). N/A *Eliminate land disturbances that favors Phragmites development. Chapter 31 - SWIMMING POOLS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Building regulations, Ch. 7; plumbing, Ch. 26. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate swimming pools, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 11-30-9; state regulation of public swimming pools, Ch. 1111/2, § 1201 et seq. 

Sec. 31-1. - Compliance required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain on any property within the boundaries of the village a swimming pool for public or private use without complying with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1973, § 241/2-1) 
Sec. 31-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases when used in this chapter shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section: 
    Fence. Any structure of wood, metal or other material constituting a permanent obstruction to the free access to a swimming pool. 
    Swimming pool. Any structure, apparatus, or excavation of a depth of more than two feet. 
(Code 1973, § 241/2-2) 
Sec. 31-3. - Fencing required. 
(a)  Permanent fence. Every swimming pool shall be protected by a fence enclosure as required for residential use, with a height of not less than 48 inches, nor more than six feet and shall be equipped with a self closing gate and a latch. 
(b)  Temporary fence. Upon excavation of any area with a depth of more than 18 inches, and prior to the placement of a permanent fence as noted above, the contractor and/or property owner shall cause to be installed a temporary construction fence, as approved by the building inspector. Said temporary fence shall have a height of 48 inches, and shall extend around the full perimeter of the excavated site. 
(Code 1973, § 241/2-3; Ord. No. 80-435, 10-27-80; Ord. No. 05-1533, § 6, 11-21-05) 
Sec. 31-4. - Electrical requirements. 
    The following electrical requirements shall apply to swimming pools: 
(1)  No aerial conductors shall extend over or be installed in the immediate vicinity of a swimming pool. There shall be a horizontal clearance of 15 feet from pool to aerial conductors. 
(2)  Galvanized rigid conduit shall extend from a pool outlet box and shall be pitched down to provide drainage. 
(3)  Outlet boxes shall be cast type with threaded hubs. 
(4)  Threaded connections shall be made at boxes and/or couplings. Pressure connectors are not acceptable. 
(5)  Conductors shall be approved for wet locations. 
(6)  Fixtures shall be Underwriters' Laboratory approved for submersible use when installed within the pool. 
(7)  Fixtures shall be approved for wet locations when installed closely adjacent to the pool. 
(8)  Each fixture shall be grounded by means of a groundfall interrupter (GFI) [ground fault circuit interrupter (GFCI)] or a grounding conductor which shall extend from the source (cutout cabinet or distribution cabinet) to each fixture. All rails and diving boards shall be grounded. 
(9)  Submersible lighting for swimming pools, reflector pools and display fountains: 
a.  The voltage shall not exceed 12 volts. 
b.  Step down transformers shall be used in conjunction with the lighting and shall be remotely located from the units they supply. Overcurrent protection shall be provided for both the primary and secondary windings. 
c.  A main disconnect shall be installed on the primary feed to the transformer, also the transformer shall be properly grounded. 
(Code 1973, § 241/2-6; Ord. No. 05-1533, § 6, 11-21-05) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 05-1533, § 7, adopted Nov. 21, 2005, deleted §§ 31-4 and 31-5, and renumbered former §§ 31-6-31-8 as 31-4-36 as herein set out. Section 31-4 pertained to location permit required and derived from Code 1973, § 241/2-4. Section 31-5 pertained to location permit fee and derived from Code 1973, § 241/2-5. 
Cross reference- Electrical regulations generally, Ch. 9. 
Sec. 31-5. - Liability of agent or tenant for violation. 
    Any person in possession of the property, either as agent or tenant in any manner or form shall be equally liable with the owners of such property for the violation of this chapter. 
(Code 1973, § 241/2-7; Ord. No. 05-1533, § 6, 11-21-05) 
Editor's note- See note following § 31-4. 
Sec. 31-6. - Penalty for violation. 
    Whenever in this chapter any act is prohibited or made or declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor, or whenever in such chapter the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision of this chapter shall be punished by fine of not more than $500.00. Each day any violation of any provision of this chapter shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 80-435, 10-27-80; Ord. No. 05-1533, § 6, 11-21-05) 
Editor's note- See note following § 31-4. 
Chapter 32 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Finance and fiscal procedures, § 2-66 et seq.; tax levy authorized for civil defense, § 8-21; licenses and business regulations, Ch. 18. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 32-1. - Municipal use tax. 
(a)  A tax is hereby imposed in accordance with the provisions of section 8-11-6 of the "Illinois Municipal Code" (Ill. Rev. Stat., Ch. 24), approved May 29, 1961, as amended, upon the privilege of using in the municipality of Bourbonnais, Illinois, any item of tangible personal property which is purchased outside Illinois at retail from a retailer, and which is titled or registered with any agency of Illinois government. The tax shall be at the rate of one percent of the selling price of such tangible personal property, with "selling price" to have the meaning as defined in the Use Tax Act, approved July, 1955, as amended, and the tax shall be collected from persons whose Illinois address for titling or registration purposes is given as being within the municipality of Bourbonnais. 
(b)  Such tax shall be collected by the Illinois Department of Revenue for the Village of Bourbonnais and the tax must be paid, or an exemption determination obtained from the department of revenue, before the title or certificate of registration for the personal property may be issued. The department of revenue shall have full power to administer and enforce the provisions of such Act and this section. 
(Ord. No. 87-640, §§ 1, 2, 9-21-87) 
Secs. 32-2-32-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RETAILERS' OCCUPATION TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority for tax, procedure, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 8-11-1; Retailers' Occupation Tax Act, Ch. 120, § 440 et seq. 

Sec. 32-16. - Imposed. 
    A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of selling tangible personal property at retail in this village, at the rate of one percent of the gross receipts from such sales made in the course of such business, in accordance with the provisions of Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 120, section 439.121. 
(Code 1973, § 25-18) 
Sec. 32-17. - Report required. 
    Every such person engaged in such business in the village shall file on or before the last day of each calendar month, the report to the state department of revenue required by law. 
(Code 1973, § 25-19) 
Sec. 32-18. - Payment. 
    At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the state department of revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed on account of the receipts from sales of tangible personal property during the preceding month. 
(Code 1973, § 25-20) 
Sec. 32-19. - Penalty. 
    Whenever in this article any act is prohibited or made or declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor, or whenever in such article the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision of this article shall be punished by fine of not more than $500.00. Each day any violation of any provision of this article shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 80-434, 10-27-80) 
Secs. 32-20-32-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TAX INCREMENT FINANCING 
DIVISION 1. - INTERESTED PARTIES REGISTRIES 

Sec. 32-26. - Definitions. 
    As used in these Registration Rules, the following terms shall have the definitions set forth below. 
    Act shall mean the Tax Increment Allocation Redevelopment Act 65 ILCS § 5/11-74.4-1 et seq. as amended from time to time. 
    Village shall mean Village of Bourbonnais, Kankakee County, Illinois. 
    Interested party(s) shall mean (a) any organization(s) active within the village (b) any resident(s) of the village, and (c) any other entity or person otherwise entitled under the Act to register in a specific registry who has been registered in such registry and whose registration has not been otherwise terminated in accordance with these registration rules. 
    Redevelopment project area shall mean a redevelopment project area that (a) is intended to qualify (or has subsequently qualified) as a "redevelopment project area" under the Act and (b) is subject to the "interested parties" registry requirements of the Act. 
    Registration application form shall mean the form appended to these registration rules or such revised form as may be approved by the village consistent with the requirements of the Act. 
    Registry or registries shall mean each interested parties registry, and all such registries, collectively, established by the village pursuant to section 11-74.4-4.2 of the Act for the redevelopment project area. 
(Ord. No. 06-1555, Exh. A, § A, 2-21-06) 
Sec. 32-27. - Establishment of registry. 
    The village shall establish a separate interested parties registry for each redevelopment project area, whether existing as of the date of the adoption of these rules or hereafter established. The village shall establish a new registry whenever it has identified an area for study and possible designation as a redevelopment project area. In any event, the process of establishing the new registry must be completed prior to the deadline for sending any of the notices required by section 32-36 of these rules or any other notices required by the Act with respect to the proposed redevelopment project area. 
(Ord. No. 06-1555, Exh. A, § B, 2-21-06) 
Sec. 32-28. - Maintenance of registry. 
    The village clerk or his or her designee shall maintain the registries. The registry shall include the name, address, and telephone number of each registered resident; and for registered organizations, the name and phone number of a designated contact person. 
(Ord. No. 06-1555, Exh. A, § C, 2-21-06) 
Sec. 32-29. - Registration by residents. 
    An individual seeking to register as an interested party with respect to a redevelopment project area must complete and submit a registration application form to the village clerk. Such individual must also submit a copy of a current driver's license, lease, utility bill, financial statement, or such other evidence as may be acceptable to the clerk to establish the individual's current residency in the village. 
(Ord. No. 06-1555, Exh. A, § D, 2-21-06) 
Sec. 32-30. - Registration by organizations. 
    An organization seeking to register as an interested party with respect to a redevelopment project area must complete and submit a registration application form to the village clerk. Such organization must also submit a copy of a one-page statement describing the organization's current operations in the village. 
(Ord. No. 06-1555, Exh. A, § E, 2-21-06) 
Sec. 32-31. - Determination of eligibility. 
    All individuals and organizations whose registration application form and supporting documentation complies with these registration rules shall be registered in the applicable registry within ten business days of the village clerk's receipt of all such documents. If the village clerk determines that an applicant's registration application form and/or supporting documentation is incomplete or does not comply with these registration rules, the clerk shall give written notice to the applicant specifying the defect(s). The applicant shall be entitled to correct any defects and resubmit a new registration application form and supporting documentation. 
(Ord. No. 06-1555, Exh. A, § F, 2-21-06) 
Sec. 32-32. - Notices and availability of information. 
    Upon registration, interested parties shall be entitled to receive all notices required under the Act, including how to obtain information concerning the applicable redevelopment project area. The village reserves the right to charge recipients for the cost of copies and postage/delivery charges for requested documents. 
(Ord. No. 06-1555, Exh. A, § G, 2-21-06) 
Sec. 32-33. - Renewal and termination. 
    An interested party's registration shall remain effective for a period of three years. At any time after such three-year period, the village clerk shall provide written notice by regular mail to the interested party stating that such registration shall terminate unless the interested party renews such registration within 30 days of the clerk's mailing of written notice. To renew such registration, the interested party shall, within such 30-day period, complete and submit the same registration application form and supporting documentation then required of initial registrants in order to permit the clerk to confirm such person's residency or such organization's operations in the village. The registration of all individuals and organizations whose registration application form and supporting documentation is submitted in a timely manner and complies with these regulation rules shall be renewed for an additional, consecutive three-year period. If the village clerk determines that a registrant's renewal registration application form and/or supporting documentation is incomplete or does not comply with these registration rules, the clerk shall give written notice to the registrant at the address specified in the renewal registration application form submitted, specifying the defect(s). The registrant shall be entitled to correct any defects and resubmit a new registration application form and supporting documentation within 30 days of receipt of the clerk's notice. If all defects are not corrected within 30 days of the interested party's receipt of the village clerk's notice, the interested party's registration shall be terminated. Any interested party whose registration is terminated shall be entitled to register again as if a first-time applicant. 
(Ord. No. 06-1555, Exh. A, § H, 2-21-06) 
Sec. 32-34. - Amendment to registration. 
    An interested party may amend its registration by giving written notice to the village clerk by certified mail for any of the following reasons: (i) a change in address for notice purposes; (ii) in the case of organizations, a change in the name of the contact person; and (iii) a termination of registration. Upon receipt of such notice, the clerk shall revise the applicable registry accordingly. 
(Ord. No. 06-1555, Exh. A, § I, 2-21-06) 
Sec. 32-35. - Registries available for public inspection. 
    Each registry shall be available for public inspection during the village's normal business hours. 
(Ord. No. 06-1555, Exh. A, § J, 2-21-06) 
Sec. 32-36. - Notices to be sent to interested parties. 
    Interested parties shall be sent the following notices as well as any other notices required under the act with respect to the applicable redevelopment project area: 
(a)  Pursuant to subsection 74-4-5(a) of the Act, notice of the availability of a proposed redevelopment plan and eligibility report, including how to obtain this information. Such notice shall be sent by mail within a reasonable period of time after the adoption of the ordinance fixing a time and place for the public hearing for the proposed redevelopment plan. 
(b)  Pursuant to subsection 74-4.5(a) of the Act, notice of changes to a proposed redevelopment plan that does not: (1) add additional parcels of property to the proposed redevelopment project area, (2) substantially affect the general land uses proposed in the redevelopment plan, (3) substantially change the nature of or extend the life of the redevelopment project, or (4) increase the number of low- or very-low-income households to be displaced from the redevelopment project area, provided that measured from the time of creation of the redevelopment project area the total displacement of households will exceed ten. Such notice shall be sent by mail not later than ten days following the village's adoption by ordinance of such changes. 
(c)  Pursuant to subsection 74-4.5(c) of the Act, notice of amendments to a previously approved redevelopment plan that does not: (1) add additional parcels of property to the redevelopment project area, (2) substantially affect the general land uses in the redevelopment plan, (3) substantially change the nature of the redevelopment project, (4) increase the total estimated redevelopment project costs set out in the redevelopment plan by more than five percent after adjustment for inflation from the date the plan was adopted, (5) add additional redevelopment project costs to the itemized list of redevelopment project costs set out in the redevelopment plan, or (6) increase the number of low- or very-low-income households to be displaced from the redevelopment project area, provided that measured from the time of creation of the redevelopment project area the total displacement of households will exceed ten. Such notice shall be sent by mail not later than ten days following the village's adoption by ordinance of any such amendment. 
(d)  Pursuant to subsection 74.4-5(d)(9) of the Act for redevelopment plans or projects that would result in the displacement of residents from ten or more inhabited residential units or that contain 75 or more inhabited residential units, notice of the availability of the annual report described by subsection 74.4-5(d), including how to obtain the annual report. Such notice shall be sent by mail within a reasonable period of time after completion of the certified audit report. 
(e)  Pursuant to section 74.4-6(e) of the Act, notice of the public meeting required under the Act for a proposed redevelopment project area that will result in the displacement of ten or more inhabited residential units or which will contain 75 or more inhabited residential units. Such notice shall be sent by certified mail not less than 15 days before the date of such public meeting and shall include the information required under subsection 74.4-6(e) of the Act. 
(Ord. No. 06-1555, Exh. A, § K, 2-21-06) 
Sec. 32-37. - Noninterference. 
    These Registration Rules shall not be used to prohibit or otherwise interfere with the ability of eligible organizations and individuals to register for receipt of information to which they are entitled under the Act. 
(Ord. No. 06-1555, Exh. A, § L, 2-21-06) 
Sec. 32-38. - Amendment of registration rules. 
    These registration rules may be amended by the village subject to and consistent with the requirements of the Act. 
(Ord. No. 06-1555, Exh. A, § M, 2-21-06) 
Secs. 32-39-32-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - INDUSTRIAL PARK CONSERVATION AREA 

Sec. 32-51. - Findings. 
(1)  The Village Board of the Village of Bourbonnais hereby makes the following findings: 
(a)  The area constituting the Industrial Park Conservation Area in the Village of Bourbonnais, Illinois, is described in Exhibit A, as attached to Ord. No. 96-1658. 
(b)  There exist conditions that allow the area to be designated as a redevelopment project area and to be classified as an "industrial park conservation area" as defined in section 11-74.4-3 (d) of the Act, to wit: 
1.  Bourbonnais, by virtue of being located in Kankakee County, is a labor-surplus municipality as defined in section 11-74.4-3 (e) of the Act and documented in the plan. 
2.  The area includes both vacant land suitable for use as an industrial park and a conservation area is contiguous to the vacant land as documented in the plan. 
3.  The area is currently zoned M-1 or M-2 Industrial. 
(c)  The industrial park conservation area, on the whole, has not been subject to growth and development through investment by private enterprise and would not be reasonably anticipated to be developed without the adoption of the redevelopment plan. 
(d)  The redevelopment plan and redevelopment project for the industrial park conservation area conforms to the comprehensive plan for the development of the municipality as a whole. 
(e)  The parcels of real property in the proposed redevelopment project area are contiguous and only those contiguous parcels of real property, which will be substantially benefited by the proposed redevelopment project, are included in the industrial park conservation area. 
(f)  The estimated date for the completion of the redevelopment project or retirement of obligations issued shall not be later than December 31 of the year in which the payment to the village treasurer as provided in subsection (b) of section 11-74.4-8 of the Act is to be made with respect to ad valorem taxes levied in the twenty-third calendar year after the year in which the ordinance approving the redevelopment project area is adopted. 
(2)  The tax increment redevelopment plan and project for the industrial park conservation area, which were the subject matter of the hearing held on October 2, 2006, are hereby adopted and approved. A copy of the aforementioned redevelopment plan and project, marked as exhibit B is attached to and made a part of Ordinance No. 06-1658. 
(Ord. No. 06-1658, §§ 1, 2, 10-23-06) 
Sec. 32.52. - Plan adopted. 
(1)  Tax increment financing is hereby adopted in respect to the tax increment redevelopment plan and project approved and adopted pursuant to Ordinance No. 06-1568 in the Village of Bourbonnais in respect to the following described industrial park conservation area, and attached hereto as exhibit A; which the industrial park conservation area was designated pursuant to Ordinance No. 06-1569. 
(2)  After the total equalized assessed valuation of taxable real property in the industrial park conservation area exceeds the total initial equalized assessed value of all taxable real property in the industrial park conservation area, the ad valorem taxes, if any, arising from the levies upon real property in the industrial park conservation area by taxing districts and the rates determined in the manner provided in subsection (c) of section 11-74.4-9 of the Act each year after the effective date of this section until the redevelopment project costs and all obligations issued in respect thereto have been paid shall be divided as follows: 
(a)  That portion of taxes levied upon each taxable lot, block, tract or parcel of real property which is attributable to lower of the current equalized assessed value or the initial equalized assessed value of each such taxable lot, block, tract or parcel of real property in the industrial park conservation area shall be allocated to and when collected shall be paid by the county collector to the respective affected taxing districts in the manner required by law in the absence of the adoption of tax increment allocation financing. 
(b)  That portion, if any, of such taxes which is attributable to the increase in the current equalized assessed valuation of each lot, block, tract or parcel of real property in the redevelopment project area over and above the initial equalized assessed value of each property in the industrial park conservation area shall be allocated to and when collected shall be paid to the municipal treasurer who shall deposit said taxes into a special fund called "the special tax allocation fund for the industrial park conservation area" of the village for the purpose of paying the redevelopment project costs and obligations incurred in the payment thereof, pursuant to such appropriations which may be subsequently made. 
(Ord. No. 06-1660, §§ 1, 2, 10-23-06) 
Chapter 33 - TREES, SHRUBS AND WEEDS[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 33-1. - Gas pipes injuring trees, shrubs. 
    Any person maintaining any gas pipes in the village shall, in the absence of provision in the franchise concerning the subject, keep such pipes free from leaks so that no injury shall be done to any tree or shrub. 
(Code 1973, § 26-1) 
Secs. 33-2-33-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TREES AND SHRUBS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 93-975, §§ 1-20, adopted Dec. 6, 1993, has been treated by the editor as superseding the provisions of former Art. II, Plants in Public Places, which pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1973, §§ 26-17, 26-18, 26-20-26-22. 
State Law reference- Planting trees on municipal property, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 1-72-1. 

Sec. 33-11. - Trees; heights of branches. 
    The owner or owners of every lot or parcel of land in the village upon which any tree is now or may hereafter be growing shall trim or cause to be trimmed the branches thereof, so that the same shall not obstruct the free passage of persons or vehicles from any street, alley or highway in the village to the adjacent sidewalk or street; and such owner or owners shall trim all branches of any tree or trees now or hereafter growing on their premises which overhang any street, alley, or public highway, so that there shall be a clear height of 12 feet above the surface of the street, alley, or highway unobstructed by branches, and a clear height of not less than ten feet over any sidewalk, and shall remove from such tree or trees all dead, decayed or broken and/or hazardous limbs or branches that overhang such street, alley or public highway, and, when any of such trees are dead and/or hazardous, shall remove the same so that they shall not fall into the street, alley or public highway. 
(Ord. No. 93-975, § 1, 12-6-93) 
Sec. 33-12. - Trees and shrubs; location and selection. 
    No person shall do any of the following without written consent of the village manager or his designated representative: 
(1)  Plant any ornamental tree or shrub in any street or parkway of the village; 
(2)  Plant any herbaceous plant or flower of any kind or character which, at its maturity, attains height of over 24 inches, in any street or parkway of the village; 
(3)  Plant any tree within 25 feet of any corner or street intersection in the village; 
(4)  Plant any tree on any street or parkway within 35 feet from any other tree in the same street or parkway; 
(5)  Plant any tree at a distance of less than four feet from the established sidewalk line of any street; 
(6)  Plant a tree at a distance of less than four feet from any driveway; 
(7)  Plant any tree at a distance of less than ten feet from any streetlamp; 
(8)  Plant any tree at a distance of less than five feet from any water buffalo box, gas meter, or fire hydrant; however, every homeowner adjacent to an improved right-of-way is entitled to at least one parkway tree regardless of the lack of space on the parkway. 
(Ord. No. 93-975, § 2, 12-6-93) 
Sec. 33-13. - Trees on public ground; defacing; removal. 
    No person shall, without written permission from the village, remove, destroy, break, cut, deface, trim, or in any manner injure or interfere with any tree, plant, or shrub that is now or may hereafter be growing in any street, alley, parkway, park, playground or public place in the village. Any person who damages any tree, shrub, or plant on any street, alley, parkway, park, playground, or public place is responsible for the replacement value or calculated value of the said tree, shrub or plant as determined by the village. 
(Ord. No. 93-975, § 3, 12-6-93) 
Sec. 33-14. - Maintenance and removal of border trees. 
    The village will be responsible for the trimming and removal of any tree, stump, or shrub that is existing or growing on any area where private and public property meet. 
(Ord. No. 93-975, § 4, 12-6-93) 
Sec. 33-15. - Earth space for trees. 
    No person shall hereafter, without a written permit from the village, place or maintain upon the ground in any street, park, or parkway in the village any stone, cement, or other material which will impede free passage of water and air to the roots of any tree without leaving a space of not less than four feet in width all around the trunk of such tree; and wherever there is no such open space about any existing tree in any street or public highway in the village, the village may make such open space or cause the same to be made and charge the expense to the person so depositing such material. 
(Ord. No. 93-975, § 5, 12-6-93) 
Sec. 33-16. - Guards for trees. 
    In the erection, alteration, demolition, and/or repair of any building or structure, the owner or owners thereof shall place such guards around all trees in the parkways or other village property as shall effectively prevent injury to the tree and tree's root systems. All construction that is done to any building or structure must conform to the specifications dealing with "Construction Around Trees" as registered and on file with the village. 
(Ord. No. 93-975, § 6, 12-6-93) 
Sec. 33-17. - Electrical wires and various objects; support. 
    No person or corporation shall, without written permission from the village, attach any electrical wire, radio antenna, insulator or any other electrical device for holding electric wire to a tree now or hereafter growing in any street, alley, parkway, park, playground, public place or public highway in the village. Furthermore, no person or corporation shall attach or place any rope, wire, sign, poster, handbill, or other object onto, into, or around any tree or shrub now or hereafter growing in any street or public highway in the village, or on any guard or protection of the same. 
(Ord. No. 93-975, § 7, 12-6-93) 
Sec. 33-18. - Electric wires; contact with trees. 
    Every person or corporation having any wire or wires charged with electricity shall, whenever practicable, securely fasten the same so that such wire or wires shall not come in contact with any tree in any street or alley in the village. 
(Ord. No. 93-975, § 8, 12-6-93) 
Sec. 33-19. - Permits. 
    Any person intending to plant, remove, spray, dust, or apply chemicals to destroy, break, cut, deface, trim or in any way injure or interfere with any tree, plant, or shrub in any street, parkway, park, playground or public place in the village must apply for a written permit from the village. 
(Ord. No. 93-975, § 9, 12-6-93) 
Sec. 33-20. - Damaging trees and shrubs. 
    Whoever shall in this village cut down, dig up, sever, injure bark, or destroy any fruit or ornamental tree, cultivated root or plant, or food-bearing bush, or shall without lawful authority cut down, uproot, destroy or injure any fruit or ornamental tree or shrubbery planted or growing on any street, highway, public thoroughfare, park or public grounds shall be responsible for the replacement value of the said tree, shrub, or plant. 
(Ord. No. 93-975, § 10, 12-6-93) 
Sec. 33-21. - Improperly located trees. 
    If any tree hereafter planted on village property at a location other than specified by the village, or shall hereafter be planted in violation of this article, the village shall cause the same to be taken up and properly be set out at the expense of the person responsible for the planting. 
(Ord. No. 93-975, § 11, 12-6-93) 
Sec. 33-22. - Obstruction of street lights or passage. 
    No tree, shrub, flower, or plant shall be permitted by the owner or occupant of any premises to grow in such a manner as to obstruct the rays of light of a public lamp or obstruct the free passage of persons or vehicles passing on any street, alley, parkway, park, playground, or other public way or place. Any person or corporation in violation must remove or trim the obstructing vegetation within 14 days after notification by the village. Any vegetation not removed within 14 days will be removed by the village, and the owner or occupant will be billed for the cost of the removal and disposal. 
(Ord. No. 93-975, § 12, 12-6-93) 
Sec. 33-23. - Low branches; trimming. 
    All trees and shrubs standing upon private property abutting on any sidewalk, street, or public place shall have their branches cut or trimmed so that no part thereof shall overhang such sidewalk, street, or public place at a distance less than 12 feet above the sidewalk or street level. 
(Ord. No. 93-975, § 13, 12-6-93) 
Sec. 33-24. - Dead trees to be removed. 
    Dead trees or parts thereof that are standing on private property and have been declared a public nuisance must be removed following notification by the village within 14 days. It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation being the owner of the property whereon such tree is situated to allow the tree to remain standing after the expiration of 14 days following the notification of the discovery of the dead tree. 
(Ord. No. 93-975, § 14, 12-6-93) 
Sec. 33-25. - Infected trees to be destroyed. 
    Elm trees of all species and varieties infected with Dutch elm disease (Ceratocystis ulmi) are hereby declared a public nuisance and shall be removed from the village within 14 days following notification of the discovery of such infection. It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation being the owner of property whereon such tree is situated to possess or keep such a tree after the expiration of 14 days following notification of the discovery of said infection. 
(Ord. No. 93-975, § 15, 12-6-93) 
Sec. 33-26. - Elm bark beetle; breeding places destroyed. 
    Elm logs or parts thereof in a dead or dying condition that may serve as a breeding place for any elm bark beetle are hereby declared a public nuisance, and it shall be unlawful for the person, firm or corporation owning property whereon the same is situated to possess or keep the same in such condition. Elm logs or parts thereof must be removed from the village within 14 days of notification by the village. Failure to remove such material will result in a fine of not less than $50.00. Each day that such violation shall occur may be treated as a separate violation. 
(Ord. No. 93-975, § 16, 12-6-93) 
Sec. 33-27. - Village to enforce article. 
    The village is charged with the enforcement of this article, and to that end may enter, or direct a representative to enter, upon private property at all reasonable hours for purposes of inspecting trees thereon, and may cause to be removed such specimens as are required for purposes of analysis to determine whether or not the same are infected, and to cause to be removed such diseased trees upon failure of the owner to do so after notification. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to prevent the village or the representative from entering on private property for purposes of carrying out the duties hereunder, or to interfere with such village in the lawful performance of the duties under provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 93-975, § 17, 12-6-93) 
Sec. 33-28. - Removal of tree by village; charges to owner. 
    In cases where the property owner fails to remove or trim a tree as required by this article and a tree is removed or trimmed at the direction of the village, it shall be the duty of the village to cause a statement of charges for such tree removal or trimming and disposal to be sent to such property owner. 
(Ord. No. 93-975, § 18, 12-6-93) 
Sec. 33-29. - Collection by village; lien. 
    Whenever such charges shall remain unpaid for a period of 30 days from the date of the bill herein provided for, the village is hereby authorized to: 
(1)  Institute suit in the name of the village to enforce collection of such charge; and/or 
(2)  File a sworn statement showing an obligation in the office of the recorder of deeds of the county, and the filing of such statement shall be deemed notice of the lien for payment of such charges. 
(Ord. No. 93-975, § 19, 12-6-93) 
Sec. 33-30. - Penalty. 
    Whoever violates any provision of any section in this article in regard to the location or maintenance of any tree or shrub, and after notice by the village manager shall refuse to fail to properly replant or trim such tree or shrub, the village manager may have such work performed at the expense of the person so in default. In addition thereto, any person violating any provision of this article shall be fined not less than $10.00 nor more than $200.00 for each offense. Each day that a violation continues shall be treated as a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 93-975, § 20, 12-6-93) 
ARTICLE III. - OFFENSIVE AND TALL GROWTHS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Weed abatement, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 11-20-6 et seq. 

Sec. 33-31. - Certain weeds prohibited, declared nuisance. 
    Any weeds such as jimson, burdock, ragweed, thistle, cocklebur, or other weeds of a like kind, found growing in any lot or tract of land in the village, are hereby declared to be a nuisance, and it shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to permit any such weeds or growth to grow or remain in such place. 
(Code 1973, § 26-33; Ord. No. 81-468, 6-2-81) 
Sec. 33-32. - Height limitation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to permit any weeds, grass or plants, other than trees, bushes, flowers, or other ornamental plants to grow to a height exceeding eight inches within the village; any such plants or weeds exceeding such height are hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(Code 1973, § 26-34; Ord. No. 80-454, § 2, 10-27-80; Ord. No. 81-468, 6-2-81; Ord. No. 94-989, § 1, 4-4-94) 
Sec. 33-33. - Barberry bushes. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to plant or permit the growth of the bush of the species of tall, common or European barberry, further known as Barberis vulgaris, or its horticultural varieties within the village. The planting or maintenance of growth of this species is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(Code 1973, § 26-35; Ord. No. 81-468, 6-2-81) 
Sec. 33-34. - Notice requiring abatement. 
    It shall be the duty of the maintenance supervisor to serve or cause to be served a notice upon the owner or occupant of any such premises on which weeds or plants are permitted to grow in violation of the provisions of this article, and to demand the abatement of the nuisance within five days. A notice served pursuant to this section shall be sufficient notice to require that the owner or occupant abate the nuisance within five days after such notice and not permit the nuisance to recur within the calendar year in which notice is served. 
(Code 1973, § 26-36; Ord. No. 81-468, 6-2-81; ord. No. 89-734, § 1, 11-6-89) 
Sec. 33-35. - Abatement by village. 
    If the person so served does not abate the nuisance within five days after such notice, or if the nuisance is abated but recurs within the calendar year in which notice was previously served, the maintenance supervisor may proceed to abate such nuisance as often as the nuisance recurs and the expense therefrom shall be charged to and paid by the owner or occupant without further notice. The cost shall be determined at the rate of $200.00 for the first hour required to set up and transport equipment to the offending site and $125.00 per hour for each and every hour thereafter required to abate the nuisance. The aforesaid costs are based upon calculating the reasonable costs to the village in setting up, maintaining and operating and required equipment as well as the wages paid to the operators and overhead paid on the equipment and personnel. 
(Code 1973, § 26-37; Ord. No. 81-468, 6-2-81; Ord. No. 89-734, § 2, 11-6-89; Ord. No. 94-989, § 2, 4-4-94) 
Sec. 33-36. - Lien for village expenses. 
(a)  Charges for weed abatement shall be a lien upon the premises, as provided by statute. Whenever a bill for weed abatement remains unpaid 30 days after the bill has been sent to the owner or occupant, the village clerk may file with the recorder of deeds of the county a statement of lien claim. This statement shall contain a legal description of the premises served, and the amount of the unpaid bill, and a notice that the village claims a lien for this amount. 
(b)  Notice of such lien claim shall be mailed by the village clerk to the owner or occupant of the premises, whenever such bills remain unpaid for a period of 30 days after they have been mailed to the owner's or occupant's last known address. 
(c)  The failure of the village clerk to record such lien claim or to mail such notice, or the failure of the owner or occupant to receive such notice, shall not affect the right to foreclose the lien for unpaid weed abatement bills as outlined herein. 
(d)  Property subject to a lien for such unpaid bills shall be sold for nonpayment of the same, and the proceeds of the sale shall be applied to pay the charges, after deducting costs, as is the case in the foreclosure of statutory liens. Such foreclosure shall be by bill in equity in the name of the Village of Bourbonnais. 
(Code 1973, § 26-38; Ord. No. 81-468, 6-2-81) 
Sec. 33-37. - Penalty. 
    The violation of any provision of this article shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed $500.00; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which such nuisance continues unabated after five days from receipt of such notice. 
(Code 1973, § 26-39; Ord. No. 81-468, 6-2-81)

(Ord. No. 80-433, 10-27-80)
