3.10-8. Lighting or other equipment. Any lighting used to illuminate off-street parking facilities shall be directed away from residential properties and public streets in such a way as to not create a nuisance. In no case shall lighting exceed three foot candles measured at the property line. 
3.10-9. Signs. Accessory signs shall be permitted for parking facilities in accordance with the provisions specified in article IX. 
3.10-10. Loudspeaker systems. All excessive sound levels coming from loudspeaker systems attached or unattached to any motorized vehicle shall not be permitted in any parking lot located within the village. Loudspeaker systems shall not be permitted except by ordinance of the village board after recommendation by the plan commission. 
3.10-11. Location. For all driveways hereinafter installed after the effective date of this chapter, all driveway surfaces shall be no closer than three feet to the adjoining side yard. 
3.11 Trucks and trailers. Except as otherwise as may be provided herein, trucks in excess of 12,000 pounds and trailers shall not be parked in the front of any building. 
(Ord. No. 95-1060, § 2, 8-7-95; Ord. No. 04-1420, §§ 1, 2, 4-19-04; Ord. No. 05-1526, § 20, 10-3-05)

(b)  Automobile laundries, manual. One parking space per each two employees, plus one parking space per each manager plus two reservoir parking spaces per each washing bay, one of which shall be located in front of and one directly in back of each manual car wash bay. 
(c)  Automobile laundries, automatic. One parking space per each two employees plus one parking space per each manager plus 15 reservoir parking spaces. 
4.6-10. Integrated shopping centers. Integrated shopping centers which do not contain theaters, restaurants, medical offices or other uses requiring spaces in excess of five spaces per 1,000 square feet of gross floor area as determined by the village engineering, the village plan commission and the village board of trustees, shall provide parking spaces in accordance with the following: 
(a)  Shopping centers with up to 24,000 square feet of gross floor area. Four parking spaces per each 1,000 square feet of gross floor area. 
(b)  Shopping centers with 24,000 square feet, but less than 400,000 square feet of gross floor area. Four and one-half parking spaces per each 1,000 square feet of gross floor area. 
(c)  Shopping centers with 400,000 square feet or more of gross floor area. Five parking spaces per each 1,000 square feet of gross floor area. 
Where theaters, restaurants, medical offices or other uses requiring spaces in excess of five spaces per 1,000 square feet of gross floor area as determined by the village engineer, the village plan commission and the village board of trustees are established as a portion of any integrated shopping center, such uses shall provide parking spaces calculated on the basis of the individual use(s) using the schedule of off-street parking requirements in the appendix. 
4.7. Parking category number 7-Industrial uses.

Wastewater treatment plants

(Ord. No. 98-1162, § 4, 10-19-98; Ord. No. 03-1373, § 1, 9-15-03; Ord. No. 07-1698, § 1, 6-4-07; Ord. No. 02-1310, § 6, 6-17-02) 
Sec. 5. - Off-street loading requirements. 
5.1. General requirements (B-1/B-2, M-1/M-2). 
5.1-1. Loading berth, description. An off-street loading berth shall be a hard-surfaced area of land, open or enclosed, other than a street or a public way, used principally for the standing, loading or unloading of motor trucks, tractors and trailers so as to avoid undue interference with the public use of streets and alleys. A required loading space shall be not less than ten feet in width, 45 feet in length, and 14 feet in height, exclusive of access aisles and maneuvering space, except as otherwise specifically dimensioned hereafter. 
5.1-2. Location. No permitted or required loading berth shall be located in the front of any building, nor shall said berth be closer than 50 feet to any property in a residential district unless completely enclosed by building walls, or a uniformly painted solid fence or wall, or any combination thereof not less than six feet in height. No permitted or required loading berth shall be located within 25 feet of the nearest point of intersection of any two streets. Loading berths open to the sky may be located in any required yard except a front yard. 
(a)  Central loading facilities. Central loading facilities may be substituted for off-street loading facilities on individual zoning lots provided the following conditions are fulfilled: 
1.  Each zoning lot served shall have direct access to the central loading area without crossing streets. 
2.  The total number of off-street loading berths provided shall meet the minimum requirements of this chapter, based on the sum of the several types of uses served. Area of types of uses may be totaled before computing number of loading berths. 
3.  No zoning lot served shall be located more than 300 feet from the central loading area. 
(b)  Control of central loading facilities. When the required off-street loading facilities are collectively provided and used in central loading facilities, written covenants and easements assuring their retention, maintenance, and use for such purposes shall be executed by the parties concerned. Such covenants and easements shall be reviewed by the village engineer and the village plan commission and approved as to content and form by the village attorney and filed for record in the office of the county recorder. 
5.1-3. Measurement of berth. When determination of the number of required off-street loading berths results in a requirement of a fractional berth, any fraction up to and including one-half shall be disregarded, and fractions over one-half shall be interpreted as one loading berth. 
5.1-4. Surfacing. All open off-street loading areas and access aisles shall be improved with a compacted stone base not less than 12 inches thick and shall be surfaced with not less than four inches of asphaltic concrete, or reinforced Portland Cement Concrete not less than eight inches thick with compacted stone base of not less than four inches thick. 
5.1-5. Access. All off-street loading facilities shall open directly upon an aisle or driveway not less than 12 feet wide or to a public street. 
5.1-6. Utilization. Space allocated to any off-street loading facility shall not, while so allocated, be used to satisfy the requirement for any off-street parking facilities or portion thereof. 
5.1-7. Minimum loading facilities. Uses of buildings, structures, or parcels of land which require off-street loading facilities, but which have less area than the minimum prescribed for such required facilities, shall be provided with adequate receiving facilities, accessible by motor vehicle off any adjacent service drive on the same lot. 
5.1-8. Lighting. Any lighting used to illuminate off-street loading areas shall be directed away from residential properties and public streets in such a way as to not create a nuisance. 
5.1-9. Signs. Accessory signs shall be permitted for loading areas in accordance with the provisions specified in article IX. 
5.2. Off-street loading and unloading facilities. In all districts where property uses include the loading and unloading of materials or merchandise from vehicles, off-street loading and unloading facilities shall be provided in accordance with the following requirements:

(Ord. No. 04-1420, § 3, 4-19-04) 
Sec. 6. - Drive-in facilities. 
(1)  Required spaces. Every drive-in establishment, as defined in article iii Definitions, hereinafter constructed after the effective date of this ordinance, shall provide a minimum of five stacking spaces per facility, plus one space per waiting area provided. 
(2)  Design and layout. The stacking spaces shall be designed so as not to interfere with the ingress and egress to the off-street parking, traffic circulation on- or off-site, and traffic visibility. Drive-in establishments shall not be located in the front of the principal building and the maneuvering space shall be provided in the side or rear yard. 
(3)  Additional standards. 
(a)  Stacking spaces shall not be used for the sale, repair, dismantling or servicing of any vehicles, equipment, materials, or supplies. 
(b)  Each off-street stacking space shall not be less than eight feet in width and 18 feet in length, exclusive of access drives. 
(c)  Stacking areas shall be constructed in accordance with required specifications for off-street parking areas, as provided for herein. 
(Ord. No. 04-1414, § 3, 3-15-04) 
ARTICLE IX. - SIGNS 

Sec. 1. - Prohibited signs. 
    It shall be unlawful to erect, operate or maintain: 
(1)  Any sign which has blinking or flashing lights or lighting which changes periodically or gives the appearance of movement, except those by which the light movement itself creates letters or numerals which convey a noncommercial public service, political or religious message. 
(2)  Any sign which is not effectively shielded so as to prevent beams or rays of light from being directed at any portion of a traveled way of any public highway or which is of such intensity as to cause glare or to impair the vision of any driver of a motor vehicle. 
(3)  Any sign which has blinking, flashing and/or visible moving parts with less than four seconds intervals. 
(4)  Any sign which advertises or publicizes an activity not conducted on the premises upon which the sign is maintained, except for signs displaying noncommercial public service, political or religious messages. 
(5)  Any portable street sign, except those displaying noncommercial public service, political or religious messages. 
(6)  Any projecting sign on commercial advertising off point of sale. 
(7)  Any billboard sign displaying commercial advertising off point of sale, except those which display a noncommercial public service, political or religious message. 
(8)  Any roof sign. 
(9)  Any snipe sign at the same location for more than 72 hours. 
(Ord. No. 94-1010, § 2, 6-6-94) 
Sec. 2. - Ground or pole signs. 
2.1. Distance from buildings. No part of a ground or pole sign shall be less than five feet from any building. 
2.2. Height. No part of a ground or pole sign shall exceed 35 feet in height when measured from the ground grade. No ground or pole sign shall extend over a pedestrian way. The location for all ground or pole signs shall be installed with the outer projection of the sign on the plum, one foot in back of the property line in all zoned districts. 
2.3. Number of ground or pole signs. Ground or pole signs are limited as follows: Three ground or pole signs shall be permitted on contiguous lots which are occupied by a single business or occupied by two or more businesses which use or have the privilege of using common parking areas on one or more such lots. Exceptions: 
(1)  One additional ground or pole sign shall be permitted on a lot or on such contiguous lots provided that the two signs are at least 200 feet apart and the area of the additional sign is based on the amount of frontage not used to calculate the area of the other sign. 
(2)  One additional reader board sign shall be permitted for an automobile service station provided the copy states only sales or information of sales of a commercial commodity and the sign is not more than three feet by five feet in an area and located below the main sign. 
(3)  Enter or exit, direction, travel arrows, customer parking, loading or unloading, but not limited to the above (Article VIII, 3.10-9) signs may be installed if needed by owner with no square footage deductions. 
2.4. Size, area: The maximum area of a ground or pole sign, including all faces, shall be based on lot frontage or the total frontage of all contiguous lots as described in section 2.3 above, and shall be in accordance with the following schedule. No one face shall exceed one-half of such maximum: 
Frontage 
 (feet) One Side Maximum 
(square feet) Up to 51  50 51 to 150  75 150 to 250 100 250 to 350 125 350 or more 175  
Exception. The maximum allowable sign square footage for one side of a lot with frontage on more than one side may be increased to the sum of the maximum allowable sign square footage for all sides with frontage. For purposes of this section, frontage is defined as the line of property that is adjacent to a street. 
2.5. Restrictions. No ground or pole sign may extend into or over a vehicular way unless a clearance of 15 feet is maintained. 
(Ord. No. 94-1010, § 2, 6-6-94; Ord. No. 95-1060, §§ 3, 4, 8-7-95) 
Sec. 3. - Wall signs. 
3.1. Number of wall signs. No limitations. 
3.2. Size, areas. 
(1)  Front wall. The combined total area of all front wall signs for a business shall not exceed two square feet per linear foot of the building front occupied by the business which the sign advertises. 
(2)  Side and rear walls. Each business may have signs on side and rear walls. The total combined area of all rear and side wall signs for each business shall not exceed the lesser of (a) area allowed for a front wall sign, or (b) two square feet per linear foot of wall on which the sign is mounted, multiplied by the front linear feet of the business, divided by the front linear feet of the building. 
3.3. Height, clearance. No part of a wall sign shall extend above the top of the wall on which it is mounted. No part of a sign which projects over public property shall have less than eight feet of clearance. 
3.4. Projection. A wall sign may project a maximum of 12 inches from the wall on which it is mounted over a public way or on private property. 
Sec. 4. - Marquee signs. 
4.1. Location. A marquee sign shall be mounted parallel to the wall to which the marquee is attached, provided one sign may be mounted at an angle under the marquee at each entrance. 
4.2. Number of signs. One sign mounted parallel and one under the marquee at each business entrance. 
4.3. Size, area. The parallel marquee sign shall not exceed two feet by 20 feet and any sign under the marquee shall not exceed six square feet per side. The total area of all marquee signs and wall signs on the wall to which the marquee or canopy is attached, added together, shall not exceed two square feet per linear foot of building frontage. 
4.4 Height, clearance : No part of a marquee sign shall extend above the wall to which the marquee or canopy is attached. A clearance of 12 feet shall be maintained over a pedestrian way, and 15 feet over a vehicular way, except that a sign on a soft variance attached to the edge of the marquee may have a clearance of eight feet. 
4.5. Projection. A marquee sign mounted parallel to the edge of the marquee sign shall not project horizontally more than one foot from the edge of the marquee. 
(Ord. No. 94-1010, § 2, 6-6-94; Ord. No. 06-1565, § 2, 4-17-06) 
Sec. 5. - Real estate signs. 
    Real estate signs are limited to one per lot. Each sign is not to exceed six feet in height when measured from the ground, and no more than four square feet in area per face except corner lots may have two such signs. 
    Each lot is permitted an additional real estate sign saying "open house," when the house on the lot is being offered for sale. 
Sec. 6. - Construction signs. 
    Construction signs are limited to one per lot at the site of construction, not to exceed 100 square feet. The sign may include the name of the contractor, engineer, architect and lending institutions responsible for construction. No construction sign shall remain beyond the period of construction. 
Sec. 7. - Billboard signs. 
7.1. All billboard signs shall be constructed with the bottom of the sign area exactly ten feet from the ground at all points. 
7.2. The actual sign area shall not exceed 15 feet in height and 20 feet in width, or it shall not exceed a total of 300 square feet. 
7.3. If said sign is not leased for more than 30 consecutive days, the complete sign area shall be painted a solid white color or covered with a solid white cover. 
Sec. 8. - Notice of unsafe signs. 
    When any sign becomes insecure, in danger of falling, or otherwise unsafe, or if any sign shall be unlawfully installed, erected or maintained in violation of any provisions of this chapter, the owner thereof or the person or firm maintaining same shall upon written notice of the Bourbonnais Building Inspector, forthwith in the case of immediate danger and in any case within not more than ten days, make such sign conform to the provisions of this article or shall remove it. If within ten days the order is not complied with, the Building Inspector may remove such sign at the expense of the owner or lessee thereof as provided by the BOCA Basic Building Code, current edition. 
Sec. 9. - Obstruction to access. 
    A sign shall not be erected, constructed, or maintained so as to obstruct any fire escape, required exitway, window or door opening used as an element of a means of egress or to prevent free passage from one part of a roof to another part thereof or access thereto. 
Sec. 10. - Obstruction to ventilation. 
    A sign shall not be attached in any form, shape or manner which will interfere with any opening required for ventilation, except that such signs may be erected in front of and may cover transom windows when not in violation of the provisions of the BOCA Basic Building Code, current edition. 
Sec. 11. - Construction. 
    All signs shall be designed and constructed in conformity to the provisions for materials, loads and stresses as provided by the BOCA Basic Building Code, current edition. 
Sec. 12. - Illuminated signs. 
    All electrically illuminated signs shall be certified as to electric wiring and devices by the electrical inspector of the Village of Bourbonnais, and all wiring and accessory electrical equipment shall conform to the requirements of the National Electrical Code. 
Sec. 13. - Additional permits. 
    Electrical permits shall be issued for the erection or maintenance of illuminated signs. 
Sec. 14. - Repair and condition of sign. 
    No sign shall be maintained which is not in repair and in good condition. A sign which is not in repair and in good condition is declared to be a nuisance. 
Sec. 15. - Vacant premises. 
    After premises have been vacant for 90 days, any sign on the premises relating to a business which does not occupy the premises shall be removed by the building inspector of the Village of Bourbonnais at the expense of the building owner. 
Sec. 16. - Nonconforming signs. 
    Any sign which does not conform to the provisions of this chapter, and which lawfully existed and was owned by the person or business advertising on it on July 15, 1982, may continue, provided that no alterations are made thereto. Said sign may remain until the date the premises or the business thereto is sold to a new owner or owners. 
    Exception: 
(1)  Flashing signs and signs creating undue glare are prohibited as of July 15, 1982. 
(2)  Alterations not exceeding $500.00 per year may be made to a nonconforming sign. 
(3)  A new sign shall not be permitted on any premises which has a nonconforming sign, except real estate signs, political signs, and public information signs. 
Sec. 17. - Commercial signs. 
    No commercial sign shall be located, erected, maintained or operated within 100 feet of any residential zone, and no commercial sign shall be located, erected, maintained or operated within a residential zone unless it conforms to the definition of "home occupation," "marquee sign" or "real estate sign" as defined in Article III. 
Sec. 18. - Nuisance. 
    Violation of this chapter is hereby declared to be a nuisance. In the event any violation of this chapter continues for more than 30 consecutive days, subsequent to written notice detailing the violation mailed to the owner or lessee of the offending sign, the building inspector is authorized to seek an injunction in the Circuit Court of Kankakee County and bring the action in the name of Bourbonnais. 
Sec. 19. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 14-1974, § 2, adopted October 20, 2014, repealed § 19, which pertained to nonapplication and derived from Ord. No. 91-852, adopted Nov. 4, 1991. 
Sec. 20. - Garage and yard sale signs. 
20.1.  Notwithstanding provisions contained elsewhere, the following regulations shall apply to the placement of all residential garage and yard sale signs within the Village of Bourbonnais, including garage and yard sales customarily held by churches, schools and similar organizations: 
(1)  Off-site garage and yard sale signs shall be allowed on Thursday, Friday and Saturday only, and must be removed by no later than 7:00 a.m. on Monday. 
(2)  Off-site garage and yard sale signs shall be no larger than two feet by two feet. 
(3)  Off-site garage and yard sale signs shall not be placed on trees or fences, and no garage or yard sale sign shall be placed on utility poles, street light poles, traffic signals, street signs, stop signs, or similar items. 
(4)  All off-site garage and yard sale signs shall contain the address of the property where the garage or yard sale is being held. 
(5)  No garage or yard sale sign shall be placed, posted or otherwise located in the following areas: 
a.  Within 100 feet in any direction of the intersection of Routes 45/52 and 102, including the landscape islands located therein; and 
b.  Any village property, inclusive of the village hall (700 Main Street, NW), public works buildings (240 Tomagene Avenue, 255 Mooney Drive, 345 Water Street), village parks, village flower beds, landscape areas, or drainage areas. 
(6)  No garage or yard sale sign shall be displayed on any portable device or vehicle parked on any public street or right of way. 
(7)  If signs are placed in the right-of-way, namely that area between a sidewalk and the curb, the person placing the sign shall first have to have the permission of the owner of the property adjoining said right-of-way, or that property owner would have the ability to remove and dispose of said sign(s). 
(8)  If the village has to remove any garage or yard sale sign because said sign(s) do not meet these regulations, the person or persons responsible for the placement of said sign(s) may be subject to a $50.00 removal fee. 
(Ord. No. 99-1208, § 1, 1-3-00) 
ARTICLE X. - RESIDENCE DISTRICTS 

Sec. 1. - Purpose. 
    The residence districts set forth herein are established in order to protect public health and promote public safety, convenience, comfort, morals, prosperity and welfare. These general goals include, among others, the following specific purposes: 
1.1. To protect residential areas against fire, explosion, noxious fumes, offensive odors, noise, smoke, vibrations, dust, heat, glare and other objectionable factors; 
1.2. To protect residential areas to the extent possible and appropriate in each area against unduly heavy motor vehicle traffic, especially through traffic, and to alleviate congestion by promoting off-street parking; 
1.3. To protect residential areas against undue congestion of public streets and other public facilities by controlling the density of population through regulation of the bulk of buildings; 
1.4. To protect and promote the public health and comfort by providing for ample light and air to buildings and the windows thereof; 
1.5. To promote public comfort and welfare by providing for usable open space on the same zoning lot with residential development; 
1.6. To provide sufficient space in appropriate locations to meet the probable need for future residential expansion and to meet the need for necessary and desirable services in the vicinity of residences, which increase safety and amenity for residents and which do not exert objectionable influences. 
1.7. To promote the best use and development of residential land in accordance with a comprehensive land use plan, to promote stability of residential development, and protect the character and desirable development, and to protect the value of land and improvements and so strengthen the economic base of the village. 
Sec. 1.1. - Footing and foundation requirements. 
    All residential buildings hereinafter placed, constructed or structurally altered shall be placed on a continuous footing and foundation, as defined under the BOCA building code. 
(Ord. No. 98-1162, § 5, 10-19-98) 
Sec. 1.2. - Minimum size of dwelling. 
    Each single-family detached dwelling, and any other structure occupied in whole or in part for residential purposes, shall contain at least 1,350 square feet of livable floor area, exclusive of garages and any story below grade. 
(Ord. No. 08-1764, § 2, 3-17-08) 
Sec. 2. - R-1 one-family residence district. 
2.1. Permitted uses. 
(a)  One-family detached dwellings. 
(b)  Home occupations, as defined in section 2.6 of this article. 
(c)  Reserved. 
(d)  Reserved. 
(e)  Accessory buildings, as defined herein and as regulated by article VII. 
(f)  Planned developments, as defined in article XIII. 
(g)  Signs, as regulated by article IX. 
(h)  Off-street parking facilities, as required or permitted by article VIII. 
(i)  Publicly-owned open space such as parks, playgrounds, golf courses, forest preserves, and wildlife sanctuaries. 
(j)  Small community residence, provided: 
i.  They are located not less than 600 feet from another small community residence; and 
ii.  Prior to occupancy, operators shall submit an application for, and shall receive a certificate of zoning compliance, to be issued by the building department. Said application shall be obtained from the building department. 
(k)  Water towers, water reservoirs, sewage lift stations (if underground) for consumers in all districts with engineer, design and location. 
2.2. Special uses. The following uses may be allowed by special use permit in accordance with the provisions of article XV. 
(a)  Reserved. 
(b)  Reserved. 
(c)  Cemeteries, crematories or mausoleums. 
(d)  Churches. 
(e)  Convents, monasteries, rectories or parish houses to be occupied by not more than ten persons. 
(f)  Golf courses and country clubs, private. 
(g)  Reserved. 
(h)  Municipal or privately-owned recreation building or community center, when operated not for profit. 
(i)  Reserved. 
(j)  Planned residential developments, as defined in article XIII. 
(k)  Public utility facilities, i.e., filtration plant, water reservoir or pumping station, heat or power plant, transformer station and other similar facilities. 
(l)  Private playgrounds or parks which shall adjoin and touch another parcel/lot of real property with a residential building on it, both parcels/lots owned by the same person or entity. 
(m)  Railroad rights-of-way. 
(n)  Schools, elementary, high or college, public or private, including dormitories housing students and personnel thereof. 
(o)  Mobile classrooms, prefabricated classrooms, modular classrooms, temporary buildings used for classrooms and any temporary structure used for classroom or daycare purposes that is located on real property owned by and used by a church with a special use permit as allowed in 2.2(d) or a school with a special use permit as allowed in 2.2(n). This section requires a special use permit in addition to any other special use permit granted hereunder. Said special use permit may be granted for up to a four-year period. After four years of the date of issuance of the special use permit required herein, a renewal of said special use permit is required, which shall require the same application, fees and process as any special use permit. 
(p)  Temporary buildings, mobile units and manufactured units, used for construction purposes, sales or similar purposes for a period not to extend beyond the completion date of such construction or three years, whichever occurs first. After three years of the date of issuance of the special use permit required herein, a renewal of said special use permit is required, which shall require the same application, fees and process as any special use permit. 
2.3. Height of buildings. The maximum height of buildings permitted shall be as follows: 
2.3-1. One-family detached dwellings. Not to exceed 40 feet, or three and one-half stories, whichever is lower. 
2.3-2. Churches. One hundred feet for towers or steeples, but not more than 70 feet for the main structure. 
2.3-3. Garages, freestanding; accessory structures. See article VII. 
2.4. Lot size. 
2.4-1. Every one-family residence hereafter erected or structurally altered shall be on a lot having an area of not less than 10,000 square feet and width at the established building line of not less than 75 feet, except as provided in article V. 
2.4-2. Churches, convents and monasteries hereafter erected or structurally altered shall be on a lot having an area of not less than 15,000 square feet and a width at the building line of not less than 80 feet. 
2.5. Yard areas. No building shall be erected or enlarged unless the following yards are provided and maintained in connection with such building, structure or enlargement. 
2.5-1. Front yard. Each lot upon which a dwelling or permitted nonresidential use is constructed shall have a front yard of not less than 25 feet. Where lots comprising 40 percent or more of the frontage between two intersecting streets are developed with buildings having front yards with a variation of not more than 15 feet in depth, the average of front yards shall establish the minimum front yard depth for the entire frontage. In no case shall a front yard of more than 40 feet be required. 
2.5-2. Side yards. On each lot upon which a dwelling is constructed there shall be a side yard on each side equal to not less than eight feet. The combined total of the side yards on interior lots shall not be less than 16 feet. On corner lots there shall be maintained a side yard of not less than 25 feet on the side adjacent to the street which intersects the street upon which the building or structure maintains frontage, and in the case of a reversed corner lot, there shall be maintained a setback from the side street of not less than 25 feet. No accessory building on said reverse corner lot shall project beyond the front yard required on the adjacent lot to the rear. No accessory building shall be located nearer than five feet to the side lot line of said adjacent lot and five feet to the rear lot line. 
On lots upon which a church is constructed or extensions made to an existing church, there shall be a side yard of not less than ten feet on each side of the main structure and a combined total of side yards of not less than 25 feet. 
2.5-3. Rear yard. Every lot or parcel of land upon which a building is constructed shall have a rear yard of not less than 30 feet. On a reversed corner lot, the rear yard shall not be less than the side yard setback of the adjacent property (eight feet). 
2.5-4. Lot coverage. Not more than 35 percent of any lot may be occupied by buildings or structures, including accessory buildings. 
2.5-5. Permitted obstructions. The following obstructions shall be permitted when located between the building setback line and the property boundary line: 
(a)  Terraces; 
(b)  Awnings and canopies; 
(c)  Chimneys, not projecting more than two feet; 
(d)  Steps not over four feet in height; 
(e)  Arbors and trellises; 
(f)  Fences or walls (rear yards only) (see fence regulations in chapter 7, "Buildings and Building Regulations," of the Code of Ordinances); 
(g)  Breezeways and open porches (rear yards only); 
(h)  Driveways (see article V, section 16). 
2.6. Home occupations. 
2.6-1. Home occupations shall not employ any person that is not a member of the immediate family living on the premises. 
2.6-2. There shall be no exterior display or except as allowed by the sign regulations for the district in which such home occupation is located, and there shall be no exterior storage of equipment or materials used in connection with the home occupation. 
2.6-3. Any need for parking generated by the occupation shall be met off the street and other than in a front or corner side yard. 
2.6-4. No home occupation shall involve construction features or the use of electrical mechanical equipment that would change the fire rating of the structure or of the fire district in which the structure is located. 
2.6-5. Home occupations may include, among others: 
(a)  Art or crafts studio. 
(b)  Day care center, child or adult. 
(c)  Day care home. 
(d)  Family care home for the developmentally disabled. 
(e)  Foster family home. 
(f)  Senior citizens home. 
(g)  Home for the aged. 
(h)  Intermediate care facilities. 
(i)  Dressmaking. 
(j)  Teaching or tutoring, limited to one pupil at a time except for occasional groups. 
(k)  Authors or composers. 
(l)  Offices of a professional person such as clergyman, attorney, physician, architect, engineer, accountant or other administrator. 
2.6-6. Home occupations shall not include: 
(a)  Any wholesale or retail business that involves the use of commercial vehicles for delivery of materials to or from the premises. 
(b)  Any manufacturing or processing operation. 
(c)  Any repair or service establishment. 
(d)  A stable or kennel. 
(e)  A restaurant. 
(f)  A clinic or hospital. 
(g)  A mortuary. 
(h)  A private club. 
(i)  The renting of trailers. 
(j)  A tourist home. 
(k)  Any activity that creates noise, fumes, odor, dust, electrical interference or pedestrian or vehicular traffic that is more than normal for the area in which it is located. 
2.7. Storage of trucks and recreational vehicles. A single recreational vehicle as defined herein may be parked or stored on a lot in a residential district provided that: 
2.7-1. It is at no time occupied for living or sleeping purposes. 
2.7-2. It is not connected to natural gas, water or sanitary sewer service. 
2.7-3. It is stored in its collapsed position if it is a vehicle of the collapsible type not stored in a garage. 
2.7-4. It is parked or stored in a location determined by the following: 
(a)  In a garage or carport, where one exists on the premises large enough to accommodate the vehicle. 
(b)  Otherwise, in the driveway to the rear of the principal building line that is parallel or most nearly parallel to the street to which the driveway extending to the rear of this line. 
2.8. Parking. See Chapter 19 of the Bourbonnais Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 95-1060, § 4, 8-7-95; Ord. No. 04-1444, §§ 1a.-2d., 10-18-04; Ord. No. 05-1519, § 1, 8-1-05; Ord. No. 05-1526, §§ 14, 16, 10-3-05; Ord. No. 07-1684, § 1, 2-5-07; Ord. No. 08-1770, § 2, 5-5-08; Ord. No. 08-1783, § 2, 7-21-08; Ord. No. 06-1657, § 2, 5-15-06) 
Sec. 3. - R-2 one-family residence district. 
3.1. Permitted uses. Any use permitted in the R-1 one-family residence district. 
3.2. Special uses. Any use permitted as a special use in the R-1 one-family residence district may be permitted in any R-2 district in accordance with the provisions of article XV. 
3.3. Height of buildings. The same regulations shall apply as required or permitted in the R-1 one-family residence district. 
3.4. Lot size. Every one-family detached dwelling hereafter erected or structurally altered shall be on a lot having an area of not less than 7,500 square feet and a width at the established building line of not less than 70 feet, except as provided in article V. 
3.5. Yard areas. No building shall be erected or enlarged unless the following yards are provided and maintained in connection with such building, structure or enlargement. 
3.5-1. Front yard. The same regulations shall apply as required or permitted in the R-1 one-family residence district. 
3.5-2. Side yards. On each lot upon which a dwelling is constructed there shall be a side yard on each side equal to not less than eight feet. The combined total of the side yards on interior lots shall not be less than 16 feet. On corner lots there shall be maintained a side yard of not less than 25 feet on the side adjacent to the street which intersects the street upon which the building or structure maintains frontage, and in the case of a reversed corner there shall be maintained a setback from the side street of not less than 25 feet. No accessory building on said reversed corner lot shall project beyond the front yard required on the adjacent lot to the rear. No accessory building shall be located nearer than five feet to the side lot line of said adjacent lot and five feet to the rear lot line. 
On lots upon which a church is constructed or extensions made to an existing church, the same regulations shall apply as permitted or required in the R-1 one-family residence district. 
3.5-3. Rear yard. Every lot or parcel of land upon which a building is constructed shall have a rear yard of not less than 30 feet. 
3.5-4. Lot coverage. The same regulations shall apply as permitted or required in the R-1 one-family residence district. 
3.5-5. Permitted obstructions. The same regulations shall apply as permitted or required in the R-1 one-family residence district. 
3.5-6. Storage of trucks and recreational vehicles. The same regulations shall apply as permitted or required in the R-1 one-family residence district. 
(Ord. No. 04-1441, § 5, 9-20-04) 
Sec. 4. - R-3 one-family residence district. 
4.1. Permitted uses. Any permitted uses in the R-1 one-family residence district as well as manufactured homes, manufactured housing, and other single-family housing and dwelling units. 
4.2. Special uses. Any use permitted as a special use in the R-1 one-family residence district may be permitted in the R-3 district in accordance with the provisions of article XV. 
4.3. Height of buildings. The same regulations shall apply as required or permitted in the R-1 one-family residence district. 
4.4. Lot size. Every one-family detached dwelling hereafter erected or structurally altered shall be on a lot having an area of not less than 6,000 square feet and a width at the established building line of not less than 50 feet, except as provided in article V. 
4.5. Yard areas. No building shall be erected or enlarged unless the following yards are provided and maintained in connection with such building, structure or enlargement. 
4.5-1. Front yard. Each lot upon which a dwelling is erected shall have a front yard of not less than 25 feet. When lots comprising 40 percent or more of the frontage between two parallel streets located on the same intersecting street are developed, there shall be a front yard building setback line with a variation of not more than 15 feet in depth. 
4.5-2. Side yards. On each lot upon which a dwelling is constructed there shall be a side yard on each side equal to not less than six feet. The combined total of the side yard on interior lots shall not be less than 12 feet. No accessory building on a reversed corner lot shall project beyond the front yard required on the adjacent lot to the rear, side lot line of said adjacent lot. On lots upon which a church is constructed or extensions made to an existing church, the same regulations shall apply as permitted or required in the R-1 one-family residence district. 
4.5-3. Rear yard. Every lot or parcel of land upon which a building is constructed shall have a rear yard of not less than 25 feet. 
4.5-4. Lot coverage. The same regulations shall apply as permitted or required in the R-1 one-family residence district. 
4.5-5. Permitted obstructions. The same regulations shall apply as permitted or required in the R-1 one-family residence district. 
(Ord. No. 95-1060, § 5, 8-7-95) 
Sec. 5. - R-4 two-family residence district. 
5.1. Permitted uses. The following uses are permitted: 
(a)  Any use permitted in the R-1 one-family residence district. 
(b)  Two-family dwellings. 
(c)  Small community residence, provided: 
(i)  They are located not less than 600 feet from another small community residence; provided, however, that up to two such residences may be located on the same zoning lot; and 
(ii)  Prior to occupancy, a certificate of zoning compliance is applied for and received. 
(d)  Duplex condominiums (see definitions "Condominiums-Two-family). 
5.2. Special uses. 
(a)  Any use which may be allowed as a special use in the R-1 one-family residence district, in accordance with the provisions of article XV. 
(b)  Reserved. 
5.3. Transitional uses. Principal offices of physicians, dentists, attorneys, architects, real estate brokers, and other professional occupations, when located in a residential structure used primarily as a home and when located on lots having a side line adjoining a lot in a business or manufacturing district, or adjacent to a railroad right-of-way, or when facing a business or manufacturing district, or a railroad right-of-way directly across a street or alley, provided that: 
(a)  The lot on which the transitional use is located does not extend more than 75 feet from the adjoining business or manufacturing district, or more than 120 feet in depth from the street line in cases where the lot does not adjoin but faces a business or manufacturing district. 
(b)  The home occupations are conducted in conjunction with the use of a dwelling unit as a home by the occupant thereof, with not more than two employees other than members of the related family, and that the residential character of the exterior of the dwelling is not changed. Medical clinics are not included or permitted. 
5.4. Automobile parking facilities. Automobile parking facilities shall be provided as required or permitted in this chapter. 
5.5. Lot size. 
(a)  Lot size. Every one family detached dwelling hereinafter erected shall be located on a lot having an area of not less than 7,500 square feet, and a width at the established building line of not less than 70 feet, except as provided in article V. 
(b)  Every two-family dwelling hereafter erected shall be located on a zoning lot having a minimum area of not less than 10,000 square feet, and a minimum lot width of not less than 70 feet at the established building line, provided that where a lot has less width than required herein, and was recorded under separate ownership from adjoining lots prior to the adoption of the ordinance, such lot may be occupied by a two-family dwelling, but in no case shall the lot area per dwelling unit be less than 3,000 square feet. 
(c)  All nonresidential principal uses, as permitted in this section, shall be located on a tract of land having an area of not less than 10,000 square feet and a width of not less than 75 feet at the established line. 
(d)  Minimum lot sizes for special uses shall be prescribed at the time the special use permit is authorized, but in no case shall it be less than 10,000 square feet in area. 
5.6. Yard areas. No building shall be erected or enlarged unless the following yards are provided and maintained: 
Front yards. Each lot upon which a dwelling is erected shall have a front yard of not less than 25 feet. When lots comprising 40 percent or more of the frontage between two parallel streets located on the same intersecting street are developed, there shall be a front yard building setback line with a variation of not more than 15 feet in depth. 
5.6-2. Side yards. On each lot upon which a dwelling is constructed there shall be a side yard on each side equal to not less than eight feet of the width of the lot, the combined total of the side yards on interior lots shall not be less than 16 feet. No accessory building on a reversed corner lot shall project beyond the front yard required on the adjacent lot to the rear, nor be located nearer than five feet to the side lot line of said adjacent lot. 
5.6-3. Rear yards. Every lot or parcel of land upon which a building is constructed shall have a rear yard of not less than 25 feet. On a reversed corner lot, the rear yard shall not be less than the side yard setback. 
5.7. Height of buildings. The same regulations shall apply as required or permitted in the R-1 one-family residence district. 
5.8. Lot coverage. The same regulations shall apply as required or permitted in the R-1 one-family residence district. 
5.9. Permitted obstructions. The same regulations shall apply as required or permitted in the R-1 one-family residence district. 
(Ord. No. 95-1060, § 6, 8-7-95; Ord. No. 05-1482, §§ 1-3, 1-3-05) 
Sec. 6. - R-5 multiple-family residence district. 
6.1. Permitted uses. 
(a)  Any use permitted in the R-1 one-family residence district. 
(b)  Boarding and lodging houses. 
(c)  Multiple-family dwellings and apartments. 
(d)  One-family row dwellings (party-wall type). 
(e)  Two-family dwellings. 
(f)  Converted dwellings. 
(g)  Small community residences, provided: 
(i)  They are located not less than 600 feet from another small community residence; provided, however, that up to two such residences may be located on the same zoning lot; and 
(ii)  Prior to occupancy, a certificate of zoning compliance is applied for and received. 
(h)  Nursing homes. 
(i)  Community residences of up to ten persons, provided: 
(i)  They are located not less than 600 feet from another community residence; and, 
(ii)  Prior to occupancy, a certificate of zoning compliance is applied for and received. 
(j)  Condominiums, multifamily, see definitions. 
6.2. Transitional uses. See "transitional uses" as permitted in R-4 two-family residence district. 
6.3. Special uses. The following uses may be allowed by special use permit in accordance with the provisions of article XV. 
(a)  Any use which may be allowed as a special use in the R-1 one-family residence district. 
(b)  Reserved. 
(c)  Off-street public parking areas and garages, provided there is a need for this facility and that no appropriate site is available in nearby business or manufacturing districts. 
(d)  Public buildings, including art galleries, libraries, museums or similar structures. 
(e)  Telephone exchanges, antenna towers and other outdoor equipment essential to the operation of the exchange. 
(f)  Tourist homes having no more than five rooms for transient guests. 
6.4. Height of buildings. No building shall hereafter be erected or structurally altered to exceed three and one-half stories or 40 feet, whichever is lower. 
6.5. Automobile parking facilities. Automobile parking facilities shall be provided as required or permitted in this chapter. Parking and/or free standing garages are not permitted in the front yard. 
6.6. Lot size. 
6.6-1. One-family dwellings. The same regulations shall apply as required or permitted in the R-2 one-family residence district. 
6.6-2. Two-family dwellings. Every two-family dwelling hereafter erected or structurally altered shall be on a lot having an area of not less than 7,500 square feet and a width at the building line of not less than 70 feet, except as provided in article V. 
6.6-3. Multiple family dwellings and apartments. Every multiple family dwelling or apartment building hereafter erected or structurally altered shall be on a lot having an area of not less than 10,000 square feet, or 2,500 square feet per dwelling unit, whichever is higher, and a width at the building line of not less than 60 feet, except as provided in article V. 
6.6-4. Converted dwellings. An existing one-family dwelling located on a lot of less area than required in this section may be converted to a two-family dwelling without increasing the lot size, provided that the building is not enlarged beyond its present outside dimensions and that all other regulations of this ordinance are complied with. Additions may be made to an existing building only when lot size and yard requirements of this section are complied with. 
6.6-5. Churches, convents and monasteries. The same regulations shall apply as required or permitted in the R-1 districts. 
6.7. Yard areas. No building shall be erected or enlarged unless the following yards are provided and maintained in connection with such building, structure or enlargement. 
6.7-1. Front yard. The same regulations shall apply as required or permitted in the R-2 districts. 
6.7-2. Side yards. 
(a)  One-family detached dwellings. The same regulations shall apply as required or permitted in the R-2 districts. 
(b)  Two-family dwellings. The same regulations shall apply as required or permitted for one-family detached dwellings. 
(c)  Multiple-family dwellings and apartments. On interior lots there shall be a side yard on each side of a main building of not less than eight feet and a combined total of side yards of not less than 16 feet for all multiple-family dwellings and apartments of not more than two stories in height. For each additional story added above the two stories, the side yard on each side of the main building shall be increased by two feet in width. No accessory building on a reversed corner lot shall project beyond the front yard line required on the key lot in the rear, nor be located nearer than five feet to the side lot line of such key lot. 
(d)  Converted dwellings. An existing one-family dwelling located on a lot having side yards of less width than required herein may be converted to a two-family dwelling, provided that the building is not enlarged beyond its present outside dimensions. 
6.7-3. Rear yard. Every lot or parcel of land upon which a building is constructed shall have a rear yard of not less than 25 feet. 
6.7-4. Lot coverage. 
(a)  The same regulations shall apply as permitted or required in the R-1 one-family residence district. 
(b)  Not less than 20 percent of the lot shall be preserved as green space. 
6.7-5. Permitted obstructions. The same regulations shall apply as required or permitted in the R-1 residence districts. 
6.7-6. Minimum dwelling unit size. All dwelling units hereinafter constructed in the village shall have the following minimum size: 
Studio or one bedroom 750 square feet Two bedroom 850 square feet Three or more bedrooms 1,000 square feet   
For the purpose of this article, a dwelling unit is defined as a building, or portion thereof, but not including a house trailer or mobile home, designed or used exclusively for residential occupancy, including one-family dwelling units, two-family dwelling units, and multiple-family dwelling units, but not including hotels, motels, boarding or lodging houses. 
6.7-7. Minimum number of bathrooms. All dwelling units hereinafter constructed in the village shall have the following minimum number of bathrooms: 
Studio or one bedroom One bath Two bedrooms One bath Three or more bedrooms One and one-half baths  
For the purpose of this article, a bathroom is defined as a room containing a sink, water closet, and a bathtub or shower. A one-half bath is defined as a room containing a water closet and sink, but not a bathtub or shower. 
6.8. Exterior materials. All multi family buildings hereinafter constructed or structurally altered in the village shall have not less than 50 percent brick, stone or exposed aggregate or a combination of same on all exterior walls of the building. 
(Ord. No. 95-1060, §§ 7-9, 8-7-95; Ord. No. 98-1162, §§ 1-3, 10-19-98; Ord. No. 04-1441, §§ 6-10, 9-20-04; Ord. No. 05-1526, § 15, 10-3-05) 
Sec. 7. - R-6 mobile home residence district. 
7.1.  Definitions. 
    Mobile home. See "manufactured home" as defined in article III of the zoning code. 
    Mobile home park. See "manufactured home park" as defined in article III of the zoning code. 
7.2.  Mobile home park as planned unit development. Mobile home park districts shall be developed and processed as a planned unit development provided, however, that the construction of all streets within a mobile home park shall conform to the standards and specifications of the village, as required by section 30.8 of the subdivision ordinance. 
7.3.  Minimum and maximum size of mobile home parks. Mobile home parks shall be not less than five acres nor more than 100 acres in size. 
7.4.  Permitted uses. Any use permitted as a permitted use in the R-1 one-family residence district shall be considered a permitted use in a mobile home park district. 
7.5.  Special uses. Any use permitted as a special use in the R-2 one-family residence district may be allowed as a special use in the mobile home park district. 
7.6.  Height of buildings. The maximum height of buildings permitted shall be as follows: 
(a)  One-family detached dwelling. Not to exceed 25 feet, or two and one-half stories, whichever is less. 
(b)  Churches. One hundred feet for towers or steeples, but not more than 70 feet for the main structure. 
(c)  Garages, freestanding, accessory structures. See article VII, Accessory Buildings herein. 
7.7.  Lot size. Every one-family dwelling hereinafter erected, placed on site, or structurally altered shall be on a lot having an area of not less than 7,500 square feet, and a width at the established building line of not less than 70 feet. 
7.8.  Yard areas. No building shall be erected, placed on site, or structurally altered unless the following yards are provided and maintained in connection with such buildings, structure or enlargement: 
(a)  Front yard. Each lot upon which a dwelling is erected, placed on site, or structurally altered, shall have a front yard of not less than 25 feet. When lots comprising 40 percent or more of the frontage between two parallel streets located on the same intersecting street are developed, there shall be a front yard building setback line with a variation of not more than 15 feet in depth. 
(b)  Side yards. On each lot upon which a dwelling is erected, placed on site, or structurally altered, there shall be a side yard on each side equal to not less than eight feet. The combined total of the side yard on interior lots shall not be less than 16 feet. No accessory building on a reversed corner lot shall project beyond the front yard required on the adjacent lot to the rear. No accessory building shall be located nearer than five feet to the side lot line of said adjacent lot. On lots upon which a church is constructed, placed on site or structurally altered, the same regulations shall apply, as permitted or required in the R-1 one-family residence district. 
(c)  Rear yards. Every lot or parcel of land upon which a building is constructed, placed on site or structurally altered, shall have a rear yard of not less than 30 feet. 
(d)  Buffer yard. There shall be provided a 25-foot landscaped buffer yard, as approved by the planning commission, around the perimeter of all mobile home parks hereinafter developed. This buffer yard shall be in addition to any other setback or yard area requirement. 
(e)  Lot coverage. No more than 40 percent of any lot may be occupied by buildings or structures, including accessory buildings. 
(f)  Permitted obstructions. The following obstructions shall be permitted when located between the building setback line and the property boundary line: 
(1)  Terraces; 
(2)  Chimneys, not projecting more than two feet; 
(3)  Steps not over four feet in height; 
(4)  Arbors and trellises; 
(5)  Fences or walls (rear yards only) (see fencing regulations in chapter 7 "Buildings and Building Regulations" of the Code of Ordinances); 
(6)  Driveways (see article V, section 26, General Provisions, Parking of vehicles). 
7.9.  Development standards for mobile home parks. 
(a)  General provisions. 
1.  No mobile home park shall be located in an area where the conditions of soil, groundwater level, drainage or topography may cause hazard to the property, health or safety of the occupants. 
2.  No mobile home park shall be located such that is exposed to objectionable smoke, dust, noise, odors, vibrations or other adverse influences. 
3.  Ingress and egress to a mobile home park shall be provided in such a manner [so as] to facilitate access by emergency vehicles, and should be designed to provide efficient and safe traffic circulation in the vicinity. 
4.  No part of any mobile home park shall be used for nonresidential purposes except accessory uses that are required to directly serve mobile home park. 
(b)  Size, density of mobile home parks. The total density of any mobile home park shall not exceed five units per acre. Existing mobile home parks may be altered to bring such parks into conformity with this subsection. However, no additions or alterations may be made to any existing mobile home park unless such additions or alterations are in conformity with this subsection and unless the total area of the mobile home park, with such additions or alterations, consists of at least three acres of 24 mobile home sites and provided further that such additions or alteration to any mobile home park shall contain not more than four mobile home sites for each gross acre of land. 
(c)  Compliance with building codes. The mobile home shall be constructed so as to conform with the applicable standards and specifications of the village. 
(d)  Tenant storage. Storage facilities shall be provided on or conveniently near each mobile [home] site for the active storage of outdoor equipment, furniture, or tools and for the inactive storage of such other materials as are used only seasonally or infrequently by the tenant and which cannot be conveniently stored in a typical mobile home. There shall be a minimum of 90 square feet provided for general storage for each mobile home site. Storage facilities shall be designed in a manner that will enhance the appearance of the park and shall be constructed of suitable weather resistant materials appropriate for that use and maintenance contemplated. 
(e)  Streets and walks. The construction of all streets within the mobile home park shall conform to the standards and specifications of the village, as required in section 30.8 of the subdivision ordinance. In order to minimize wind forces, every attempt shall be made to provide for curvilinear street layout and design. The construction of all sidewalks, as required, shall be made in conformity with the standards and specifications of the village. Individual walkways to each mobile home shall be provided, extending from the adjacent parking areas and in conformity with the standards and specifications of the village. 
(f)  Public utilities. All utilities shall be located underground as required in the village's subdivision ordinance. Each mobile home shall be connected to public water and sewer facilities and natural gas lines. Gas storage tanks, including tanks storing propane, shall not be permitted. 
(g)  [Off-street parking.] Off-street parking shall be provided as required in article VIII of the Village Code of Ordinances. 
(h)  [Nonroadway improvements.] Streetlights, parkway trees and other nonroadway improvements shall be provided as required by the village's subdivision ordinance. 
(i)  Park site donation. Prior to the approval of any planned unit development for any mobile home park hereinafter located within the village, or within one and one-half miles thereof, the owner of said mobile home park shall comply with the provisions of subsection 30-8(g) of the village's subdivision ordinance regarding park site donations. 
(j)  Additions to mobile homes. No permanent structure shall be affixed to any mobile home, except for a canopy or awning, garage, carport, breezeway, or other structure designed for nonhabitable use with particular mobile home. 
(k)  Community facility/emergency shelter. The owner of each mobile home park hereinafter approved for development with the village shall, upon the placement of 25 or more mobile homes, have constructed within the mobile home park a community facility/ emergency shelter. Said buildings shall have an occupancy of not less than 50 percent of the number of residents residing in the mobile home park. Upon the placement of any additional mobile homes, capacity of said community facility/emergency shelter shall be expanded as required herein. 
(l)  Emergency warning system. The owner of each mobile home park hereinafter approved for developing within the village shall install and dedicate to the village an emergency warning system of such design as required by village standards and specifications. 
(m)  Mobile home site requirements. A minimum of two improved off-street paved parking spaces shall be provided for each mobile home site. 
(n)  Street requirements. 
1.  All mobile home parks shall be provided with adequate, safe, and convenient vehicular access from abutting public streets. 
2.  All mobile home parks shall have at lease two entrances/exits to public streets. 
3.  Public street dedications within or abutting mobile home parks shall be made in accordance with the village's subdivision ordinance. 
4.  Entrance drives into mobile home parks shall have direct access to a public street and shall be designed to have free traffic flow onto such public streets. No parking or mobile home lot access driveway shall be permitted off an entrance drive for a distance of 50 feet from a public right-of-way. 
5.  Minimum pavement widths for private streets shall be in accordance with the village's subdivision regulations. All dimensions are exclusive of parking areas. 
6.  With respect to paving materials, curbs and gutters, grading, intersections, off sets, and radii of curvature, the provisions of the village's subdivision ordinance shall apply to private streets. 
7.10.  Utilities and required services. 
(a)  Water supply and distribution systems. 
1.  All mobile homes shall be furnished with a municipal public supply of water. 
2.  All other applicable minimum requirements of the Illinois State Department of Public Health must be met. 
(b)  Sewage systems. 
1.  All mobile homes shall be supplied with a municipal public sewerage collection system. 
2.  All other applicable minimum requirements of the Illinois State Department of Public Health must be met. 
7.11.  Solid waste disposal. 
(a)  All refuse shall be stored in water-tight containers located on each mobile home site or within 150 feet thereof. 
(b)  Refuse shall be collected once per week and transported to a disposal site in compliance with state law. Incineration of any refuse or vegetation within a mobile home park is prohibited. 
(c)  All other applicable minimum requirements of the Illinois State Department of Public Health must be met. 
7.12.  Fire protection. 
(a)  Mobile home parks shall be kept free of all litter, rubbish or other accumulated flammable materials. 
(b)  Approved fire hydrants shall be located throughout the mobile home park and shall be located not more than 500 feet from any mobile home. The hydrants shall deliver a minimum of 75 gallons of water per minute at a pressure of 20 pounds per square inch at the highest elevation point of the mobile home park. 
(Ord. No. 02-1284, § 2, 2-19-02; Ord. No. 05-1526, § 17, 10-3-05) 
ARTICLE XI. - BUSINESS DISTRICTS 

Sec. 1. - Purpose. 
    The business districts set forth herein are established to protect the public health, to promote public safety, comfort, convenience, and the general welfare, and to protect the economic base of the village and the value of property. These general purposes include, among others, the following specific objectives: 
1.1. To promote the most desirable use of land in accordance with a well-considered plan so that adequate space is provided in appropriate locations for the various types of business uses, thereby protecting and strengthening the economic base of the village. 
1.2. To place in separate districts those businesses which may create noise, odors, hazards, unsightliness, or which may generate excessive traffic. 
1.3. To permit selected business uses in districts where adjacent to or inclusion in a residential area has sufficient elements of service or convenience to such areas as to offset the disadvantage. 
1.4. To encourage the grouping in appropriate locations of compatible business uses which will tend to draw trade that is mutually interchangeable and so promote public convenience and business prosperity and contribute to the alleviation of traffic and pedestrian congestion. 
1.5. To provide for the establishment of off-street parking facilities, permitted and required, so as to alleviate traffic congestion and so promote shopping convenience and business prosperity. 
Sec. 2. - B-1 business district, limited retail. 
2.1. Permitted uses. 
(a)  Antique shops. 
(b)  Air conditioning and heating sales. 
(c)  Art shops or galleries, not including auction rooms. 
(d)  Art and school supply stores. 
(e)  Automated teller machines. 
(f)  Baker shops, including the baking and processing of food products, when prepared for retail use on the premises only. 
(g)  Banks, savings and loans, and financial institutions. 
(h)  Barbershops, beauty parlors, hairstyling salons, massage or similar personal service shops. 
(i)  Bicycle sales, rental and repair shops. 
(j)  Blueprinting and photostating establishments. 
(k)  Book and stationery stores (except adult bookstores). 
(l)  Reserved. 
(m)  Business machine sales, rental and service, including computer stores. 
(n)  Candy, ice cream, popcorn, nut and yogurt stores. 
(o)  Camera and photographic supply shops for retail sale. 
(p)  Card and gift shops. 
(q)  Carpet, rug and linoleum stores for retail sale. 
(r)  Catering establishments. 
(s)  China and glassware stores. 
(t)  Clothing, shoe, hat, and shoe repair stores and tailor shops. 
(u)  Coin and philatelic stores. 
(v)  Convenience food stores. 
(w)  Costume rental shops. 
(x)  Custom dressmaking establishments. 
(y)  Currency exchanges. 
(z)  Department stores and discount department stores. 
(aa)  Drug stores. 
(bb)  Dry cleaners and laundries (processing to be done off-site) and laundromats. 
(cc)  Dry goods stores. 
(dd)  Electrical appliance stores and repairs, but not including appliance assembly or manufacturing. 
(ee)  Employment agencies. 
(ff)  Florist shops. 
(gg)  Food and grocery stores. 
(hh)  Frozen food stores and food lockers. 
(ii)  Furnace supply and service. 
(jj)  Furniture stores, and upholstery when conducted as part of the retail operations and secondary to the main use. 
(kk)  Furriers, when conducted for retail trade on the premises only. 
(ll)  Gift shops. 
(mm)  Hardware stores. 
(nn)  Haberdashery shops. 
(oo)  Health clubs as defined herein. 
(pp)  Hobby shops and craft shops. 
(qq)  Household appliance stores, including radio, television, stereo, video, lighting, clock and music. 
(rr)  Insurance offices.

(ggg) Paint and wallpaper stores.

(iii) Phonographic, record, tape, compact disc, sheet music, and video stores.

(zzz) Ticket agencies and sales, theater and/or amusement. 
(aaaa) Toy stores. 
(bbbb) Travel bureaus and transportation ticket offices. 
(cccc) Variety stores. 
(dddd) Yard goods and sewing material stores. 
(eeee) Any other similar type retail store not specifically listed herein that is economically compatible with the established uses on adjoining property. 
(ffff) Water towers, water reservoirs, sewer lift stations if underground for consumer use in all districts with engineering design and location. 
(gggg) Bed and breakfast facilities, as defined in article III, Definitions, herein. 
(hhhh) Live entertainment, as defined in article III herein, and as regulated under chapter 18 of the Municipal Code, provided however: 
1.  That these regulations shall not apply to "auditoriums, stadiums, arenas, armories, gymnasiums and other similar places of public events," as permitted in article VI, subsection 2.2 (b) herein; 
2.  That all live entertainment shall be restricted to indoor areas only; 
3.  That the area designated for live entertainment shall not exceed 25 percent of the gross floor area of the primary use; 
4.  That required off-street parking shall be increased by 25 percent over that which would otherwise have been required; 
5.  That hours for live entertainment shall be limited to 11:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m. Sunday through Thursday, and 11:00 a.m. to 12 midnight Friday and Saturday; 
6.  Reserved; 
7.  That live entertainment, as noted herein, shall not include "adult business uses", as defined in article III herein, and regulated under the provisions of article V, section 18, and article XII, section 3.1 herein. 
(iiii) Village-owned and -operated police or emergency services communication towers not to exceed 170 feet in height. 
All activities, except for automobile off-street parking facilities as permitted or required in this B-1 district shall be conducted wholly in an enclosed building. 
2.2. Special uses. The following uses may be allowed by special use permit in accordance with the provisions of Article XV. 
(a) Animal hospitals, small, completely contained. 
(b)  Auditoriums, stadiums, arenas, armories, gymnasiums, and other similar places of public events. 
(c) Automobile parts and accessory stores. 
(d) Clubs and lodges (nonprofit), fraternal or religious institutions. 
(e) Commercial schools for music, dance or business. 
(f) Day care centers provided: 
1.  Said day care center is fully compliant with all applicable state and federal regulations. 
2.  Any outside play area is located at least 15 feet from any street or parking lot, and is fully enclosed by a fence having a height of not less than four feet. 
(g) Drive-in establishments as defined herein. 
(h) Dwelling units, provided they are located above the first floor and above a permitted business. Dwelling units shall not be permitted on the ground floor of business buildings, or in the rear of business establishments on the ground floor: 
(i)  Electric substations. 
(j)  Hospitals. 
(k)  Reserved. 
(l)  Kiosks. 
(m)  Meeting halls. 
(n)  Mortuaries. 
(o)  Municipal, police and fire stations. 
(p)  Reserved. 
(q)  Pet shops, including grooming. 
(r)  Planned unit developments for business. 
(s)  Public libraries. 
(t)  Radio and television broadcasting stations. 
(u)  Reserved. 
(v)  Telephone exchanges and offices, antenna towers and other outdoor equipment essential to the operation of the exchange in the interest of the public convenience and necessity. 
(w) Nursing homes. 
(x) Automobile rental agencies, provided: 
(i)  Said use is limited to passenger vehicles, and expressly prohibits trucks (in excess of one-ton), buses and farm implements; (bold face provided to denote change) 
(ii)  Said use expressly prohibits motor vehicles repairs and sales 
(y) Off street parking lots and public garages, but not including storage garages. 
(z) Accessory buildings, as defined herein, as regulated by article VII, and as further regulated as follows: 
a.  Said building shall be of masonry construction and alarmed; 
b.  Said building shall not exceed a maximum size of 25 feet × 40 feet, or 1,000 square feet; 
c.  Said building shall not exceed a maximum height of one story, or 20 feet; 
d.  Said building shall have a pitched, gable or hip roof; flat roofs are hereby prohibited; 
e.  Said building shall not be any closer than five feet to any adjoining lot line; 
f.  Said building shall not be located within, nor infringe with any drainage or utility easement; 
g.  Said building shall meet all required building, plumbing and electrical codes, provided however, that no washroom facilities, bath, lavatory, powder room, restroom, sauna, shower, shower room, spa, steam room, toilet, washroom or water closets shall be allowed within the structure; 
h.  Said building shall have gutters and downspouts; 
i.  There is hereby prohibited within the building the storage of any combustible materials, hazardous waste, and/or flammable liquids; 
j.  N [No] living areas shall be allowed in the garage, nor shall any person or persons be allowed to live therein, rent, or otherwise use the building or any part thereof as any form of residence; 
k.  The structure shall not be used for the repair or servicing of automobiles, vehicles, trucks or motorcycles; 
l.  The site plan for the development shall be reviewed by the Village's Engineer and the placement and location of the free standing garage must be taken into consideration with respect to any drainage issues and/or requirements; 
(aa) Restaurants, including those possessing a valid class B or C liquor license, but specifically excluding and prohibiting a class A liquor license, as defined herein. 
2.3. Height of buildings. No building or structure shall be erected or structurally altered to exceed a height of four stories nor shall it exceed 50 feet in height. Parapet walls, chimneys, cooling towers, elevator bulkheads, stacks, and necessary mechanical appurtenances may be erected over and above the maximum height of 35 feet, provided they are constructed in accordance with all other ordinances of the village. 
2.4. Yard areas. No building shall be constructed or enlarged unless the following yards are provided and maintained in connection with such building. 
2.4-1. Front yard. No front yard shall be required when all frontage between two intersecting streets lies within this district. However, when lots within this district are adjacent to and adjoining lots in a residence district, all of which front upon the same street between two intersecting streets, there shall be established the same front yard setback for all of the frontage as had been established in the residence district. 
Exception. When existing buildings located in this district have already established a building line at the street line at a depth less than required above, then all new buildings may conform to the same building line, except for the first 50 feet of the B-1 district frontage adjacent to the residence district, whereupon there shall be provided a front setback of not less than ten feet. 
2.4-2. Side yard. No side yard is required, except for a corner lot which abuts upon a residence district or upon an alley separating this district from a residence district. There shall then be provided a side yard equal to one-half the front yard required in the abutting residence district, but in no case more than ten feet. The setback shall also apply if the business buildings front the intersecting street, commonly referred to as the "side street." 
2.4-3. Rear yard. There shall be a rear yard of not less than 20 feet, provided, however, a one-story accessory building may be located thereon, except for the five feet adjacent and parallel to the rear lot line or alley line for the storage of motor vehicles and the unloading and loading of vehicles under roof, as provided in article V. 
2.5. Parking. Parking facilities shall be provided as required or permitted in this Ordinance. 
2.6. Performance standards. All activities as allowed in the B-1 district, whether as a permitted use, special use, or use variance, shall comply with the performance standards as noted in article XII, section 2.6 herein.

Exception. There shall then be provided a side yard equal to one-half the front yard required in the abutting residence district, but in no case more than ten feet. The setback shall also apply if the business buildings front the intersecting street, commonly referred to as the "side street."

3.7 [Site of permitted, special uses.] All permitted uses and special uses allowed pursuant to the B-2 Business District zoning regulations shall be wholly conducted within a permanent, enclosed building, with the exception of automobile off-street parking facilities permitted or required in this B-2 Business District.

Sec. 4. - U-1 university zoning district. 
    Purpose and intent. The university district is intended as a zoning designation applied to an area which includes a college or university and related ancillary uses held under single ownership, affiliated ownership or leasehold where controlled by the university by at least 51 percent controlling interest. The university district is further designed to allow and encourage the flexible, yet orderly development of such an area by emphasizing regulations that buffer and limit the cross effects of the district and adjacent land uses. 
4.1 Master plan. The location of buildings and structures and establishment of uses shall be in general conformance with a master land use plan, as prepared by the university, and approved by the Bourbonnais Planning Commission. The master land use plan shall designate existing and proposed buildings, structures and land uses, roadways, pedestrian walkways, and other means of access. A college or university may construct, relocate or enlarge said buildings, structures and land uses, provided that said work is consistent with the master plan as approved by the Bourbonnais Planning Commission, is consistent with the village's applicable development regulations, all necessary permits have been obtained, and said construction, relocation or enlargement is in keeping with all requirements of this district. The master plan may be amended from time to time, but any and all such amendments shall require the approval of the Bourbonnais Planning Commission. 
4.2 Permitted uses (provided said uses are affiliated with the college or university): 
a)  Public assembly uses. 
i)  Amusement and recreation uses: 
(1)  Amphitheater; 
(2)  Aquariums; 
(3)  Arenas, Field houses, stadiums, athletic fields and athletic camps; 
(3)  Auditoriums; 
(4)  Concert halls, music halls; 
(5)  Exhibition/exposition halls; 
(6)  Gymnasiums, recreation centers; 
(7)  Health spas; 
(8)  Ice rinks; 
(9)  Parks, playgrounds, arboretums; 
(10)  Performing arts center; 
(11)  Planetariums. 
ii)  Churches and religious facilities: 
(1)  Churches, synagogues, temples; 
(2)  Columbariums (a burial vault for the containment of urns holding cremated human remains along with a garden or similar space that evokes feelings of reverence, solemnity, tranquility and beauty). 
iii)  Clubs: Clubs, lodges, and organizations affiliated with the college or university located within the district, including but not limited to the following: 
(1)  Athletic clubs; 
(2)  Health clubs. 
iv)  Libraries, museums, government uses: 
(1)  Art galleries, museums; 
(2)  Community centers; 
(3)  Libraries; 
(4)  Postal services; 
v)  Food establishments: 
(1)  Restaurant; 
(2)  Donut shops; 
(3)  Ice cream shops; 
(4)  Coffee shops; 
(5)  Cafeterias; 
(6)  Food pantry. 
vi)  Passenger terminal, stations: 
(1)  Bus passenger facility; 
(2)  Taxi terminals. 
vii)  Theaters and studios: 
(1)  Theaters; 
(2)  Motions picture studios; 
(3)  Motion picture theater; 
(4)  Radio broadcasting studios; 
(5)  Television broadcasting studios. 
viii)  Educational uses: 
(1)  Non resident schools: 
(a)  Nursery schools, 
(b)  Pre-schools, 
(c)  Day care centers, 
(d)  Elementary schools, 
(e)  High schools; 
(2)  Resident schools: 
(a)  Boarding schools; 
(3)  Trade and business schools: 
(a)  Business schools, 
(b)  Vocational schools; 
(4)  Colleges and universities: 
(a)  College/university classrooms; 
(5)  Institutional uses: 
(a)  Medical clinics, 
(b)  Weather service stations and/or facilities; 
(6)  Residential uses: 
(a)  One- and two-family dwellings: 
(i)  Single-family homes, 
(ii)  Two-family homes; 
(b)  Multiple family dwellings: 
(i)  Student dormitories, 
(ii)  Student residence halls, 
(iii)  Multi-family dwellings for resident students only, provided said dwellings are owned by the college or university; 
(c)  Other:
